Known for his portraiture, Eakins calculated the work as a visual record of all the individuals present in the medical amphitheatre. Not solely a portrait of Dr. Gross and his students, Eakins inserts himself as a witness in the audience. The lighting and composition however still place all focus on the portrait of Dr. Gross.
5.     Through his master of rendering volume, individualistic features and psychological intensity, Eakins showcases his academic training in a style described as “scientific realism”; was obsessed with accuracy and known to project photographs onto canvases in order to laboriously trace figures and shift objects for a more harmoniously composed scene.

Gustave Caillebotte, Floor Scrapers, 1875
Musée d’Orsay, Paris

Realism/Impressionism
  1. Caillebotte was a member of the Impressionists, although he painted in a more realistic manner. He aimed to paint reality as it existed and as he saw it, hoping to reduce the inherent theatricality of painting.
  2. This painting is one of the first representations of urban proletariat. Whereas peasants (Gleaners by Millet) or country workers (Stone Breakers by Courbet) had often been shown, city workers had seldom been painted. Unlike Courbet or Millet, Caillebotte did not incorporate any social, moralizing or political message. His thorough documentary study (gestures, tools, accessories) justifies his position among the most accomplished realists.
  3. The tilted ground in this painting is characteristic of Caillebotte's work. His interest in high angle perspective may have been influenced by Japanese prints and/or his interest in photography as an art form.
  4. He presented it at the 1875 Salon. The Jury, shocked by its crude realism, rejected it.  Some critics talked of "vulgar subject matter" as he reintroduced the male nude as subject (torsos), but in updated form; as heroes of modern life whose pose would be demeaning if not conveying masculine strength and honest labor. He then decided to join the impressionists and exhibited it in their second exhibition in 1876.
  5. Caillebotte's sizable allowance and inheritances allowed him to paint without the pressure to sell his work and to become a patron of the Impressionists, helping fund exhibitions and supporting his fellow artists/friends through acquisitions (68 paintings).
James McNeill Whistler, Nocturne in Black and Gold: The Falling Rocket, c.1875

Aestheticism/Tonalism
  1. James McNeill Whistler (1834-1903) was an American artist active during the American Gilded Age and based primarily in the United Kingdom. He was averse to sentimentality and moral allusion in painting, and a leading proponent of the credo "art for art's sake".
  2. His artworks were often named after music compositions. This one is “nocturne” others are “symphonies,” “harmonies” etc. indicating they are artistic arrangements made for their aesthetic value. 
  3. Painting of fireworks falling over a riverbank, trees, dark blue sky. Painted in a limited color scheme, not a realistic landscape but an evocation of the magical mood created by the glowing fireworks in an evening sky. (Tonalism:  Between 1880 and 1915, dark, neutral hues such as gray, brown or blue, often dominated compositions by artists associated with the style. During the late 1890s, American art critics began to use the term "tonal" to describe these works.)
  4. This painting was the subject of the trial Ruskin v. Whistler. When Ruskin accused Whistler in the press of ripping off his buyers for charging 200 guineas for the painting and accused him of “throwing a pot of paint in the face of the public.” In many ways, the defendant in the case was not simply the art critic John Ruskin, but art—especially modern art—itself. What was in the balance here? One weighty question concerned the role of art in society. Ruskin believed that art possessed the power to improve society. For him, this was accomplished chiefly through an artwork’s ability to represent nature faithfully. Whistler’s attempt to capture the dazzling effects of a fireworks display over the Thames through startling, explosive brushwork defied the critic’s understanding of nature as a product of divine creation. Whistler believed an artwork’s usefulness detracted from its aesthetic purpose. Whistler won the suit, but still ended up bankrupt.

Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi,
Liberty Enlightening the World (Statue of Liberty), 1875‐1884

French Republican Monumental Sculpture
  1. Intended to commemorate a century of friendship between US and France. Idea for a gift of monument from French to US conceived by Republicans during Second Empire, fundraising began after Paris Commune (1871). Third Republic was particularly big on commissioning patriotic monumental sculptures as public exemplars of its motto, “moral order”.
  2. Bartholdi received commission and chose Bedloe’s island (now Liberty Island), from which he felt the statue would be most visible. He designed a monumental sculpture responding to the site: because it would generally be seen from afar, he designed a simple, Classical form with a dramatic silhouette.  
  3. The iconography of Bartholdi’s allegory of Liberty was not traditional (helmet with sunray spikes, tablet, torch). Helmet: Americans supposedly disliked Liberty’s usual French Phrygian bonnet, associated with slavery and radicalism. May have pulled idea from the Colossus of Rhodes, lost sculpture of sun god Helos that stood astride harbor of ancient city (one of 7 wonders). Reference “enlightenment,” echoed in torch. American as a beacon of freedom. (statue faced Europe: America set example for the Old World in particular) Tablet: law, which protects people’s freedoms, prevents freedom from becoming anarchy. Inscribed JULY IV MDCCLXXVI (July 4, 1776).
  4. Over 150’ tall” could not be cast in bronze. Used a new industrial method of production: beaten copper sheets that were riveted together and attached with iron braces to central skeleton. Architects Viollet-de-Duc and later Gustave Eiffel were technical consultants. Made in Paris, dismantled for shipping. 
  5. Statue's massive arm and torch at the Centennial Exposition in Philadelphia in 1876. Afterwards the pieces were displayed in Madison Square Park, New York City until 1882 to assist in fundraising. 
  6. Statue’s base designed by American architect Richard Morris Hunt; statue installed in 1886.

Gustave Moreau, Salomé Dancing before Herod, 1876
Armand Hammer Museum of Art and  Cultural Center, Los Angeles

French Symbolism / Orientalism
1. Symbolism is a movement during the Belle Époque (1890-1914) that rejects materialism and realism (and their goal of accurate observation) to turn instead to spirituality and the imagination; harked back to a Romanticist tradition
2. Symbolism believed that there was a more meaningful spiritual reality beneath the physical world and that it could be communicated only through art; symbolism was not the observation of the world but the painting of ideas, a representation of the imaginary
3. Moreau and his contemporary Redon experienced a sudden upsurge of public interest through the publication of Huysmans’ novel A rebours [Against the Grain], in which the main character retreats into a private world surrounded by the works of Moreau and Redon
4. Depicts a biblical story: Salome dancing in front of Herod in return for the head of John the Baptists
5. A romanticized rendering of a biblical story where the femme fatale is embodied in the Oriental other; the background is a composite of various orientalist spaces
6. Moreau’s is a literary symbolism in which the underlying meaning was inherent in the subject matter (different from the symbolism of Van Gogh or Gaugin);  imaginative interpretations of literary (biblical, mythological) subjects
7. Not unlike academic history painting in its subject matter (which is derived from the Bible or mythology) but unprecedented in form: use of color and chiaroscuro to create atmospheric effect suggesting the spellbinding eroticism of Salome’s dance
8. This Symbolist turn to spirituality and the imaginary occurred at a time when psychiatry saw a rapid development as a medical discipline (by Charcot and Freud in 1880s and 90s), and a revival of religiosity and esotericism to respond to the psychological pressures of the fin de siècle; symbolism can be understood in the context of such a turn to the spiritual (Moreau) and psychology (Redon), the latter anticipating the Surrealist movement by some 50 years
William Morris, Detail of Pimpernel wallpaper, 1876

Victorian
  1. William Morris was the driving force behind a new design firm, Morris, Marshal Faulkner & Co. and shared John Ruskin and Augustus Pugin’s interest in medieval art and architecture. He idealized the middle ages as a time of a democratic art form, when art was made by the people for the people, and sought to replicate this kind of socialist art in his own designs. But because it was handpainted it was incredibly expensive, and thus in conflict with his democratic ideal of art.
  2. To counter the negative effects of industrial mass production, Morris became a staunch advocate of handmade products. He inspired the Arts and Crafts Movement, an international movement that rejected machine projection, promoting instead the practice of preindustrial craft techniques
  3. His wallpaper designs were block printed and then colored by hand. They typically used a simple and stylized flower motif inspired by traditional folk art. Each print was based on a specific flower from British gardens, rather than that elaborate, exotic, unnamed plants, seeking to establish a distinctly British design. 
  4. He created structure through his designs by building strong, rhythmic and fluid lines from the shapes of leaves, vines and branches, and he frequently superimposed the main pattern over a smaller, recessive background pattern to fill the design space. This was quite at odds with the contemporary design fashion for illusion and exaggeration.
Auguste Renoir, Ball at the Moulin de la Galette, 1876

Impressionist figure painting
1.     While Realist painters like Courbet chose to represent the working life of peasants, the Impressionists chose subject matter depicting the bourgeois class at the their leisure. Impressionist pictures appear less politically charged as a result, placing emphasis on the modern leisure life. Leisure was new phenomenon on the late 19th century, and a by-product of capitalism; the middle class was no longer forced to work throughout the year in order to make a living. Bourgeois women, who were not expected to work at all became the protagonists of impressionist leisure. 
2.     This scene depicts a popular cafe in Montmartre with an open air seating area where locals came and danced on Sundays, along with a variety of students and artists. Renoir was drawn to the mixed character of the crowd. George Riviere, a friend of Renoir’s, notes that the women in this image, whom the artist had coaxed into posing for him, were of working class origin, the type who would normally frequent such dances (Montmartre was a poor, rundown area).
3.     Though it was partially painted on the spot, Renoir also made various preliminary studies. The framing of the scene in which the figures on the sides are cut off, gives the impression that it continues beyond its bounds and that this is a slice of reality.
4.     Renoir was the first to apply Impressionistic brushwork of their landscapes to figure paintings and genre scenes. Here, the brushwork helps animate the dance moment, creating a sense of the arbitrary moment. It also creates a break away from the Academic tradition: has no one focal point in the composition.
5.     Renoir was keen to present the painting as a genuine scene of Parisian life. However, this has been contended to untrue: described as a contrived image, largely populated by Renoirs middle class friends enjoying the company of lower class women– the image of carefree enjoyment is essential an ideal.
James Abbott McNeill Whistle r, Harmony in Blue and Gold: The Peacock Room, 1876‐77

Aesthetic Movement/Anglo-Japanese Style

  1. Whistler was one of the most important artists of the Aesthetic movement, a proponent of art for art's sake.
  2. It is considered an Aesthetic movement masterpiece because of its exotic nature and colors, a decadent 19th-century interior in the Anglo-Japanese style that survived intact and reflects the wider interest in Eastern design and culture characteristic of the time (Japonisme).
  3. Whistler turned the room into a total work of art; it was an unsettling and seductive environment as he painted every surface (shutters and ceiling too) in luminous shades of green, gold, and blue, contributing to a lavish but aesthetically coordinated whole.
  4. Whistler's painting The Princess from the Land of Porcelain, hangs over the mantel as the centerpiece. It was from a series of costume pictures undertaken in mid-1860s in which western models appear in Asian dress, surrounded by Chinese and Japanese objects from Whistler's own collections.
  5. The room was designed to accommodate the blue and white Chinese porcelain collection of English shipping magnate Frederick Leyland, a long-time patron of Whistler's, held in the dining room of his London house.  However, Whistler acted on his own without a commission, leading to a fallout between them as Leyland paid half of what Whistler requested after completion (equivalent of 200k pounds!).
  6. Hurt and angry, he painted the rear wall with a vindictive allegorical mural titled Art and Money; or, the Story of the Room, depicting Leyland as a stingy peacock made of money and Whistler as the poor peacock with silver crest feathers that refer to his distinctive white forelock.
  7. After Leyland died, Charles Lang Freer, a railroad-car manufacturer, acquired it. Freer installed it in his Detroit mansion as a setting for his own collection of Asian pottery. He bequeathed it to the Smithsonian in 1906, where it now lives in the Freer Gallery of Art.
  8. The room underscores Freer's belief that "all works of art go together, whatever their period." His faith in cross-cultural aesthetic harmonies achieved its ultimate expression in the Freer Gallery itself, where Whistler's Peacock Room is located between galleries of Chinese, Korean and American art, embodying the meeting of East and West, making aesthetic connections between art, decoration, paintings, ceramics, Europe, America, and Asia.

Edward Coley Burne‐Jones, Golden Stairs, 1876-­‐80
Tate Britain, London

Aesthetic Movement

  1. Edward Coley Burne-Jones (1833-1898) was a student of Dante Gabriel Rossetti and a collaborator with William Morris. He worked in the Pre-Raphaelite style and then focused on decorative art with Morris and created stained glass designs. Golden Stairs is from later in his career when he focused on the Aesthetic movement. 
  2. The Aesthetic Movement was guided by complex ideas, but most boiled down to 2 ideas set forth by Walter Horatio Pater (1839-1894): 1) Art is superior to nature. 2) Content is not as important as form. Often focused on the figure of a beautiful woman. (See Rossetti’s Monna Vanna)
  3. Burne-Jones's aim in art is best given in his own words, written to a friend: “I mean by a picture a beautiful, romantic dream of something that never was, never will be – in a light better than any light that ever shone – in a land no one can define or remember, only desire – and the forms divinely beautiful – and then I wake up, with the waking of Brynhild.”
  4. 18 women in this painting, all with musical instruments, some dating to the Middle Ages, but there is no concrete narrative or story illustrated. 
  5. Most striking for its formal qualities: subtle color, semicircular composition, contrast between hard lines of architecture and soft contour of feminine qualities. 
  6. Musical instruments hearken to the origins of the early Aesthetic ideas of Pater who thought music was the perfect aesthetic art.

Claude Monet, Gare St‐Lazare, Paris, 1877
Fogg Art Museum, Harvard Art Museum, Cambridge, MA

Impressionism
  1. Exhibited three paintings of the Gare Saint-Lazare at 3rd Impressionist exhibition of 1877. Made 12 paintings of station total, seen from various viewpoints at different times of day. 
  2. Emphasis on quality of light (here, seen through smoke): typical of Impressionism. (According to Cézanne, “Monet is only an eye, but my God what an eye!”)
  3. Shift from Monet’s previous focus on natural/pastoral scenes, painted en plein aire
  4. Series presents viewers with spectacles of the train station and chaotic modern public life
  5. He worked on all the paintings at the same time, and sometimes he leaned the stretched canvases against each other while the paint was still wet. 
  6. Thick impasto of paint in varying hues: large visible brush strokes only make sense viewed from afar: Impressionist rejection of Academic technique. 
  7. Early iteration of Monet’s series of the same subject depicted at different times of day/in different light conditions, began in earnest in 1880s (see: Haystacks, Rouen Cathedral)
Eadweard Muybridge, Horse in Motion, 1878

Stop-action photography
1. Muybridge was a British photographer working at a time when Impressionists had become interested in new forms of vision and innovations in composition, paining casual glimpses of fleeting reality as if taking photographic snapshots, as opposed to artificially arranged compositions
2. Edgar Degas copied several of Muybridge’s horse studies (reproduced in the French journal La Nature in 1878) for his own horse paintings (i.e. Jockey’s before the Start 1878) to more accurately convey the image of a horse in motion
3. Horse race tracks were modern sites par excellence, where the fashionable crowds gathered for leisure and engaged in the activity of watching, an eminently modern activity
4. In these stop-action photographs, Muybridge was attempting to answer the question: does a galloping horse ever become fully airborne? Leland Stanford (former California governor and railroad tycoon) commissioned Muybridge to prove that the answer is yes.
5. Muybridge set up 12 cameras along Stanford’s estate and developed a way to take photos with only a fraction of a second of exposure; when running by, horses triggered trip wires connected to the cameras which took photos in rapid succession
6. The answer is yes, for a split second (frame 3): too fleeting to be seen by the naked eye but apparent through photography; new purpose of the medium of photography: capturing truth through technology
7. Technological and conceptual breakthrough: capturing a span of time by a succession of singular instants (compare the philosophy of Henri Bergson)
8. His stop-action technique was an early form of animation that helped pave the way for the motion-picture industry about a decade later
Mary Cassatt, Little Girl in a Blue Armchair, 1878

Impressionism
  1. American artist Cassatt studied in France under Gérôme, Couture and others and while there was invited by Degas to join a group of artists who were exhibited independently outside of the Salon, which came to be known at the Impressionist Exhibitions. She exhibited Little Girl in a Blue Chair at the 4th Impressionist Exhibition
  2. The dominance of the overstuffed furniture with its vibrant blue upholstery captures an odd sense of restlessness and languorousness, both matched by the girl’s pose. There is a rebellious, devil-may-care attitude in her comfortably lounging form.
  3. She seeks to recreate the feeling of disorientation and tiresomeness a child feels within the social constraints of an adult’s world, a world that seems almost oppressively gendered. Here, Cassatt presents a radically new image of childhood, and domesticity in general.
  4. The similarities between Cassat’s and Degas’s work, certainly in this period, are also striking. In its asymmetrical composition, the casual, unposed treatment of the sitter, the weightiness and solidity of its forms in contrast to that grey mercurial dollop of negative space, its use of cropping and loose brushwork, as well as the interest in the private moment that we find so often in his pastels, the hallmarks of Degas’s work can clearly be found in Little Girl in a Blue Armchair.
  5. Influence of Japonisme. As a collector of Japanese prints, she drew inspiration from their patterns and asymmetric structures, influencing the asymmetrical composition, raised viewpoint, shallow space, and abrupt cropping of the scene.

Odilon Redon, Vision, plate 8 of In the Dream, 1879
Art Institute of Chicago

Symbolism
1.     French symbolist painter, printmaker, draughtsman. Anticipated Surrealism by about fifty years and pursued it through avenues of fantasy and free association. Explores psychology through dreams and memories.
2.     Slow to venture into the public artistic arena, he did not launch his career until 1879 when he published an album of ten lithographs, In the Dream. This eighth print from the series is typical of the rest of his work, which often show eyeballs or disembodied heads floating in space. 
3.     In this print, a man and woman wandering through a colossal architectural space come upon a huge eyeball hovering between two columns. What makes the print intriguing is that it appears to suggest the occurrence of an intensifying series of visual experiences that come closer to an ‘ultimate’ vision that in itself remains invisible (the vision of the viewer of the work, the vision of the couple, and finally the vision of the eyeball directed towards the sky, appearing to catch a glimpse of something so bright that it cause it to be aglow in halo of light. 
4.     Draws from Christian imagery, most notably in Baroque paintings of visionary saints, where their eyes are opened wide as they catch a glimpse of the divine. 
5.     His hovering eyes and heads have also been associated with the contemporary fascination with hot air balloons as well as the popularization of astronomy manifested in numerous articles in family and children’s magazines.
Arnold Bocklin, Island of the Dead, 1880

Symbolism
  1. Böcklin was a Symbolist painter recognized as the leading Swiss artist of the 19th century. His paintings bore the influences of classical and Renaissance art and the Mediterranean landscape.  Böcklin created a strange, brooding fantasy world, populated by fantastical figures. 
  2. This is one of five versions of Isle of the Dead (1880–1886), his best-known work. In 1880 Marie Berna, a young widow, visited Böcklin's studio in Florence where she saw an unfinished first version of this painting on his easel. She asked for a “picture to dream by,” and commissioned a similar work as a memorial to her husband, requesting the additions of the draped coffin and shrouded female figure. This image would become widely circulated through a related etching of 1890 by Max Klinger.
  3. It was inspired by the Castello Alfonso (Aragon Castle), off the island of Ischia in Italy, where Böcklin spent the autumn of 1879. A solitary rock rises straight up from a dead calm sea where the viewer’s gaze is led up the steps but gets lost in the impenetrable darkness of the tall cypresses. The inner faces of the rock are cut with oblong portals, suggesting sepulchers. The island’s high cliff walls, the still surface of the water and the magical lighting create a sublime atmosphere, evoking a sense other-worldliness. The boat bearing the coffin with a white clad figure adds a melancholy tone.
  4. The scene is a solid embodiment of the beyond, which encapsulates many of Symbolism's tenets: a desire for artistic refuge, themes of mysticism, and a keen sense of mortality linked to the fin de siècle. In a nutshell, as Mallarmé wrote, Symbolism's goal was 'to depict not the thing but the effect it produces.'
  5. Böcklin greatly influenced Surrealists like Max Ernst, Giorgio de Chirico and Salvador Dalí.
  6. This work was enormously popular. Freud had a reproduction in his office, so did Lenin, and Hitler owned a version.
H. Béchard, Egyptian Peasant Girl, c. 1880

Orientalist photography
  1. While some traveled to document the “Orient” to document architecture, archaeology, and landscape, others took ethnographic photographs of indigenous people. Sculptor Charles Cordier is one example of this, however his photos do not survive. These are similar photographs from the era. 
  2. Orientalism 
  3. Used as ethnography in order to reproduce the types of people around the world. Goes hand-in-hand with the rise of European imperialism. From a drive to better control the world. Also used by anthropology to contribute to theories on race and types.
  4. Travel photography was often sold in pictorial travel albums starting with Maxime Du Camp. 
  5. Photography also used by Cordier to create ethnographic sculpture of different racial and ethnic types.
Max Klinger, Abduction, (plate IX) from A Glove, Opus V, 1881 (print Executed 1880)

Symbolism
  1. This plate is from Klinger’s best-known work, a “cycle” (series) of nightmarish, Gothic etchings incorporating fantastic imagery. Klinger was a prolific printmaker, working to reclaim the medium from its industrial connotations.
  2. Klinger (German, 1857-1920) studied in Karlsruhe under socialist realist painter Karl Gussow, whose influence likely encouraged him to go on to make socially-critical art. 
  3. Was interested in the novels of French writers Émile Zola and Gustave Flaubert, which exposed the darker side of urban life and the hypocrisy of the bourgeoisie; also interested in Charles Darwin’s theories of evolution. 
  4. Influenced by Japanese prints (less popular in Germany than in France at the time). WIth A Glove, for which Klinger received acclaim in Berlin, he began to experiment with intaglio printmaking processes (including etching, drypoint, and aquatint). 
  5. A Glove presages Freud’s work on fetishes: for the lover in the series, the titular glove becomes a displaced symbol of erotic yearning, taking on a life of its own and appearing like Venus, born from seafoam and driving a shell chariot. In this plate, a nightmarish creature steals the glove. 
  6. Influenced Surrealists including Giorgio De Chirico and Max Ernst, as well as German Expressionists, who claimed his graphic style as part of their Germanic heritage.
Auguste Rodin, The Gates of Hell, 1880‐1917

Symbolism / Fin de Siècle sculpture
1. While Rodin’s early work has been described as Naturalist due to its high verisimilitude (i.e. The Age of Bronze), his work at the turn of the century can be called Symbolist (attempting to express the spiritual in the commonplace)
2. Symbolism is less a style or a coherent artistic movement than a state of mind at the fin de siècle: marked by a desire to find meaning in the commonplace and a deeper truth in the recesses of the soul
3. The Gates of Hell is a set of bronze doors commissioned by the government in 1880 for the yet to be built Museum of Decorative Arts; the museum never materialized but Rodin continued to work on the doors for the rest of his career; he showed an unfinished plaster model of them in a private exhibition in 1900; they were only cast in bronze after his death
4. Drawing on Dante Alighieri’s Divine Comedy, in particular the second circle of hell (Inferno) in which one can find carnal sinners (too much sex): writhing figures in passionate embrace and in painful remorse; the lustful and the sufferers; more than 180 figures struggling to free themselves from the swirling mass of material
5. In its close packing of a multitude of bodies and the expressive poses of muscular male bodies, Gates of Hell has been compared to Michelangelo’s Last Judgement (Sistine Chapel) and Delacroix’s Death of Sardanapalus (1827-8)
6. On the rectangular area above the doors (tympana of medieval churches) perches Le Penseur: has been considered to represent Dante himself, or an allegory of thought, creativity and conscience. Above the gates stand the Three Shades: spirits of the dead who point to the sufferings below. Many of the over 200 models of individual figures eventually became independent sculptures.
7. Rodin’s works are remarkable for their unprecedented relation between sculpture and support: sculptures are not self-contained but only barely emerge from the raw and coarse material (marble or plaster) which they have been carved out of
8. Two exemplars of The Gates of Hell are now in the United States: one in Stanford, one in the Rodin Museum in Philadelphia.
Edgar Degas, Little Dancer of Fourteen Years Old, 1881

French Realism?
  1. Degas’s work underwent a transition in the 1880s from the “theatrical” to absorptive” presentation of the human subject: From the ballet and racetrack scenes, to women alone, often grooming themselves in their own bedrooms. These two terms were coined by Michael Fried and distinguish between figure paintings in which the subject seems to be aware of the painter’s/viewer’s presence, and those in which the subject is not. While this is not a grooming image, it does narrow in on the internal life of a young ballerina in a moment of introspection, seemingly oblivious to the presence of the viewer/artist.
  2. In spite of the difficult position in which she is placed, both physically and psychologically, the girl is depicted struggling for a measure of dignity: her head is held high, though her arms and hands are uncomfortably stretched behind her back.
  3. He turned to sculpture during this period for his own enjoyment, rarely selling or exhibiting them. Little Dancer was one of the only sculptures he ever exhibited, shown at Impressionist exhibition of 1881.
  4. It was originally a wax statue with a tutu made of gauze and a wig of real hair tied with a ribbon exhibited in a glass vitrine which made the work appear as an anthropological specimen. 28 Bronze casts have been made throughout the 20th C. 
  5. The sculpture caused uproar not only for the medium but for its “dreadful ugliness.” The sculpture was perceived as a specimen of human degeneration, a feared biological trend that entailed a return to a lower stage in the evolutionary process traced by Darwin. Degeneration was believed to manifest itself both in behavior and physical characteristics was thought to occur in the lowest urban class, from which dancers often came (Dancers were often forced to worked as prostitutes at this time). As such, the Little Dancer represented a human specimen – praised for its scientifically accurate representation of the facial characteristics of the degenerate.
  6. The sculpture showed the dark underside of the ballet scenes Degas had become admired for, forcing viewers to confront the seamy side of the cultural institution at the center of metropolitan life.
  7. The “terrifying reality” of the sculpture and its unusual materials that prioritized naturalism over idealization made the work daringly modern and upset all traditions of sculpture.

Edouard Manet, A Bar at the Folies Bergère, 1881­‐82
Courtauld Institute Galleries, London

French Realism/Impressionism

1.     Manet’s last major work, presented at the Salon of 1882 just one year before his death. The painting is the culmination of the interest of the Impressionists in scenes of urban leisure and spectacle. 
2.     Represents the bustling interior of one of the most prominent music halls and cabarets of Paris, the Folies-Bergère. Manet knew the setting of the club well and made a number of preparatory sketches there but the final work aws painted in his studio where he set up a bar and asked one of the barmaids to serve as a model.
3.     The club was also known for the barmaids, who were assumed to be available as clandestine prostitutes. By depicting one of these women and her male customer on an imposing scale, Manet introduces a moral subject into the realm of high art. 
4.     The image is regarded for its open endedness and perpetual questioning: the barmaid maintains an ambiguous demeanour somewhere between assertiveness and disenchantment. She stands and meets the viewer’s gaze but also draws away from it. 
5.     The dynamics of the mirror reflection in this work has been the subject of much debate: the barmaid’s reflection is too far off the right, that the objects along the counter illogically displaced: however, critics have suggested that Manet uses the mirror to show the viewer the world that the barmaid is looking out onto, and in doing so, gives her a vantage point (enabling her perspective while keeping her the subject of the painting). 
6.     His painting has been lauded for its directness that for some lacked dignity and refinement, exacerbated by the flat brushwork and loose handling of paint. The painting is equivocal and self-aware– attributes that are now designated as modern.

Wilhelm Leibl, Three Women in Church or Women of Dachau (Bavaria), 1882
Kunsthalle, Hamburg

German Naturalism

  1. Leibl was a realist painter of portraits and scenes of peasant life. He was influenced by Courbet's visit to Munich in 1869 and a subsequent stay/study in Paris (age 25), interrupted by the outbreak of the Franco-Prussian War.
  2. It depicts three rural peasants of different generations at the moment of prayer in Bavaria. The painting took 3.5 years to complete, the sitters sat for him daily, weather permitting as he built the work painstakingly. Dressed in rustic costume they quietly pursue their devotions, holding their prayer books in large hands roughened by work.
  3. Leibl’s keen attention to detail is seen in each individual's expression of religious piety, his scrupulous attention to physiognomy, poses, and hands, and the dark wood rococo pews. His sharp focus realism can be credited to his interest in photography and his study of 16C masters like Hans Holbein, to whom his works are often compared.
  4. His compassionate view of his subjects devoid of sentimentality is recognized as his greatest painting, as the outside appearance of his sitters seems infused with a sense of their inner life. 
  5. Leibl painted peasants but it was not the land or their labor that interested him (Courbet, Millet), instead, it was the effect of the land on people's character.
  6. This work formed a crucial link between mid-19th c. German Realism and International Nationalism evident at the Salon of 1889.  It is like his previous works in the same vein of realism, but the faithful reproduction of local costumes and the title (Women of Dachau) (Bavaria), reflect a new interest in pictures celebrating national identity.
  7. Leibl painted without preliminary drawing, starting directly with color.
Medardo Rosso, The Concierge (La Portinaia), 1883

Fin de Siècle sculpture
  1. Medardo Rosso (1858–1928) was born in Turin, Italy, and worked as a painter until 1880. He lived in Paris for two years, worked in Dalou’s atelier, and met Rodin. After 1889 Rosso spent most of his remaining active career in Paris, and was associated more with French sculpture than with Italian.
  2. Rosso extended the formal experiments of Rodin, deliberately dissolving sculptural forms until only an impression remained.
  3. His favorite medium, wax, allowed the most imperceptible transitions, so that it becomes difficult to tell at exactly what point a face or figure emerges from an amorphous shape and many-textured surface. Wax captured light and shadow and created a soft sfumato aura around the figure. 
  4. Sometimes called an impressionist sculptor. In his ability to catch and record the significant moment, Rosso added a new dimension to sculpture, in works that are intimiste, small-scale, and antiheroic, and anticipated the search for immediacy that characterizes so much of the sculpture to follow.
John Singer Sargent, Madame X, 1883‐84

Gilded-Age/Grand Manner Portraiture 
  1. Sargent was an expat, born in America but working in Paris. He also painted Impressionist works, but his portraits were done in the Grand Manner, which idealized and aestheticized  its subjects. 
  2. Painting shows Madame Pierre Gautreau (the Louisiana-born Virginie Amélie Avegno; 1859–1915), who was known in Paris for her artful appearance. (Not a commission, but she agreed to sit for him, hoped to enhance her appearance). Known for her very white skin.
  3. At the Salon of 1884, this painting (an iconic image) caused a scandal: Gautreau was initially painted with the right strap/chain of her gown having fallen from her shoulder, seen by critics as immoral/alarmingly provocative. Sargent ultimately repainted it to appease Gautreau and critics. 
  4. Painting intended to be his advertisement of his skills at fashionable and flattering portraiture and despite (because of?) scandal, it worked: Sargent became known as a grand-manner portraitist to the wealthy elite, particularly in England and America. 
  5. Purchased by the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1916 (Sargent considered it “the best thing I have done.”)
  6. Visited Monet at Giverny multiple times beginning in summer 1885. His commissioned portraits continued to support him financially, but he experimented with Impressionist techniques, ultimately becoming well-established as a watercolorist by 1907, when he stopped accepting commissions.
Antoni Gaudí, Church of the Sagrada Família, 1883‐1926, Barcelona

Spanish Modernisme
1. Modernisme was the Spanish version of the myriad national Art Nouveau movements in European architecture and design circles at the turn of the 20th century
2. Fueled by optimism and belief in progress of the 1890s, Art Nouveau was a reaction against the historic eclecticism that had dominated interior design of the previous ages, calling instead for stylistic unity and entirely new architectural and decorative language
3. The most exuberant and idiosyncratic representative of Spanish Modernisme is Antoni Gaudí in the Catalan city of Barcelona, where he sought a distinctly Catalan style at a time when the region was experiencing a resurgence of cultural pride
4. Gaudí had worked in the historic eclectic style common to the time but abandoned it in 1900 to turn instead to nature for inspiration (not to imitate it but to transform it creatively into new imaginative forms)
5. The Sagrada Família, Gaudí’s life work, was a commission by a local religious group who wanted to build a cathedral-size expiatory chapel for the Holy Family; Gaudí worked on the church until his death in 1926; he himself was a deeply religious Catholic
6. He took over the traditional basilica cruciform structure and the Neo-Gothic design of his predecessor but overlaid it with fluid sculptural decorations making the building resemble a living organism (a stalactite cave or a petrified forest); all straight angles replaced by serpentines and curves
7. Four tall spires (double of the usual two) were completed only after Gaudí’s death: have a square base turning into tubes, topped by elaborate finials designed in the Art Deco style of the 1930s
8. In the remainder of the church, completed after Gaudí’s death, historians have identified influences by African mud architecture, Gothic, Expressionist and Art Nouveau styles
9. Gaudí was influenced by Viollet-le-Duc, a leading proponent of Gothic Revival style: Sagrada Família begun as a Gothic Revival structure but evolved into a building without historic style, rather the expression of personal architectural imagination
10.  While frequently subsumed under the general header of Art Nouveau, Gaudí was in advance of comparable experiments in the rest of Europe

Georges Seurat, A Sunday At La Grande Jatte, 1884, 1884‐86
Art Institute of Chicago

Neo-Impressionism
  1. 1886 was the last Impressionist group show, after which the group disintegrated due to internal disagreements and the rise of the Society of Independent Artists which had organized its own non-juried salon. La Grande Jatte was exhibited at this last Impressionist show and was the most discussed.
  2. This monumentally scaled painting was unique among the Impressionists for its content - the juxtaposition of different social classes – and its style – the figures are frozen, aloof and simplified in contrast to the dynamic and animated figures of Renoir or Degas.
  3. He was inspired by the statuesque figures in the wall paintings of Puvis de Chavannes, but gives his a distinctly modern character. He was particularly influenced by the careful spacing of figures (the pyramidal device for example) throughout the composition that he believe gave Puvis’s work their pictorial majesty.
  4. Use of pointillism – small dots of different colors place on a base color that approximated the local color of the object depicted. This was a systematic application of paint, almost scientific, that diverged greatly from looseness of the impressionists. Seurat’s method was aimed at achieving an “optical mixture,” and one critic made the connection between Seurat and Modern Chromatics, a textbook on color by British physicist Ogden Root. By roots explanation, the different colors mixed in the eye which lent a greater luminosity than traditional pigment mixing on a palette.
  5. Seurat offsets the dominant color with its complementary, something Delacroix had also done 50 years earlier, inspired by the writings of pigment chemist, Eugène Chevreul, who described the intense psychological impact of colors and argued that colors combinations appear beautiful when “in harmony,” achieved through the juxtaposition of complementary colors.
  6. Color harmony for Seurat (as for Delacroix) was not only aesthetic by symbolic, a way to achieve an effect of timeless and ideal beauty, a Classical frieze of contemporary reality. He stated that his artistic model was the Frieze of the Parthenon in Athens represented the Panathenaic procession. Symbolically, the harmonies of contrasting color reflected the harmonious gathering of Parisians from contrasting backgrounds

Pierre Puvis de Chavannes, The Sacred Grove Beloved of the Arts and the Muses, 1884­‐89
Art Institute of Chicago

Symbolism
1.     The paintings of Puvis made their mark in the years following the Franco-Prussian war, and were thus tied to the question of the identity of France. Scholars have noted that his success as a ‘painter of France’ was largely due to his ability to create works which were aligned with the many ideologies existing at the time. 
2.     The original image was commissioned in 1883 as Royalists and Republican battled for the meaning of French identity. This painting, intended to be exhibited in a public space, had to satisfy the ideological mindset of the Republican commissioner. Decorations in public spaces also had to have an educational purpose. These criteria served as a framework for Puvis in his structure and reasoning.
3.     One of three versions, this work was mounted in the entry staircase in the Museum of Fine Arts in Lyon where it currently remains (other two at the AIC and the Met). The three works depict a number of deistic figures draped loosely in sheets, surrounding a mythical forest, populated by angels and muses. 
4.     Unlike his other works this did not depict a historical event or a well-known geographical landscape. While most painters of the late 19th century were pursuing more modern subjects, this image is a nod to classical art and makes a direct reference to visions of Hellenistic Greece. 
5.     Considered an example of the strain of Symbolist art that privileges the ideal over the darker side of the Sublime. The image has perhaps been identified as highly idealistic because of its carefully wrought structure: the placement of the muses forms a pyramidal composition. (the pyramidal device was commonly used in Puvis’s works). The painting peopled with muses in separate groups helps frame the composition through their body positions.

Vincent van Gogh, Potato Eaters, 1885
Rijksmuseum Vincent van Gogh, Amsterdam

Realism/Expressionism/Post-impressionism?

  1. Van Gogh was a Dutch artist who came to art late and was largely self-taught.  He had a prolific output between 1883-1890 when he died of suicide at age 37.
  2. Before moving to Paris in 1886, he practiced a form of still life and peasant painting inspired by Jozef Israëls, and his second cousin, Anton Mauve, (both members of the Hague School) as well as Millet, though rawer. In his words, “a painting of peasant life should not be perfumed.”
  3. This was his most ambitious painting produced until then, completed just before his Paris arrival (where his brother Theo lived), and he hoped it would build his non-existent reputation.  His acquaintance there with Impressionism and Neo-Impressionism made it clear that though highly original, his painting was out of step with modern trends. Today it is considered his first masterpiece.
  4. The distorted faces meant to convey that poverty and hard physical labor stunt the human mind. It expresses Van Gogh's indignation that society allows people to live stultifying lives, while also expressing respect for the integrity of peasant life and manual labor. The work's new way of presenting the peasants in a stark, expressive manner was radical.   
  5. He painted the five figures in earth colors – ‘something like the color of a really dusty potato, unpeeled of course.’ Its play of light and dark, chiaroscuro, is technically well achieved and important as it was intentionally dark, featuring a very narrow tonal range, with only a pale light coming from the lantern. Van Gogh self-consciously linked the darkness of the subject with that of the painting, hoping to become a modern peasant painter.  He had seen the changing landscape in the Netherlands as industrialization encroached on once pastoral settings and the livelihoods of the working poor with little opportunity to change vocation. 
  6. He deliberately chose a difficult composition to prove he was becoming a good figure painter. To depict the harsh reality of country life he gave the peasants coarse faces and bony, working hands. The message was more important than correct anatomy or technical perfection.
Fun fact: The early and final version of the painting were stolen and recovered twice, in 1988 and 1991, respectively.
Edgar Degas, Ballerina and Lady with a Fan, 1885

Urban Impressionism
  1. Edgar Degas (1834-1917) showed at the second Impressionist exhibition in 1876, but his artwork was quite unlike the outdoor plein-air impressions of Monet and Renoir. Interested in vision, but in angles of perception not light and atmosphere. 
  2. The composition is almost always a view from an oblique angle like this one which comes closer to the way we perceive the world than staged images in the center of our field of vision framed by neutral space. Our view of the world is often from an angle, randomly framed, looking obliquely at something depending on our position. 
  3. This framing was cut off like some photography, but that comparison is one to be careful with as Degas’ artwork prefigured the snapshot by several decades. 
  4. Degas almost always painted/drew the indoor spaces of urban life like scenes of ballet dancers and Cabarets. They were modern scenes par excellence, from the places where those who were a la mode were found. Watching was a modern activity. 
  5. Color from pastels, his favorite technique (he often mixed them with oil paints too) that created a luminous color as if lit by gaslight on stage. He captured the bright illumination and deep shadow. In his late career, the pastel was a medium he used most frequently.
  6. Use of pastel to replicate surface texture.
Henry Hobson Richardson, Marshall Field Wholesale Store, 1885-­‐87

Romanesque Revival
  1. H.H. Richardson was known for his designs in the Romanesque revival style (sometimes called Richardsonian Romanesque). Here, adapted for a commercial-use building, intended to be a wholesale warehouse for Marshall Field’s department store. 
  2. Demonstrated that large commercial block could have an integrated design. 
  3. Large arches allowed for larger windows and thinner supports between them (versus if the windows were set into the solid masonry)
  4. Did away with historical ornament prevalent at the time: Richardson used the monochromatic surface of the granite and brownstone to provide visual interest (similar to designs of Romanesque Palazzos in Italy), supplemented only by a chamfer at the corners and an enriched terminal cornice. 
  5. Seen at time as paradigmatic of a distinctly American style. Richardson, along with architects including Frank Lloyd Wright and Louis Sullivan, was among those who defined the style of American architecture in the late 19th and early 20th century. 
  6. Influenced Sullivan and Dankmar Adler (Adler + Sullivan), particularly in their designs for the Auditorium Building (Chicago, c. 1889).
William M. Harnett, The Old Violin, 1886

American trompe l’oeil still life
1. Contemporaneous to Symbolism in Europe, trompe l’oeil painting in America represented the survival of the Realist strain, pushing the notion of verisimilitude to its extreme, fooling the spectator to confuse the painted image with reality itself (trompe l’oeil = “trick on the eye”)
2. The use of trompe l’oeil effects dates back to the 15th century, especially popular in 17th century Dutch painting
3. Dismissed by art critics for its deceptiveness (seen as lacking a deeper truth), but popular amongst lay people for its cleverness and craft; often hung in bars or saloons; often included narrative and a moral lesson, which appealed to many American patrons
4. Harnett was trained as an engraver in Pennsylvania and later New York; went to Europe in 1880s (London, Frankfurt, Munich); spent four years in Munich painting still lives but took on none of the fluid painterly brushwork associated with the Munich school; was commercially successful at the end of his career, but relegated to the margins of the professional artistic community (never elected to the National Academy)
5. His style of precise still-life painting and uncanny naturalism changed very little throughout his career: small groups of darkly toned objects, later including time-worn objects from his collection of artistic bric-a-brac; however, he did shift his compositions from table tops to vertical planes of doors from which objects hung suspended
6. This painting shows a violin, sheet of music (Bellini’s La Somnambula), a small newspaper clipping, blue envelope against a green wooden door
7. Probably the most famous painting by Harnett during his lifetime and – thanks to the celebrated chromolithograph produced of it – his best known image after his death; inspired a host of copies, forgeries, and alternate versions (i.e. by Jefferson Davis Chalfant or John Friedrich Peto); a crucial painting in his career, establishing his reputation and provoking heated debate about the value of his highly veristic art; created a furore at its first exhibition in Cincinnati and continued to be hugely successful at a popular level (a police guard was required to ensure crowds would keep their distance and not reach for the violin)
Adler and Sullivan, Auditorium Building, Chicago, Ill., 1886-­89

American Industrial Architecture
  1. The 1880s saw the rise of the skyscraper in New York, but especially in Chicago, dreamed up by the Chicago School of Architecture. The Great Fire in 1871 had razed much of the city and created an unprecedented need for rebuilding, which architects saw as an opportunity to innovate to meet its role as an industrial hub.
  2. Technological advancements such as steel skeletal frame and elevator made it possible to built higher in the cities where the cost of land was high. The use of iron and glass was largely influenced by the Crystal Palace (1851)
  3. Louis Sullivan established a theoretical foundation for modern architecture in the US, enthusiastically embracing new materials, technologies and style.
  4. He worked under William Le Baron Jenney, the leading figure of the Chicago school, and then after some time in Paris at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts returned to Chicago to become a partner at Dankmar Adler’s firm. The Auditorium Building, consisting of an auditorium, hotel and office block, was the most important commission they received during Adler and Sullivan’s early years.
  5. The exterior design is influenced by H.H. Richardson’s Marshall Field Warehouse in Chicago, its style described as “Romanesque revival.” The load-bearing rusticated stone walls of the building made the cultural hub appear as a Romanesque palazzo. The foundation was solid enough to support a 16 story tower.
  6. Sullivan’s search for new mode of architectural expression is best seen inside the theater, which was acclaimed for its amazing acoustics, air-conditioning system and striking decoration entirely independent of classical, Medieval or renaissance motifs, instead turning to nature and geometric patterns. Richness of decoration was one of Sullivan’s trademarks.
  7. His famous phrase “form follows function” does not suggest he advocated for a plainly utilitarian aesthetic but that functions of edifice should be expressed in its form and once this form was achieved, there was no reason to leave it unadorned.
Augustus Saint‐Gaudens, Adams Memorial, 1886‐91,Washington, D.C.

American Naturalism
1.     Public commissions for sculptures boomed alongside the growth of the economy in the late 19th century but was mostly done in an academic style. 
2.     Saint-Gaudens was an American sculptor who combined naturalism and monumentality in his work and was best known for this cast-bronze allegorical figure: grave marker commissioned by author/historian Henry Adams to commemorate his wife, who committed suicide by drinking chemicals used to develop photographs. 
3.     Adams who had travelled to Japan to look for inspiration for the sculpture, advised Saint-Gaudens to contemplate iconic images from Buddhist devotional art, referencing the Buddhist concept of nirvana (state of being beyond joy or sorrow). One such subject was Kannon (the Bodhisattva of compassion). Adams wanted the serene elements of Buddhist figures to be contrasted with the waterfall like robe associated with Kannon. 
4.     In Adams’s circle of artists and writers, the old Christian certainties were considered inadequate after the violence of the Civil War, the industrialization of American and Darwin’s theories of evolution. Saint-Gauden’s ambiguous figure reflects the search for new insights into the mysteries of life and death. The shrouded being is neither male nor females, neither triumphant nor downcast. The message is inscrutable. 
5.     During the three decades of his career, Saint-Gaudens career, he redirected the course of American sculpture away from a worn out Neoclassical aesthetic to a more lively naturalistic style. Inspired by the sculptors of the Renaissance, he infused the classical tradition with his own brand of naturalism.
Henry Peach Robinson, Carolling, 1887

Pictorialism
 
  1. Robinson was one of the most vocal advocates of photography as a fine art in 19C England. As the Pictorialist's leader he advocated for painterly effects in photography, emphasizing beauty of subject matter, subjective emotions, tonality, and composition, rather than the documentation of objective reality. Pictorialism approached the camera as a tool that, like the paintbrush and chisel, could be used to make an artistic statement.
  2. Robinson is best known for his pioneering combination printing, an early example of photomontage, that enabled him to assemble elaborate compositions. The technique involved exposing several negatives onto the same paper to form a single image. He often used sketches to prepare, like for Carolling, a combination print made up of three glass plate negatives of different portions of the image.
  3. Robinson often printed or engraved the title of the photograph or a small text that was meant to enhance the meaning or make narrative sense of the scene. This poetic citation functions as an epigraph by casting the emotional tone of the image and was a key element of Robinson’s fictive space, connecting his work to academic painting's interest in the literary, as suggestive titles and poetic associations were common practices in the Royal Academy exhibitions; most commonly scenes from Shakespeare as in this image. His hope was that viewers would assume the relationship between text and image to be akin to academic painting.
  4. His subjects were anecdotal and often pastoral, favoring the sentimental scenes common in the Victorian era, making this image an excellent example of both his vision and technique.
  5. Although he sometimes used natural settings, he often imitated the out-of-doors inside his studio, to control lighting, air flow, and his models.  Costumed actors or society ladies modeled for his bucolic scenes, since he found country people too awkward and dull to fit his picturesque ideal. Because his goal was to produce photographs that mimicked paintings, he had no qualms about mixing the real and the artificial to achieve a “pictorial” effect.  
  6. He published Pictorial Effect in Photography (1869), a handbook that for decades remained the most influential work on photographic practice and aesthetics (wrote 7 other books).  The title is the first time “pictorial” was used in relation to photography and is the basis for the term “pictorialism."
  7. Robinson anticipated elements in the work of contemporary photographers like Philip-Lorca DeCorcia's theatricality and the complex staging of Jeff Wall or Gregory Crewdson.
Vincent Van Gogh, Night Café, 1888

Post-Impressionism
  1. Vincent van Gogh (1853-90) was a post-impressionist master of color.  He was sharply aware of the extraordinary effects he was achieving through his expressive use of color. “Instead of trying to reproduce exactly what I have before my eyes, I use color more arbitrarily,” he wrote, “in order to express myself forcibly.”
  2. Van Gogh said of Night Cafe, “I have tried to express the terrible passions of humanity by means of red and green.” The Night Café is a nightmare of deep-green ceiling, blood-red walls, and discordant greens in the furniture. The perspective of the brilliant yellow floor is tilted so precipitously that the contents of the room threaten to slide toward the viewer. Uses clashing colors and disharmony to create a visceral response. 
  3. Van Gogh also felt that colors took on an intriguing quality at night, especially by gaslight: in this painting, he wanted to show how “the white clothing of the café owner, keeping watch in a corner of this furnace, becomes lemon yellow, pale and luminous green.”
  4. This cafe in Arles was an all-night haunt, populated by vagrants and prostitutes. 
  5. He called it his “ugliest picture” but it wasn’t necessarily unsuccessful, in fact the disquieting atmosphere prefigures the uncanny landscapes and interiors of the surrealists.
Emile Bernard, Breton Women in a Meadow, 1888

Post-Impressionism/Cloisonnism
  1. Bernard called this technique Cloisonnism, after cloisonné enamel, in which thin bands of metal (usually gold or silver) are used to outline areas which are then filled with bright enamel pastes. In Cloisonnism, dark lines bound areas of flat, lighter color. Took inspiration from Gothic art (stained-glass and enamel work) and Japanese ukiyo-e woodblock prints (popular among his peers). 
  2. Simplified forms, increasing abstraction. Not a naturalist, illusory depiction of 3D reality: rather, expressions of reality’s inner mystery and poetry. 
  3. Painted the year that Bernard (1868-1941) met Paul Gauguin, at suggestion of van Gogh. Gauguin was interested in Bernard’s ideas and painted a number of works with Breton subjects that exemplify what Gauguin called “style” (increasingly abstract) eg, Vision after the Sermon, 1888). 
  4. This painting was a response to Vision after the Sermon: Bernard was annoyed that Gauguin was usurping his artform. Meant to contrast Gauguin’s mysterious scene: according to Bernard, he “deliberately painted a sunlit field, illuminated with Breton bonnets and blue-black groups.”
  5. Gauguin coined the term “Synthetism” to differentiate his work from Bernard’s. 3 goals: to convey something about real appearance of subject, express poetry artist saw within it, create works with a “decorative” quality (form over subject matter).
James Ensor, The Entry of Christ into Brussels, 1888

Belgian Symbolism / The Group of Twenty (Les XX)
1. Belgian artist James Ensor was a founding member and most original artist of The Group of Twenty (Les XX), an avant-garde exhibition society of Symbolist artists organizing nine annual exhibitions in the 1880s and 90s as a progressive alternative to the Brussels Salon, controlled by the Belgian Academy (like to Impressionists in France in the 1870s and 80s but more international in scope)
2. Ensor started as a Realist painter but became increasingly experimental in style and technique: turns from real to imaginary subjects; experiments with layering to represent space; use of palette knives, spatulas, and both ends of his brush to create textured canvas (in response to the French Pointillist style)
3. Usually a painter of private and intimate interiors, this is Ensor’s largest and most public work which, ironically, was never exhibited (rejected by Les XX)
4. Entry of Christ shows a traditional biblical theme transposed into contemporary reality: a political rally with marching bands and banners (reading “Long Live the Socialist State”). Political significance: painted three years after the founding of the Belgian Workers’ Party, a socialist opposition party
5. Christ is riding on a donkey behind a marching band, surrounded by grotesque figures in the papier maché masks typical of Belgian Mardi Gras parades; represents a mob, threatening to trample the viewer, a crude, ugly, chaotic, dehumanized sea of masks, frauds, clowns, and caricatures; Christ is in part a self-portrait: mostly ignored, a precarious, isolated visionary amidst the herdlike masses of modern society; Christ functions as a political spokesman for the poor and oppressed
6. Compare to Brueghel’s Christ Carrying the Cross (1564): also shows a biblical scene transposed to contemporary reality; Christ is equally swallowed up by the crowd
7. With its aggressive, painterly style and merging of the public with the deeply personal, Christ's Entry is a forerunner of twentieth-century Expressionism.
Paul Sérusier, Landscape: The Bois d’Amour (The Talisman), 1888

Symbolism / Post-Impressionism – The Nabis
  1. Sérusier founded a Symbolist cult group called the Nabis. Taking their name from the Hebrew word nabi (prophet) they saw themselves as initiations of a highly subjective art deeply rooted in the soul of the artist. The “talisman” of the movement, painted under Gauguin’s direct guidance, was this painting.
  2. Gauguin had encouraged Sérusier to approach nature more subjectively, freeing himself from the restrictions of realistic representation. He advised Sérusier to use colors straight from the tube resulting in a picture barely recognizable as a landscape, made up of irregular areas of flat contrasting colors, considerably more abstract than anything Gauguin did.
  3. The Nabis (later including Pierre Bonnard, Maurice Denis and Edouard Vuillard) believed that a painting was first and foremost a harmonious ensemble of lines and colors. It was in this arrangement of lines and colors that the subjectivity and personality of the artist would be encouraged to manifest.
  4. This recognition that before becoming a landscape, a painting is merely a canvas covered with colors assembled in a certain order, anticipates the idea of medium specificity that Clement Greenberg would champion in the United States in the 1950s, and the emphasis on personal expression and individual sensation anticipates the abstract expressionists.
Vincent Van Gogh, Starry Night, 1889

Post-Impressionism
1.     While the works of Seurat, Cézanne and Van Gogh are now considered to move away from the impressionists’ core concerns, these artists still thought of themselves as Impressionists. It was not until the early 20th century that their works were seen as distinct from the Impressionists, differing only in that they believed their predecessors were too naturalistic: engaged in expressive brushwork as a psychological reaction to the world.
2.     Van Gogh’s exaggerated brushstrokes are seen most clearly in his last works, painted after a series of seizures that led him to commit himself to an asylum in Saint-Rémy near Arles, where he painted the Starry Night during one of the extended lucid periods between intermittent attacks. 
3.     As an artist who preferred working from observation, his subjects in the asylum were limited to his surroundings and views of outside his window. Here, he depicts the view of the countryside visible through his window, modified to express his feelings about life, death and infinity. While he has a painted numerous other paintings observing the view from his window, this is the only nocturne in the series. 
4.     What is striking about the image is that with the exception of the village, the rest of the scene appears to be in motion. The mountains wash up and recede like waves, the cypress trees reach up to the sky like flames, the bright stars rotate and leave coiled trails. We are confronted with an animated force on nature that is associated with God or the Creator (adds a religious interpretation to the painting)
5.     Van Gogh intended for the work to inspire others to emulate night scenes (writes to Theo, hope that it “might give others the idea of doing night effects better than I do.”) His “night effect” became a foundational image for Expressionism.
Paul Gauguin, Soyez amoureuses vous serez heureuses (Be in Love and You Will Be Happy), 1889

Symbolism/Post-impressionism

  1. Paul Gauguin styled himself and his art as “savage.” He began his career with the Impressionists in Paris, then turned to symbolism, and during the late 1880s fled in search of an edenic paradise where he could create pure, “primitive” art; first in Brittany, where he made this work, and later in Tahiti.
  2. Gauguin's childhood memories of Peru, a trip to Martinique, and the African art he saw at the 1889 Universal Exposition in Paris stimulated his interest in "primitive" civilizations and prompted him to convey the same spontaneity and force in his work. Gauguin’s paintings showed a preoccupation with dreams, mystery, and evocative symbols. He also sculpted, carved wood reliefs and objects, and made ceramics.
  3. This is a polychrome bas-relief wood panel, an obscure and personal allegory. Gauguin depicts himself in the upper right, sucking his thumb and grasping the hand of a nude woman who seems to recoil amid other figures, faces, flowers and a fox that gazes out at the viewer. He wrote that he considered it "the best and strangest thing I have ever done in sculpture. Gauguin (as monster) seizing the hand of a protesting woman and telling her: 'Be in love and you will be happy.'" This sculpture anticipated his painterly visions of Tahiti, as mysterious, erotic, and savage.
  4. When first exhibited in 1891 at the Salon des XX in Brussels it was slammed by critics, who said "all lasciviousness, all the struggles of mind and flesh, and all the pain of sensual delight seem to writhe and gnash their teeth" and labeled him "beyond the bounds of insanity" and a "pornographic image maker." It was exhibited again in 1906 during a posthumous retrospective that led to a reappraisal of his wood carvings and influenced artists like Matisse, Brancusi, and Picasso.
  5. The title/inscription is somewhat ironic given that the work's subject matter is bleak and its mood turbulent, an exploration of lust, voyeurism, and male sexual power; it's inclusion in the image also goes against the pre-literate "primitive" ages he sought to emulate.
  6. Other works have the same phrase printed within the picture space: an 1894 watercolor, an 1898 woodcut, another bas-relief (1901-02), and several sketches.  Gauguin conceived his 1890 relief Soyez mystérieuses ("Be mysterious") as a companion piece.

Jacob A. Riis, “Five Cents a Spot” Lodging House, Bayard Street, c.1889
Museum of the City of New York

Documentary Photography
  1. Jacob Riis (1849-1914) was a Danish-American social reformer, "muckraking" journalist and social documentary photographer. He contributed significantly to the cause of urban reform in America at the turn of the twentieth century with his documentation of tenement life in New York.
  2. This photo is from his 1890 book How the Other Half Lives, a pamphlet that was originally published in Scribner’s with line drawings of his photography. It was later published as a book and reached a wider audience. In it he described the squalid living conditions of the slums, where people lived without ventilation or sanitation in cramped, overcrowded rooms. He described this scene: “It was photographed by flash-light on just such a visit. In a room not thirteen feet either way slept twelve men and women, two or three in bunks set in a sort of alcove, the rest on the floor. A kerosene lamp burned dimly in the fearful atmosphere, probably to guide other and later arrivals to their ‘beds,’ for it was only just past midnight. A baby’s fretful wail came from an adjoining hall-room, where, in the semi-darkness, three recumbent figures could be made out. The ‘apartment’ was one of three in two adjoining buildings we had found, within half an hour, similarly crowded. Most of the men were lodgers, who slept there for five cents a spot.” 
  3. Riis was a journalist, not an artist, but he used a brand new photographic technique: flash powder. Flash powder was a mixture of magnesium with potassium chlorate and some antimony sulfide for added stability. Riis lit the magnesium powder on a frying pan. The process involved removing the lens cap, igniting the flash powder and replacing the lens cap; the time taken to ignite the flash powder sometimes allowed a visible image blurring created by the flash. The introduction of flash photography made it possible for Riis to photograph the darkest corners of society, like this overcrowded lodging room with no light. It also allowed him to take photos at night when the worst conditions were most apparent. 
  4. The use of flash photography to document the dark places of the city where no one willingly ventured allowed Riis to capture the unflinching realities of life in the city and bring it to those who had the power to make change. 
  5. The outcry from Riis’ journalistic photography brought about a reform movement. He considered that to be his only purpose, not art production. But his photographs reflect the power of images to bring about social change. His use of technology also advanced photography.
J. Kuhn, The Champ‐de­‐Mars and the Eiffel Tower, C. 1889‐90

Industrial Design + Monumental Architecture
  1. The Universal Exposition of 1889 was planned by the French Third Republic government in the mid-1880s to celebrate the French Revolution’s centennial. It was imagined as a Europe-wide event. Some nations (eg. the Ottoman Empire) declined to participate because they didn’t agree with ideals of French revolution.  
  2. The Eiffel Tower was designed by the company owned by Gustave Eiffel (1832-1923) for the Universal Exposition. It was initially planned to be a temporary structure, like many of those built for expositions and world’s fairs at the time. Won an open call for a monumental gateway/beacon for the exposition. 
  3. Eiffel’s company worked in industrial design, on bridges and industrial buildings. 
  4. The tower was made possible by a new technique of wrought-iron construction, combining strong support girders with open latticework. The lattice-girder piers made it wind-proof.
  5. Speedy construction (2 yearsm 250 men) was facilitated by the prefabrication offsite of modular elements (compare to the Crystal Palace.)
  6. Tallest structure in the world at the time (984 ft). Glass elevators (which were designed by the Otis Elevator company) took visitors on a curved path to the top to see a panoramic view of the city. Nearly 2 million people visited over the 7 months of the exposition. Tower was painted with irridescent paint that made it seem to glow. 
  7. Artists seemed to hate the structure: William Bouguereau, Ernest Meissonier, Charles Garnier and others signed an 1887 protest against the tower, published in Le Temps in 1887. Maupassant, an author who also signed the protest above, called it a “giant ungainly skeleton upon a base that looks built to carry a colossal monument of Cyclops, but which just peters out into a ridiculous thin shape like a factory chimney.”
  8. Kuhn seems to have been a publisher of travel and tourist prints in Paris in the late 19th century. These prints would likely have been available to purchase to visitors to the fair as souvenirs.
Paul Signac, Opus, 217. Against the Enamel of a Background Rhythmic with Beats and Angles, Tones And Tints, Portrait of M. Félix Fénéon in 1890, 1890

Pointillism / Neo-Impressionism
1. Full title: “Against the Enamel of a Background Rhythmic with Beats and Angles, Tones and Tints”
2. Signac was amongst those artists who turned the Impressionist’s random and choppy brushwork into a systematic method of application which Fénéon termed “Neo-Impressionist”: instead of mixing paint on the palette, the colors would combine in the viewer’s eye
3. Fénéon was an art critic, journalist and publisher and anarchist; day job was as a clerk at the Ministry of War; accused of having bombed a Parisian restaurant and imprisoned, acquitted, but fired from his job, became an art dealer (Matisse, Italian Futurists, African art collection)
4. 1890s in Paris: time of economic and social hardship; anarchism was a worker’s movement for the recognition of bad living and working conditions, aimed at the overthrow of institutions that perpetuated economic divides; Neo-Impressionists were all part of anarchist movement
5. Shows Fénéon with characteristic upturned goatee and cyclamen flower, with top hat, glove and walking stick; swirling patterns in background that create kaleidoscopic color wheel
6. Likely an allusion to the scientific color theory of Charles Henry: Signac had just illustrated his book on the “algebra” of visual rhythm; the exceedingly long title might be a joking evocation of Henry’s scientific pretentions
7. Possibly also symbolic of Pointillist technique as described by Fénéon: one takes a few steps back and the technique vanishes, the painting is no longer a painting but resembles a mosaic or tapestry
8. Subject matter reminiscent of the quintessentially modern theme of spectacles and performances in modern café and cabarets; Fénéon looks like a circus artist or conductor (compare Seurat’s Le Cahut 1889)
9. Exhibited at the Salon des Indépendents in 1891, not well received by critics (because background dominated figure), gifted to Fénéon

Jean‐Léon Gérome, Pygmalion and Galatea, c. 1890
Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York

Néo-Grec
1.  Represents a scene from Greek mythology (Pygmalion’s love of his sculpture of “ideal womanhood” makes the statue come alive), but has the qualities of a genre painting, offering a glimpse into the studio of a historical artist. In representing the myth in a contemporary setting, Gérôme sought to reinvigorate a subject that he considered very hackneyed.
2.  This is one of many works that Gérôme made of the subject, as a sculpture, and as other paintings from various angles. It is thought that he used as his model for Galatea his own plaster sculpture.
3.  This painting, along with the other versions that follow self-reflexively refer to the role of the artist, imaging the transformation taking place in a contemporary artist studio. The other versions feature this painting in their background, comparing the love of Pygmalion to the care of the artist.
4. Gérôme was an academic painter who worked in both the Néo-Grec style and on Orientalist subjects. Néo-Grec = trend in painting and interior design aimed at recreating daily life in Classical antiquity
5. Painted in meticulous academic detail, depicting surroundings in near-photographic accuracy. Shares its carefully researched detail with the Orientalist paintings in Gérôme’s oeuvre (compare Prayer in the Mosque 1872)
Louis Sullivan, Wainwright Building, St. Louis, Mo., 1890-­91

Chicago School of Architecture
1.     Marked the beginning of modern skyscraper design, designed by Chicagoan architects, Dankmar Adler and Louis Sullivan. Considered an influential prototype of a modern office architecture. The building represented a revolt against American dependence on European antecedents in architecture, expressed through tall steel frame buildings. 
2.     Was named after a local financer and brewer, Elli Wainwright who commissioned the space to operate his St Louis Brewers Association. With the intention of opening up the corner of the building to the street, the first floor was dedicated to street level shops, the higher floors to be public offices, the top houses water tanks and machinery.
3.     Credited for being the first successful utilization of steel frame construction. The first two floors are faced in brown sandstone and the next seven in continuous brick piers. Sullivan described the symbolism of his architecture as one of simple geometric and structural forms and organic ornamentation. (construction based on a steel frame that is clad in masonry)
4.     Organic ornamentation and carvings that decorated the main entrance and the spandrels between windows on different floors are characteristic of Sullivan: formalized yet naturalistic celery-leaf foliage that he published in System of Architectural Ornament.  
5.     This building exemplifies Sullivan’s theories of tall buildings, based on the structure of the classical column and his desire to emphasize the height of the building: "The skyscraper must be tall, every inch of it tall. The force and power of altitude must be in it, the glory and pride of exaltation must be in it. It must be every inch a proud and soaring thing, rising in sheer exultation that from bottom to top it is a unit without a single dissenting line."
6.     In the 1972, the building was listed as a City Landmark after it became a National Historic Landmark in 1958. It is currently owned by the State of Missouri and is used for state offices.
Henri de Toulouse‐Lautrec, Le Divan Japonais, 1892‐93

Art Nouveau
  1. Best known for his depictions of the seamier side of Parisian nightlife, Toulouse-Lautrec's images often featured the fin-de-siècle it-girls, like actress Sarah Bernhardt and Moulin Rouge dancers like La Goulue. Part of his greatness stemmed from his access. As a fixture on Montmartre’s bohemian scene, he was friends with the artists and performers he depicted. His posters, prints, and paintings captured the vibrant appeal of the Belle Époque and continue to shape our perception of the era.
  2. In 1891 he began producing large-scale poster advertisements - including this one, his most famous - that were affixed to buildings, kiosks, and billboards across Paris, earning him immediate celebrity as a printmaker.   
  3. The Divan Japonais, a cabaret in Montmartre, was redecorated in 1893 with fashionable Japanese motifs and lanterns. Its owner, Édouard Fournier, commissioned this poster to attract customers to the opening.
