This exists in stark contrast to Old Master or Renaissance depictions of this scene that represents the event and all the figures with calm restraint.
  4. This painting in its colors, composition and loose brushstrokes retain the hallmarks of Die Brücke.
  5. Emil Nolde believed in the ethnic superiority of the Nordic people and became a member of the Nazi party in 1920; his art was at first tolerated by Goebbels and then condemned in 1934, and included in the Entartete Kunst exhibition in 1937

George Bellows, Both Members of This Club, 1909
National Gallery of Art, Washington, D. C.

Ashcan School 
1.    In the early 20th century, Bellows aspired to represent the rough and dark edges of New York City. He moved to New York in his early twenties and studied with Robert Henri at the New York School of Art, and became part of an informal group of American artists led by Henri who came to be called the “Ashcan School” due to their gritty brand of realism and apparent muddiness of their color palettes. Typical subjects for the group included youths, working class people, immigrant communities and the urban streets. 
2.    This painting is the third and largest of Bellow’s early prizefighting subjects. Boxing was a controversial subject at the time (public boxing matches were banned in New York State in 1900), but the interracial theme in which the black boxer appears to be winning made the painting even more so. 
3.    The painting is likely a reference to the recent and much publicized success of the African-American prizefighter Jack Johnson, who had won the world heavyweight championship in 1908. Painted at the height of the Jim Crow era, Bellows delineation of a white fighter about to be defeated by a black opponent was a provocative piece of social commentary. 
4.     Bellows’ brushstrokes underscore the violence and physicality of the match. The paint is applied with a quickness that echoes the energetic movement of the athletes. The forms, while distinct, are not delicately rendered. The obscure darkness of the background precludes any perception of recession into space, and create the feeling of a dangerous and secretive atmosphere. 
5.    Bellows painting also reflects a contemporary interest in crowd psychology. He claimed, “the atmosphere around the fighters is a lot more immoral than the fighters themselves.” He exaggerates the faces of the onlookers; they grimace and shout at the drama above them. His incisive depiction of the audience reveals the influence of 19th century French caricaturist Honoré Daumier.
Albert Kahn, Ford Motor Company Factory, Highland Park, Michigan, 1909

1. Kahn was the foremost American industrial architect of his day; sometimes called the "architect of Detroit."
  2. His firm, Albert Kahn Associates, developed a new style of construction whereby reinforced concrete replaced wood in factory walls, roofs, and supports. This gave better fire protection and allowed large volumes of unobstructed interior.
  3. Khan's style came to define proper factory design: vast, open floors that allowed for the efficient arrangement of machinery; large steel-frame windows that brought in more light and fresh air, creating a more pleasant and productive working environment that enhanced worker productivity; and the potential for expansion, or connection of additional structures to meet increased demand.
  4. This was the first production plant in history to assemble cars on a modern moving assembly line. This improved production time of the Model T from 728 to 93 minutes, which lowered the price of the Model T from $700 in 1910 to $350 in 1917.
  5. The complex included offices, factories, a power plant, and a foundry. Over 120 acres, it was the largest manufacturing facility in the world when it opened. Because of its spacious design, it set the precedent for many factories and production plants built thereafter, revolutionizing not only auto manufacturing, but the entire industrial world.
  6. After the Model T went out of fashion, the plant turned to automotive trim manufacturing and Fordson tractor assembly. During World War II, Ford built 1,690 M4 Sherman tanks (the most widely used medium tank by the United States and Western Allies), that were assembled here as part of America's Arsenal of Democracy.
  7. It became a National Historic Landmark in 1978. Today the plant is no longer used for automotive production, it awaits redevelopment.
  8. Altogether, Kahn's firm worked on more than 1,000 commissions from Henry Ford.

Henri Matisse, Back I‐IV, c. 1909‐1931
Tate Gallery, London

1. Henri Matisse was a French artist, known for both his use of colour and his fluid and original draughtsmanship. He was a draughtsman, printmaker, and sculptor, but is known primarily as a painter. 
  2. Matisse made a visit Rodin's studio in 1900 in Paris, who at the time was a towering figure of sculpture. Matisse incorporated bronze sculpture into his oeuvre from time to time. 
  3. Back I-IV is a series of four bas-relief sculptures, by Henri Matisse. It's Matisse's largest and most monumental sculptures.
  4. Matisse did not conceive The Backs as a series, but occasionally returned to the theme over the years. Even so, these reliefs—his largest sculptures—present a coherent progress, from a relatively detailed naturalism toward a near-abstract monumentality. Over twenty years he progressively refined the original pose, based on a woman leaning on a fence, until he achieved a massive simplicity.
  5. Matisse's decision to show the back view of a woman on such a monumental scale was unorthodox. However, by concealing her face, he avoided the complexities of visual engagement between artist and model. This helped him to consider the nude as an arrangement of forms that he could simplify and stylize.
  6. Through the progression of his variations on the theme, the modelling of flesh has given way to the massing of androgynous bulk and the gently curved spine has been replaced by an abstracted plait. One of the most important contributions of Matisse’s career stemmed from his ability to eliminate all extraneous elements and concentrate on the essential lines necessary to give a form meaning.
  7. The cast bronzes are larger than life size, monumental, and the vertical relief style echoes an upright vertical space like a painting, but instead paints in volumes. 
  8. Back (I) appeared in the second Post-Impressionist show in London and the Armory Show in New York City.
  9. Echoes Rodin's Gates of Hell, because they both present opaque confusion of forms against which the eye is not allowed any progression in depth.
Adolf Loos, Steiner House, Vienna, Austria, 1910

Proto-Rationalism, (Early) Modern Architecture
  1. Designed for the painter Lilly Steiner and her husband Hugo
  2. It was Loos’ goal to maximize the space at his disposal without violating the building regulations of suburban Vienna: the authorities would only grant planning permission for a one-storey house with a converted mansard roof, while the clients wanted a comprehensive spatial programme.
  3. Manifestation of Loos’ Ornament and Crime written in 1908, in which he repudiated the heavily-decorated style of the Vienna Secession: his design for the Steiner House eschews ornament in favor of naked functionality. 
  4. Exterior: White stucco, as protection for bricks (like many of his buildings) Also creates a smooth, unadorned exterior. 
  5. Loos’ essays denouncing ornament at the time were influential. According to Loos, "...I have discovered the following truth and present it to the world: cultural evolution is equivalent to the removal of ornament from articles in daily use. I thought I was giving the world a new source of pleasure with this; it did not thank me for it. People were sad and despondent.”
  6. House is symmetrical from the front and from the back, though the two façades differ strongly (the front with the arced two-story roof, the back three-stories and rectilinear. 
  7. Often described as the first truly modern piece of architecture
Robert Delaunay, Eiffel Tower in Trees, 1910

Cubism / Orphism
1. This is one in a series of over 30 Eiffel Tower paintings, framed by a foreground tree in the manner of Cézanne: the Eiffel Tower built for the 1889 Universal Exposition and architectural symbol of modernity
2. Exemplifies the lessons Delaunay learned from Cubism’s use of shifting viewpoints: fragmentation of tower and foliage, limited palette and blocklike forms; tower portrayed from several viewpoints at once, tracing the motion of the eye (and hence a temporal element of viewing) as it follows the tower upward (compare Braque’s Houses at l’Estaque 1908)
3. At the top, the tower begins to oscillate between foreground and background, between being an autonomous object and surface pattern
4. The painting marks the beginning of his engagement with light to permeate and fracture solid shapes, splintering them into a kaleidoscope of shattered elements; he will later go on to explore the energy and immateriality of light more intensely, shifting to pure planes of color and geometrical shapes without any vestiges of architecture (compare his Simultaneous Contrasts 1913)
5. The fragmentation here also conveys a sense of rapid motion, which possibly reflects ideas of the Futurists published in their 1910 manifesto
6. Delaunay was shaped by German avant-garde early in his career (exhibited with the Der Blaue Reiter in Munich in 1911 and 1912) and was one of the first French artists to embrace abstraction
7. Joined the Cubists in the 1911 Salon des Indépendants (praised by Apollinaire), but unlike the cubists, he never painted figures or still lives
8. Painting was executed when he was away from Paris, painted from memory; apparently in celebration of his engagement to Sonia Delaunay
Henri Matisse, The Dance, 1910

Fauvism (a bit late for Fauvism proper though)
Oil on canvas
  1. Matisse used the term “decorative” to describe the fusion of form and content in his work. While often criticized and trivialized for this, Matisse engaged with the decorative as a way to refuse centuries of subservience to anecdote and naturalism.
  2. The work was commissioned by wealthy Russian industrialist Sergei Shchukin, as one of three large canvases to fill his spiral staircase in his Moscow palace. It was hung by a companion work Music in which five figures sit statically playing instruments and singing in the same color scheme as The Dance.
  3. The motif in dance can be traced to Greek face painting or peasant dances and was first used by Matisse in background for Le Bonheur de vivre.
  4. The figures here are sealed into the foreground but the close cropping, large size and autonomy from the intense green earth.
  5. Visible influence of Cezanne in the flattening of space, consideration of the body in relation to the entire composition, connecting the figures and organizing them in dialogue with the background, as well as in the incomplete black contours of the figures, emphasizing this connection between the figure and the depicted environment.  
  6. The jarring juxtaposition of vivid colors creates visual vibrations that make the surface of the canvas dance, echoing the imagery of the painting, thus speaking to his “decorative” emphasis on the fusion of content and form. Here, Matisse paints the dance, not the dancers.
Henri Rousseau, The Dream, 1910

1.    His last completed work before his death, The Dream is the largest in a series of more than 25 jungle paintings by Rosseau. However, he never travelled outside of France and instead drew on images of the exotic as they were commonly presented to the urban masses in Europe through popular literature, colonial expositions and the Paris Zoo. 
2.    Influenced by a combination of sources, Rosseau created modern, unconventional renderings of traditional genres of landscapes, portraiture and allegory. The outrageous imagery that resulted from these hybrid influences was celebrated by Surrealists whose art valued the surprising juxtapositions and dream-like moods created in his paintings. 
3.    Although he had ambitions to become a famous academic painter, Rosseau instead became the opposite: the quintessential “naïve” artist. Largely self-taught, he developed a style that evidenced his lack of academic training (absence of correct proportions, one-point perspective, sharp unnatural colours). Such features results in a body of work imbued with a sense of mystery and eccentricity. 
4.    This painting features an almost surreal portrait of Yadwigha, Rosseau’s Polish mistress from his youth, lying naked on a divan, gazing over a landscape of lush jungle foliage– mixing a domestic and the exotic setting. The academic style of the nude is reminiscent of neoclassical odalisques portrayed by artists like Ingres, and the exotic setting of the jungle speak to the late 19th century French colonialist expansion. 
5.    The title of the work stems from the escapist fantasies associated with the landscapes. The details of the jungles were inspired by his visits to Paris’s natural history museum and Jardin des plantes (a combined zoo and botanical garden). Of his visits, he said, “When I am in these hothouses and see the strange plants from exotic lands, it seems to me that I am entering a dream.”
Erich Heckel, Standing Child, 1911

German Expressionism / Die Brücke
  1. Heckel was a German painter and printmaker, who studied architecture briefly, before becoming a founding member of Die Brücke (The Bridge), which existed between 1905-1913. The group, inspired by Edvard Munch, sought to make a "bridge" between traditional German painting and modern expressionist painting.
  2. Heckel and his Brücke colleagues revived the woodcut technique, as it was a cheap and quick medium to produce affordable art. The woodcuts are the most dramatically primitivist and expressive work produced by them, because of the extremes of black and white that define their space and because they recapitulate the awkwardness of medieval German woodcuts.  
  3. Heckel used three woodblocks in the puzzle technique invented by Munch to create this image printed in green, red, and black. It is drawn with a forceful use of outline and broadly colored fields, lending the scene a certain rawness.
  4. For Brücke artists, nature represented a healing escape from the crowds and anxiety of the city. In nature, they and their subjects could shed their inhibitions, as well as their clothes, to celebrate the freedom of mind and body.  Expressionist nudes in the landscape, like this one, encapsulate their vision of a merging of humans and nature as the most authentic expression of being. 
  5. Pictured here is Lina Franziska Fehrmann (1900-1950), aka Fränzi, who was one of Die Brucke's muses/favorite models. She is depicted as a part of the landscape, her body an expression of unadulterated nature. In contrast to the angular form of her slender body, her crudely drawn face conveys in a minimum of detail an expression implying knowledge beyond her years.
  6. Fränzi and her siblings (she was 1 of 12) regularly posed for 3 of the 4 main Brücke artists - reflecting the spirit of collectivity that pervaded the group - beginning in summer 1909, when she was only 8. Her role in their work has occasionally been deemed unsettling, as some portraits depict her as innocent and childlike, and others like an erotic Lolita.
Max Pechstein, Indian and Woman, 1910

German Expressionism: Die Brücke
  1.  Pechstein (1881-1955) was the most eclectic artist of the Brucke group; he painted notable works that shift from one style to another.
  2. This painting is much closer to the joyful color palette of the French fauves than the disturbing clashes of color that artists of Die Brucke often used.  
  3. Image illustrates the interests of the Expressionists with its erotic subject, modeling of the figures, and Fauve-inspired colors. Pechstein’s work iis sculptural and curvilinear in contrast to Mueller or Heckel, and not tinged by the intense anxiety that informed so much of Kirchner's work.
  4. Early contact with the art of Vincent van Gogh stimulated Pechstein's development toward expressionism and might have influenced his use of color. 
  5. Max Pechstein used perceptions of “primitive,” exotic wildness in his work as a means of expressing inner feeling and disengaging from the established Western art tradition. Artists of Die Brücke often focused on the male and female nude form to the same effect.
  6. Beginning in 1933, Pechstein was vilified by the Nazis because of his art. A total of 326 of his paintings were removed from German museums. Sixteen of his works were displayed in the Entartete Kunst (Degenerate Art) exhibition of 1937.
Sonia Delaunay, Blanket, 1911

Orphism
  1. Delaunay recalled, “About 1911 I had the idea of making for my son, who had just been born, a blanket composed of bits of fabric like those I had seen in the houses of Russian peasants. When it was finished, the arrangement of the pieces of material seemed to me to evoke cubist conceptions and we then tried to apply the same process to other objects and paintings.”
  2. Eventually, Delaunay stretched the blanket and exhibited it. 
  3. Roots the practice of Orphism in craft. Delaunay continued to create visual art and decorative work including printed textiles which covered the walls of her home as wallpaper.
  4. The poet Guillaume Apollinaire coined the name Orphism, after the Greek god Orpheus who was renowned for his musical talents: Orphists aspired to musical level of abstraction; thought of colors as being in harmony (or disharmony). 
  5. Orphism was abstract but unlike Cubism, it embraced brilliant color (influenced by Neo-Impressionists and Symbolists) and representations of time and experience: artists from this loosely-affiliated group represented a vision of simultaneity and flux. Orphism is related to Simultanism (the depiction of simultaneity) (Orphism introduced non-objective painting to French audiences.) 
  6. Informed Robert Delaunay’s Simultaneous Windows (Sonia Delaunay’s husband). Blanket was more successful in shedding figurative elements, perhaps by virtue of its genesis in textiles: the blankets that Delaunay says inspired her were likewise not representational. 
  7. Orphism faded after start of WWI in 1914.
Umberto Boccioni, States of Mind I: The Farewells, 1911

Italian Futurism
1. This is the first in a trilogy of paintings called States of Mind about the arrivals and departures at a train station: an emblem of movement and modern transportation becomes the focal point of the picture; modern machines that give new meaning to the word “speed”; approaching train (loaded with weapons and troops) as a symbol of impending war
2. It exemplifies the importance of Analytic Cubism in the formation of the Futurists: Carrà, Severini and Boccioni had visited Picasso in his studio in Paris that year, absorbed the lessons of the new French style into their own dynamic idiom
3. Sense of tension and chaotic movement through vibrating and curving patterns
4. Explores the psychological dimensions of modern life’s transitory nature: loneliness, anguish and dazed confusion; people consumed by and fused with the steam of the locomotive
5. Collage element of number “6943” on the cab of a dissolving engine: autonomous signs dissociated from any context, underscore the flatness of the canvas and its property as material object, are outside any illusion of pictorial space (Braque and Picasso introduced numbers in 1911)
6. Exhibitions of Futurists in a Paris gallery in 1912, positively reviewed by Apollinaire: a provincial movement in Italy became part of international experiments in art
7. Boccioni studied Impressionism and Post-Impressionism in Paris in 1906, travelled to Russia for three months in 1906, died at the age of 33, in 1916, when thrown from his horse during a cavalry training exercise and trampled

Arthur Dove, Nature Symbolized No. 2, c. 1911
The Art Institute of Chicago

Early Abstraction
Pastel on paper
  1. Dove started as a commerical illustrator, but after spending time in Paris studying European modernism, Dove returned to New York with a strong sense of artistic direction, inspired by the lean toward abstraction that he had witnessed in France. 
  2. Dove was concerned more with the spiritual forces of nature than it external forms and the curving shapes of the pastels were inspired by the natural world. He called this group of abstract pastels The Ten Commandments as if together constituting his spiritual and artistic credo.
  3. He sought to articulate “essences” of the spiritual found in nature, that manifested in his work as biomorphic shapes representing different kinds of energy or organic evolution, suggesting an inner principle of inherent reality. He referred to his type of abstraction as “extraction” where he extracted the essential forms of a scene from nature. The color of this work, and curvilinear forms evoke a sense of growth and movement in nature.
  4. He became close to Stieglitz who shared his idea that art forms should embody modern spiritual values, not materialism and tradition. With the support of Stieglitz’s gallery who showed The Ten Commandments at his gallery 291 in 1912, Dove became one of the first true “abstract” American painters, and this show is widely considered to be the first show in the US to show abstract art. 
  5. He has been seen as a forerunner of abstract expressionism.
Wassily Kandinsky, final study for the cover of the Blaue Reiter Almanach, 1911

1.    The Blaue Reiter (Blue Rider) art movement was founded in 1911 by the young artists Wassily Kandinsky and Franz Marc, and remained active in Europe until 1914. Published in Munich in 1912, the Blaue Reiter Almanac presented the movement’s synthesis of international culture to the European avant-garde at large. 
2.    This book was originally intended to be a yearly almanac, although only the first issue was published. It featured a dozen essays on topics ranging from “primitive” masks to the stage direction for an experimental color-tone drama called Yellow Sound. It included an eclectic variety of illustrations, combining the works of artists like Van Gogh, Cézanne, Picasso with Chinese ink painting, Renaissance woodcuts, African statues and Medieval sculpture.
3.    The name Der Blaue Reiter as Kandinsky suggested, was chosen because both Marc and Kandinsky liked riders and the color blue. The group’s emblem, depicted in this cover image, was the Roman Christian soldier Saint George who slayed a dragon that was demanding human sacrifices. The figure of the Blue Rider thus embodied the spiritual focus of the group as well as their belief that art plays an important social role. The crude, child-like simplicity of the cover art, along with its Christian reference, is a visual emblem of the group two main themes: primitivism and spirituality
4.    The aim of the collective was to place an emphasis on the inner or subjective mental state of the artists, as opposed to the outer or objective experience of nature, which was a central themes of Expressionist art theory. They were opposed to the approach of the Italian Renaissance of the 1400s, which saw a rise of a naturalistic style of representations that they contended, was only concerned with representing the outer appearances of material reality. 
5.    In addition to work by its members, the Almanac featured works by non-European and untrained folk artists, which would have been identified at the time as primitive. What the disparate works had in common was their rejection or lack of knowledge of post-Renaissance Western tradition, with its emphasis on naturalism, scientific knowledge and technological progress. They instead saw modern science and urban life as a threat to humankind’s true spiritual vocation.
Franz Marc, The Large Blue Horses, 1911

German Expressionism / Der Blaue Reiter
  1. Marc was a painter and printmaker, and founding member of Der Blaue Reiter (The Blue Rider), active from 1911-1914, together with German and Russian expatriate artists like August Macke and Wassily Kandinsky. Artistic approaches varied from artist to artist.  However, the group shared a desire to express spiritual truths; believed in the promotion of modern art; the connection between visual art and music; the spiritual and symbolic associations of color; and a spontaneous, intuitive approach to painting. The group was short-lived because of the outbreak of World War I.
  2. Marc turned to the subject of animals as a source of spiritual harmony and purity in nature, a means to reconnect with what had been lost in the modern era; they were a symbol of the primitive and arcadian life sought by the Expressionist painters.
  3. Marc's interest in spirituality stemmed from his mother, a devout, socially liberal Calvinist.  Before becoming an artist, he wanted to study theology.
  4. Following Red Horses and Yellow Cow, he completed his suite of monumental, primary-color compositions with The Large Blue Horses. He drew from a prior work, the Lenggries Horses (1908) for the pose and semi-circular arrangement of the horses, and close vantage point. Here, the horses are encircled, almost like a halo, by a pair of curving white lines.  The absence of a rider is in keeping with Marc's belief in the supremacy of animal spirituality over that of humans.
  5. This painting is exemplary of his mature style, where color had a symbolic rather than descriptive function and were independent of the subject. Marc's use of blue was meant to convey masculinity and spirituality.
  6. This painting was included in the Blaue Reiter's first exhibition in Munich, in December 1911. Today, it lives at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, Minnesota, as the painting left Europe when the Nazis labeled Marc a 'degenerate' artist.
  7. With the outbreak of World War I in 1914, Marc was drafted into the German Army, where he made military camouflage, painting canvas covers used for hiding artillery from aerial observation. In 1916, Marc was killed by shrapnel during the Battle of Verdun.
Henri Matisse, The Red Studio, 1911

Matisse, post-Fauvism
  1. Matisse was a French artist, known for both his use of colour and his fluid and original draughtsmanship. He was a draughtsman, printmaker, and sculptor, but is known primarily as a painter.
  2. Red Studio is a singular, culminating expression of several key aspects of Matisse's artistic development up to that point. The painting reflects the influence of Fauvism, Impressionism, Post-Impressionism, his early travels abroad, and his own emerging artistic code.
  3. The red that dominates the canvas is evocative of his earlier work The Dessert: Harmony in Red (1908), yet it also illustrates compelling differences: exaggerated forced perspective, thinner washes of color, and a pared-down composition. The use of color and lack of focal point work together to create harmony and balance.
  4. Matisse's technique in L'Atelier Rouge to use just one bold, rich color to create the entirety of the composition-by strategically using the absence of the red-would significantly impact the succeeding generations of Modern artists (e.g. influenced Rothko), the technique of layering color to establish depth or perspective—without formal use of line—serves as a crux for most of color field painting. (he painted canvas yellow and put a thin veil of rusty red over it to create the negative space)
  5. the room acts as a self-portrait standing in for him, the works in the studio are representational of works he actually has done, but he is not faithful to them (he changes the palette and plays with them)
  6. no sense of light of shadow which might be seen in an earlier Matisse painting (even though this is a later work) everything is pared down to its essence (see Backs I-IV)
Georges Braque, The Portuguese (The Emigrant), fall 1911‐ early 1912

Analytic Cubism
  1. Analytic Cubism, of which The Portugese is an example, included a limited, almost monochromatic  painterly palette and a flattening of visual space through a visual fragmenting of physical objects. It was developed by Braques and Picasso beginning in 1911. 
  2. Writers including Apollonaire and Metzinger attempted to argue that more--rather than less--visual information was offered by such paintings, although they tend to many viewers’ eyes (then and now) to appear increasingly abstract. 
  3. Such writers often described the breakdown of the painter’s distinct spatial position as a function of the fourth dimension
  4. The spatial relationship of painters to works: multiple perspectives were sometimes represented by Cezanne, as in his apple paintings, the offering of viewers more of the visual field/more of reality by Cezanne and other Post-Impressionists influenced the development of Analytic Cubism
  5. Picasso’s encountered art from Africa and Oceania - and the geometric planes thereof - in 1907. The “primitivist” style of early Cubism owes much to Picasso’s experience of these works, which he saw as offering an alternative to Naturalism in depictions of reality
  6. The letters and numbers on the surface here draw attention to the flatness of the canvas - they appear to be formal, rather than representational (early Cubist works often included newspapers and other pieces of ephemera with printed text)
  7. Exhibited by dealer Daniel-Henry Kahnweiler, a proponent of Picasso’s and Braques’ work at the time.

Walter Gropius and Adolph Meyer,
Fagus Shoe‐last Factory (Faguswerk), Alfeld, 1911‐12

Bauhaus
1. While director of the Bauhaus school, Gropius continued his own architectural practice in collaboration with Meyer (who became the second director of the Bauhaus, followed by van der Rohe)
2. Fagus Factory is a landmark in the development of modern architecture and early industrial design
3. Innovation: use of complete glass sheathing, even at the corners; invention of the curtain wall (thin, aluminum-framed wall containing infills of glass, non-structural i.e. does not carry the weight of the floor or roof)
4. Commissioned by the company owner who wanted a radical structure to express the company’s break from the past
5. Influenced by their teacher Behren’s AEG Turbine Factory 1908-9 (both Gropius and Meyer worked on this project); however, the Fagus Shoe Factory is a direct inversion of the Turbine Factory
6. Both factories have corners free of supports and expansive glass surfaces, but the Turbine Factory has heavy elements structural elements at its corners, giving it an image of stability and monumentality instead of the airiness and lightness of the functionalist Bauhaus aesthetic
7. In the Turbine Factory, the glass walls are recessed behind the load-bearing piers, while in the Shoe Factory, the piers are recessed behind the glass surfaces
8. The role of the Shoe Factory’s walls is reduced from a heavy load-bearing to that of a screen that keeps the weather out and occupants in
9. Foreshadows much of the work of the Bauhaus school to come in Europe and North America (Gropius joins Harvard in 1937)
10.  Fagus factory is still in operation today
František Kupka, Disks of Newton (Study for Fugue in Two Colors), 1911‐1912

Orphism (or Simultaneism)
Oil on canvas
  1. Kupka (Czech, 1871– 1957) attended art academies in Vienna and Prague and was influenced by spiritually motivated movement of Nazarene art, decorative Czech folk art and other forms of ornament, knowledge of color theory, an awareness of the art of the Vienna Secession, and a lifelong involvement with spiritualism and the occult
  2. Settling in Paris, he discovered chronophonography and early cinematography which, combined with Chevreul’s color theory, formed his notion of art, based on the human figure, but that suggested a temporal dimension through sequential movement. in this sense, he shared the interests of the Italian Futurists whose work he would first encounter after he made this work.
  3. He was a new addition to the cubist rank, offering a different and innovating alternative for cubism to Braques or Picasso, more in line with Duchamp, Picabia, Leger and Delauney
  4. He differed from most involved in cubist movement because of his connection to the spiritual realm, arriving at his own personal non-objective art, before Robert Delauney did.
  5. In 1912, Apollinaire described the abstract experiments of Kupka, Delauney, Leger and other Orphism, which Kupka individualistically rejected. The term, naming a style that brought musical qualities to painting, referred to Orpheus, the doomed musician of Greek legend whose songs could tame wild beasts and soothe the gods. Apollinaire defined the style as one based on the invention of new structures “which have not been borrowed from the visual sphere,” though the artists he designated had all relied on the “visual sphere” to some degree. But it was a recognition that this art was in its way as divorced as music from the representation of the visual world or literal subject.
  6. The title refers to Isaac Newton who discovered the light of the sun is composed of seven colors of the spectrum. Here Kubka’s composition is formed of the full range of the spectrum.
Piet Mondrian, Flowering Apple Tree, 1912

Mondrian’s early landscapes marked a transition from a naturalistic to a revolutionary modern style. The early phase of his career also reveals his preoccupation with his own spirituality. Like many artists at the time, he was drawn towards the syncretic and universalising ideas of Theosophy. Adherents to Theosophical beliefs held that a fundamental harmony unites all living things, and this essential unity manifests itself visually in simple geometric forms– for them, pure abstraction could convey a sense of universality in a way that representational art could not. 
2.    In his early years, Mondrian focused on a single scene or object such as a tree presented frontally, in close-up presentation. His motifs were painted in nearly abstract planes, and usually manifested in a series of works. 
3.    In the Flowering Apple Tree, he discards the descriptive pictorial language and transmutes the image entirely into the poetic forms of “visual rhyme” and “optical alliteration.” At the time, Mondrian favoured centralised compositions which involved greater density in the center with gradual loosening towards the edges.
4.    In early 1912, Mondrian moved to Paris and became conversant with the Cubist style. During his first years in Paris, he subordinated his colors to grays and ochers under the influence of Picasso and Braque. As a result in this painting, color has been reduced to the benefit of form: the palette limited to a few tints of green, ocher, gray and purple.
5.    This painting followed his earlier painting of the same subject, The Gray Tree (1912), but is far less painterly in surface treatment. In the earlier work, strokes defined the form; here, a thinly applied layer of paint is used to bring the whole composition together.
Pablo Picasso, Still Life with Chair Caning, 1912

Synthetic Cubism
  1. Synthetic cubism, cubism's second stage, began when the artists started being more experimental, adding textures and patterns to their paintings, experimenting with collage using newspaper print and patterned paper. Whereas analytical cubism was about breaking down an object (like a bottle) viewpoint-by-viewpoint, into a fragmentary image, synthetic cubism was about flattening out the image and sweeping away the last traces of allusion to three-dimensional space.  It is generally considered to run from about 1912 to 1914, although it lasted into 1920s.
  2. Cubists' search for alternative modes of representation led Picasso to adopt collage (Braque did it first) for the most prominent element that gives the work its title.  He used common oil cloth, an industrial material that was like an early version of contact paper, with a design simulating chair caning; glued it directly onto the canvas, offering an exacting degree of illusionism that was formerly linked solely to painting.
  3. This incorporation of unorthodox materials not associated with high or fine art offered a radically new connection to the external world. His use of found objects also included the use of rope to frame the canvas in mockery of the usual gold, custom-made frame (though the rope was also custom-made).  The rope encourages a reading of the painted surface as a horizontal glass table top, "allowing" one to see objects placed over and under, as well as shadows and reflections.  Such spatial ambiguity is one of the ways Picasso challenged the most fundamental artistic conventions.
  4. Another novelty, was his use of the letters 'J-O-U'.  Here, Picasso is again playing with space and illusionism, as the lettering is on a surface, thus destroying the illusion of depth. The letters may be read as a bundled newspaper, as the French word for newspaper is "journal" or as a play on the word 'jouer' which means to play, which is what he is doing with space here.
  5. Picasso expanded on Cezanne's multiperspective still lives to present a radical view of a Parisian tabletop, as we seem to be looking down, across, and from fragmented points of view at the napkin, pipe, lemon, and other objects.
  6. Picasso questioned whether images or elements of a piece not rendered by the artist’s hand reduced the quality of the artwork. In doing so, he demonstrated that art may be more about conceptual/philosophical exploration than about creating a convincing replica of the limited reality we experience, thereby changing the course of 20C art.
Pablo Picasso, Guitar, Fall 1912

Cubist sculpture
  1. Pablo Picasso (1881-1973) was a Spanish painter, sculptor, printmaker, ceramicist, stage designer, poet and playwright who spent most of his adult life in France. One of the monolithic figures of modern art. 
  2. Guitar has two versions, this is the original one made in cardboard and sheet metal made in 1912.
  3. An example of employing Cubist principles of pictorial fragmentation first developed by Picasso and Braque around 1908 in a three dimensional object; around 1911 Picasso moved away from Analytical Cubism to Synthetic Cubism and began using collage elements in his work to further defy traditional illusionism of painting, although in the 1912 guitar he replaces flatness of picture plane with three-dimensionality of sculpture.
  4. Picasso's work is an example of assemblage, which means he assembled elements of cardboard together to create a radical representation of a guitar; not an accurate representation of the object, but rather using key visual signifiers to denote the object; the Guitar can be seen to investigate the three-dimensional potential of Cubist painting; the material is unconventional, which adds to the blurring between high art and low art.
  5. Importantly, Picasso's work directly engages with the negative space around the sculpture; a significant break from the sculptural tradition in which forms were solid and not concerned with the empty space.
  6. Synthetic cubism is the later phase of cubism, generally considered to run from about 1912 to 1914, characterised by simpler shapes, brighter colours, and experimentation with materials, patterns, and techniques.
  7. This work in particular will have an influence on Constructivism and the use of utilitarian objects and materials in sculpture. Vladimir Tatlin saw this on a trip to Paris in 1914.
Natalia Goncharova, Linen, 1912

Cubo-Futurist*
  1. This oil-on-canvas painting is monochromatic in the style of Analytic Cubism: but blue-toned rather than sepia. It’s worth noting that both Analytic Cubism and Linen are within the color vocabulary of early photography: cyanotypes and B+W prints.
  2. Men’s shirts and cuffs as well as a lace collar and iron. The Russian word 'Prache' is an abbreviation for "laundry",  b.s. is an abbreviation for ‘white wash’, while 'BOT' is a shortened version of the word meaning 'work.'
  3. Goncharova was highly critical of the Italian Futurists’ view of women, and in particular of the opinion of the movement's founder, Marinetti, who said that he despised women. Taken in this light, this piece can be considered as a wry social commentary of what constitutes “women’s work.”  The artist's name placed on the iron implies a connection, or link of solidarity with the laundress. 
  4. The two sides of the work are divided between male (shirts, collars and cuffs) and female (lace, blouses, aprons) items of laundry.
  5. Goncharova and her partner, Mikhail Larionov, were part of the Russian avant-garde. Together, they experimented with notions of masculinity and femininity through what they wore as means to provoke and challenge social norms.
  6. From The Art Story: Goncharova was from an influential, wealthy, and musical family. She was interested in Russia's rural workers; in her paintings, peasants portrayed in the throws of their labor - cutting hay, shaving ice, washing, and weaving - are imbued with monumental dignity. Through repetitive everyday tasks, Goncharova observed the same celestial strength more commonly associated with religious figures, and in this sense merged the realms of heaven and earth in her pictures
Kazimir Malevich, Morning in the Village after a Snowstorm, 1912

Cubo-Futurism / Russian avant-garde
1. Malevich studied art in Moscow, where he saw the large contemporary Western art collections of the collectors Shchukin and Morozov (which contained Impressionists, Neo-Impressionists, Cubists, Fauvists, Futurists); exhibited together with Larionov and Goncharova in Jack of Diamonds and in Donkey’s Tail exhibition
2. This is an example from an early phase in Malevich’s career, which is grounded in forms of Cubism and Futurism; merged the two into his personalized amalgamation which he termed Cubo-Futurism: fusing the blocklike figures and fragmentation of Cubism with the dynamism in use of color of Futurism
3. Continuation of his Neo-primitive paintings of heavy-limbed peasants in genre scenes, which aimed to infuse Western modernist innovations with a distinctly Russian folk character
4. High degree of resemblance to Léger’s early machine cubism, but it is unclear whether they ever saw each other’s works since Malevich never travelled to Paris;
5. Painting shows two cylindrical figures of peasants moving through a mechanized landscape, in which snow is reduced to sharp-edged, metallic mounds; shapes are filled with gradations of blue, red and white
6. Malevich often falls into discussions of the Russian avant-garde that focus on its technical and stylistic innovations, rather than its social and political commentary (discussed in relation to the work of Tatlin, Lissitzky, Rodchenko); here it is possible, however, to read his repeated decision to depict peasants on the brink of the October Revolution (1917) as decidedly political
7. Malevich’s Cubo-Futurism is a stage shortly before his turn to nonrepresentational art and development of Suprematism (in exhibition Zero-Ten: The Last Futurist Exhibition 1915)
Gino Severini, Dynamic Hieroglyphic of the Bal Tabarin, 1912

Futurism / Cubist influences
Oil on canvas with sequins
  1. Here Severini depicts the dancehall as a full multisensory experience. He pictures a woman with brown curls and white, blue and pink dress dancing to music in the Paris nightclub Bal Tabarin. References to current events are scattered throughout the image – The Arab man riding a camel refers to the Turco-Italian War of 1911, and the flags convey the concurrent sense of nationalism.
  2. The Futurists’s interests in capturing the dynamism of motion is clear in this image, the delight expressed speaking to the Futurists’s revolt against the deadly dullness of 19th century bourgeois morality. This made Paris nightlife a subject of particular inspiration.
  3. But the painting also reveals the obvious influence of French Cubism in the integration of text and college elements (real sequins), use of the cubist grid, fractured places, and building of volume. A strong Italian nationalist, but living in Paris, he served as a link between the two movements.
  4. The Futurists adopted Cubist techniques to convey the sense of movement in time, while rejecting the more static and analytic approach of cubist painters. Whereas in Cubist paintings the use of multiple, fragmentary views of things suggests the viewer is moving around the object, in Futurist paintings it is the scene that is moving around the viewer.
  5. Severini was influenced by the popular philosopher Henri Bergson. Dynamic Hieroglyph was painted from memory, and in keeping with Bergson’s ideas, it attempts to convey the painter’s intuitive vision of reality in which time and space are suffused with memory and sensation. 
  6. In depicting the upper portion of a bass projecting into the painting Severini was copying a device frequently used by two earlier innovative painters of dancers and Paris nightlife, Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec and Edgar Degas. In their works the cropped tops of musical instruments were intended to give the viewer a sense of being present in the audience and looking over the musicians at the stage.
Giacomo Balla, Dynamism of a Dog on a Leash, 1912

Futurist
1.     Futurism began as a rebellion of young intellectuals against the cultural lethargy into which Italy had sunk during the 19th century where Renaissance and Neoclassical artistic values continued to dominate, in spite of avant-garde developments in neighbouring France. The futurist movement thus celebrated progress, energy and change. It attacked old institutions and promoted expression of motion, and the simultaneity of vision itself. 
2.     Balla was the oldest member of the Futurist group and the teacher of Severini and Boccioni. Working in Rome rather than Milan, he pursued his own distinctive experiments, particularly in rendering motion through simultaneous views of many aspects of objects. 
3.     This nearly monochromatic painting depicts a dachshund on a leash and the feet of a lady walking it, both in rapid motion as indicated by the blurring and multiplication of their parts. The feet of the figure and dog are fanned out in varying transparencies, and the background has fine painted streaks running through it to give the illusion of movement. 
4.     Through this image, Balla explores a new field of technology– chronophotography. Invented by the French scientist Étienne-Jules Mareyin the 1880s, this is a photographic technique where multiple photographs are taken in rapid succession to capture the movement of the subject. Chronophotographic studies of animals in motion led to the introduction in paintings of techniques to show motion, such as blurring, multiplication and superimposition of body parts, in an effort to imitate the mechanical images. 
5.     Chronophotography had been evolving for almost 30 years by the time Balla painted the puppy, and its influence was already appearing in frenetic Futurist works. Such multiplication was seen in Marcel Duchamp’s Nude Descending a Staircase No. 2, painted the same year as Balla’s painting.
Giacomo Balla, Girl Running on a Balcony, 1912

Futurism
  1. Balla was an Italian painter, art professor, and poet, best known as a key proponent of Futurism.
  2. "Bambina × balcone" is part of a trilogy from 1912 that marked Balla's turn towards futurism. It depicts his daughter, Luce, as she runs along the balcony of the Balla home.  The Futurists believed that everything is made of dynamic forces and is in constant motion.  Balla employed repetition to generate the feeling of motion, which works to represent the girl’s movement through space, and thus the passage of time, while the bright colors allude to the subject's vivacity.
  3. He did many studies to prepare for the painting and painted it on a recycled canvas, the other side bears a rural landscape dating from 1896 or 1897.
  4. It is clear that Balla was aware of Étienne-Jules Marey's and Eadweard Muybridge's use of chronophotography, as the feeling of movement is captured through the child's sequential steps, thanks to the repetition of the figure from left to right, and the regular lines of the balcony railing—the only environmental element—within the figure. 
  5. He also calls upon the techniques of French Pointillist painters and the Divisionists from northern Italy. Balla emulates their technique by using tiny squares to create a mosaic effect that breaks down the girl's image and forces the viewer to focus not on her form, but on her fragmented motion through time and space. As the painting has no central point, the eye travels across the canvas. The scene appears to continue beyond the frame's surface, attesting to the girl's dynamic energy and momentum in one continuous fluid movement. 
  6. Its significance lies in the way it inscribes the simultaneity of the perception of movement onto the spatial organization of the painting. It was a step toward abandoning representation altogether in order to find a more adequate way to depict light, speed, temporality, and movement, which led to one of the first models of nonrepresentational painting.
  7. Balla viewed his paintings as “scientific and mathematical, as well as artistic.”
Marcel Duchamp, Nude Descending a Staircase, No. 2, 1912

Marcel Duchamp, Cubo-Futurist influences
  1. Henri-Robert-Marcel Duchamp (1887 – 1968) was a French-American painter, sculptor, chess player, and writer whose work is associated with Cubism, Dada, and conceptual art.
  2. Inspired by Cubism, but using the Cubist vocabulary for expressive rather than purely formalist purposes, with which Duchamp was becoming increasingly more disillusioned
  3. Seen as a formative work in Duchamp's break away from painting; rejected at Salon de Independants in 1912 on the grounds that "A nude never descends the stairs--a nude reclines"
  4. The work caused further sensation when it was exhibited in 1913 at the Armory Show in New York, where the viewers saw it as a joke made at their expense with Duchamp's portrayal of the nude—an otherwise respected academic subject—as a mechanized figure
  5. Duchamp was delighted upon learning of the scandal and it encouraged him to return to New York few years later when he was working in Dada.
  6. While the disintegration of a representational image is central to Cubism, the depiction of movement captured in several superimposed frames goes beyond the movement and evidences dynamism in what remains a static and two-dimensional composition; in this regard, the work relates not only to Futurism, but also…
  7.  ...To the recent developments in cinema as well as photography, particularly the work of English photographer Eadweard Muybridge and even more importantly the chronophotography (taken with a gun that captured 25 plates per second) of Etienne-Jules Marey. He often placed metal strips down the sides of his subjects to emphasize the postures of movement. The resulting photographs showed a graph of the movement rather than a series of discrete photos.
Mikhail Larionov, Blue Rayonism, 1912

Rayonism, Russian avant-garde
  1. Partner of Natalia Goncharova. Both were active as artists in exhibition-making. Both were founding members of the Russian Futurist Jack of Diamonds Group (which experimented with Neo-primitivism and folk art influence), which first exhibited in 1910. Two years later they left Jack of Diamonds to create the exhibit The Donkey's Tail (1912), which rejected stylistic unity.
  2. Goncharova and Larionov moved towards a form of abstraction marked by fractured lines and luminous colors--a style that they dubbed Rayonism for the manner in which the surface of the painting seems to be struck by criss-crossing rays of light from multiple angles. 
  3. Rayonism was a combination of Cubist faceting and Futurist movement. 
  4. Rayist paintings were among the earliest non-objective paintings in modern European/American tradition, and certainly in Russia. 
  5. Rayist theory is rooted in representation, bridging representational and abstract art. Rayonism was influenced by scientific studies of light’s refraction and optics: light is emitted and perceived in rays. 
  6. Rayonism also drew on research regarding the materiality of light; recent developments in research on x-rays and radioactivity challenged the concreteness of the physical world. (Larionov had most likely read Marie Curie's Radioactivity and The Discovery of Radium, both recently published in Russia).
  7. In the “Manifesto of Rayonism,” Larionov describes “the rays of things that the artist subjects to his expressive desire. The painting appears as such not of space and time; it spews out sensations that let us sense the fourth dimension.” cf: Orphism’s interest in time and synchrony. According to Larionov, Rayonism conveyed the “ceaseless and intense drama of the rays that constitute the unity of all things.”
  8. Ties between artists in Russia and France at the time were strong: when Goncharova and Larionov fled the war in Russia (having finished only a few Rayist paintings), they went to Paris, where they were often commissioned to design sets and costumes for Ballets Russes performances by Sergei Diaghalev. At the same time, Rayonism was fiercely nationalistic, projecting itself as a distinctly Russian style influenced by folk art. 
  9. Rayonism influenced Kasimir Malevich and his Suprematist Manifesto.
Robert Delaunay, Simultaneous Contrasts: Sun and Moon, 1913 (dated 1912 on the painting)

Orphism / Simultaneity
1. Delaunay was one of the first French artists to embrace abstraction; he moved rapidly through an initial phase inspired by Cubism (see his Eiffel Tower in Trees 1910) and by 1912 had arrived at a formula of brilliantly colored abstractions with only the most tenuous roots in naturalistic observation
2. Exhibited with Der Blaue Reiter in Munich in 1911, with Der Sturm Gallery in Berlin in 1912 and with the Cubists at the Salon des Indépendants in 1911 (early contact with German avant-garde and especially Kandinsky)
3. His Disk paintings constitute the moment at which Delaunay had abandoned even the pretense of a subject in favor of pure planes of color fractured by light
4. According to his wife Sonia, they were made by observing the sun and moon for long periods and then closing his eyes to retain the retinal image of the circular shapes
5. Delaunay called his method for capturing light on canvas through color Simultaneity. He adapted the color theories of Chevreul to his art (the painting’s title stems from Chevreul’s book On the Law of the Simultaneous Contrasts of Colors 1839) but went beyond Chevreul’s scientific analyses to a mystical belief in color (color unity symbolizes harmony in the chaos of a modern world)
6. The Disk paintings are a testimony to Delaunay’s research into light, movement and the juxtaposition of contrasting colors to reproduce the rhythm of the cosmos without reference to the natural world
7. Delaunay: “Nature is no longer a subject for description but a pretext.”
8. The poet Guillaume Apollinaire coined the name Orphism, after the Greek god Orpheus who was renowned for his musical talents: Orphists aspired to musical levels of abstraction, and thought of colors as being in harmony or disharmony.
Vasily Kandinsky, Composition VII, 1913

German Expressionism (Der Blaue Rieter)
Oil on canvas
 
  1. Kandinsky was very interested in the relationship between art and music and in 1911 published a book Concerning the Spiritual in Art in which he formulated these ideas. His titles often derive from music.
  2. He had a strong interest in Theosophy, spiritism and the occult, and believed that by harnessing an inner creative force, the product of spirit rather than external vision or manual skill, he could arrive at an art entirely without representation that expressed harmony of the soul in visual terms, achieving total abstraction.
  3. Many of his compositions revolve around themes of cosmic conflict and renewel, specifically the Deluge from the Book of Genesis and Apocalypse from Book of Revelation. From such cataclysm would emerge a rebirth of a new spiritually cleansed world.
  4. One can identify within this composition the characteristic motifs Kandinsky distilled over the years, e.g. the glyph of a boat with 3 oars at lower left, a sign of the biblical floods. But so that these glyphs would not be read literally or narratively, veiled them in brilliant color. With each composition, Kandinsky edged further toward abstraction, gradually abandoning the glyphs that connected this work in any way to representation.
  5. After this painting, WWI forced his return to Russia. He did not continue his Composition series until 1923 at which point the paintings become far more geometric and linear, influenced by Synthetism, Constructivism and the Bauhaus where he was teaching.
Ernst Ludwig Kirchner, Street, Berlin, 1913

German Expressionism
1.     One of a series of “The Street” paintings that Kirchner produced in Berlin after his move there with other Die Brücke members in 1911. The move caused rifts to be formed within the group, caused by the art scene of the city  and Kirchner becoming more independently known and being offered solo shows. As a result, the group disbanded in 1913, the year this painting was created. 
2.     He created this painting in a period of  loneliness and insecurity. Berlin had a dual impact on Kircher, offering him both stimuli and independence, and alienation. He was successful yet lonely. This manifested in his paintings of street scenes from this period– losing himself in the anonymity of the big city, he began to use  his surroundings as subject matter, capturing the ephemeral energy of the streets. 
3.     Shows two prostitutes strolling the streets, surrounded by furtively glancing men. For Kirchner, prostitutes were a symbol of the modern city, where glamour and danger, and intimacy and alienation coexisted and everything was for sale. 
4.     The anxiety and excitement of the painting is intensified through bright, clashing colors and a tilted horizon that destabilises the composition. The anti-naturalistic tones are common in German Expressionism and his other work during this time period. 
5.     The 1910s in Berlin was described as a period of carefree decadence and sensual oblivion, before the violence of the two World Wars would forever change the collective consciousness, but Kirchner’s early urban portraits suggest otherwise. By the outbreak of WWI in 1914, he was more sceptical: harsh accentuations of form and infectious color combinations create an unbalanced atmosphere of uncertainty.
Aleksandr Archipenko, Medrano II, 1913

Cubism/School of Paris

  1. Archipenko was a Ukrainian-born American avant-garde artist, sculptor, and graphic artist. He was one of the first to apply the principles of Cubism to sculpture, abstracting the human figure into geometrical forms.
  2. About 1912, inspired by the Cubist collages of Braque and Picasso, Archipenko introduced the collage in sculpture in his Medrano series, depictions of circus figures from the Cirque Medrano, which many artists frequented, that defy traditional use of materials and definitions of sculpture. The volumes of the body are articulated through intersecting planes, cone and wedge elements, and abstract forms. He further defied tradition in his “sculpto-paintings,” works in which he introduced painted color to the intersecting planes of his sculptures.
  3. Medrano II is a polychrome figure, made of painted tin, wood, glass, and painted oilcloth, that was attached to a back panel, creating a stage-like setting.
  4. Archipenko alludes to the contemporary vogue for puppetry and the jesters in Picasso’s paintings. Harlequins and saltimbanques were traditional stand-ins for the artistic persona; they also offered a unique package of shapes and colors for formal resolution.
  5. It is recognized for its crossover between painting and sculpture; the work is also the only extant example of a figure in motion by Archipenko, as two other works—Médrano I (Juggler) (1912), and Woman in Front of Mirror (1913), were destroyed.
  6. Juan Gris noted that this work paralleled "the visual experience of Cubist painting" by challenging "the traditional understanding of sculpture. It was generally monochromatic at the time. His pieces were painted in bright colors. Instead of accepted materials such as marble, bronze or plaster, he used mundane materials such as wood, glass, metal, and wire. His creative process did not involve carving or modeling, but nailing, pasting and tying together, with no attempt to hide nails, junctures or seams."
  7. Archipenko exhibited at the first exhibitions of Cubism in Paris; the Salon des Indépendants and Salon d'Automne, 1910 and 1911.
Umberto Boccioni, Unique Forms of Continuity in Space, 1913 (1931 cast)

Futurist Sculpture
  1. Umberto Boccioni (1882-1916) helped shape the revolutionary aesthetic of the Futurism movement as one of its principal figures, he did both painting and sculpture and was committed to approach of dynamism of form and destruction of solid mass.
  2. This sculpture has fluttering, curving planes of bronze. Moves essentially in two dimensions, like a translation of Bocconi's painted figures into relief. Related to the Victory of Samothrace - body in dramatic mid-stride, draperies flowing out behind, arms missing (even though Marinetti despised that traditional sculpture). 
  3. Typical of Futurism - capturing motion and dynamism of modern life, emphasised speed, technology, youth, violence, and objects such as the car, the airplane, and the industrial city.
  4. Boccioni’s Technical Manifesto of Futurist Sculpture (1912): calls for renewal of "mummified art" (of sculpture); attacks academic tradition, especially on the subject of the nude; seeks dynamic fusion between his sculptural forms and surrounding environment; insists on use of all kinds of materials (glass, wood, cardboard, iron, cement, etc.)
  5. Taking off from impressionist sculptor Medardo Rosso (the only contemporary sculptor he respected), Boccioni sought a dynamic fusion between his sculptural forms and surrounding environment. He emphasized the need for an “absolute and complete abolition of definite lines and closed sculpture. We break open the figure and enclose it in [an] environment.” He also asserted the sculptor’s right to use any form of distortion or fragmentation of figure or object.
  6. He saw Picasso's works in his studio in 1911 and traveled to Paris in 1912 and visited studios of Archipenko, Brancusi, and Duchamp-Villon and saw sculpture by Picasso. Wrote "Technical Manifesto of Futurist Sculpture" (1912) right after this trip.
  7. Peculiar ambiguity between a robot and an amphibious figure, once again attempts to incorporate the traces visible in Marey's chronophotography into the sculptural body. Yet, at the same time as it inserts the fluidity of perception into a static representation, it generates the peculiar hybrid between spatial contiguity and the singular, holistic, sculptural object.

Jacob Epstein, Rock Drill, 1913‐15
(1973 Reconstruction)

Vorticism
  1. Poet-critic T.E. Hulme, an associate of the Vorticists, divided modern art into the organic and the geometric. Organic - like Worringer’s empathetic - was an attitude of “insipid optimism” placing man at the center of nature, dominant since the Renaissance. Geometric - his version of the abstract - represented the antihumanism emergent in Vorticist art, “a feeling of separation in the face of outside nature.”
  2. The Vorticists emphasized the need for, as painter-novelist-critic Wyndham Lewis put it, “the element of strangeness, and surprise, and primitive detachment,” in order for the modern age to survive its own dehumanization. (See Viktor Shklovsky’s ostranenie/e(n)strangement.)
  3. Jacob Epstein was not officially affiliated with the Vorticists (he did not sign their manifesto) but Rock Drill is sometimes pointed to as a prime example of the style.
  4. 'It was in the experimental pre-war days of 1913 that I was fired to do the rock-drill, and my ardour for machinery (short-lived) expended itself upon the purchase of an actual drill...and upon this I made and mounted a machine-like robot, visored, menancing, and carrying within itself its progeny, protectively ensconsed. Here is the armed, sinister figure of today and tomorrow. No humanity, only the terrible Frankenstein's monster we have made ourselves into...Later I lost my interest in machinery and discarded the drill. I cast in metal only the upper part of the figure'.
  5. In the original 1913 version, the plaster sculpture was mounted on an actual rock drill for exhibition. (cf: Duchampian Ready-Mades)
  6. Exhibited by the London Group in 1915: the London Group’s aim was ‘to advance public awareness of contemporary visual art by holding exhibitions annually’. It was formed in opposition to the conservative style exemplified by the Royal Academy. Reviewing the 1915 exhibition, The Connoisseur wrote “the works of Mr. Epstein and others of The London Group revealed that the aesthetic tendencies of the most advanced school of modern art are leading us back to the primitive instincts of the savage . . . ” Most of the London Group was killed in WWI.
Fun fact: I find this super upsetting to look at! (hahaha Allie yes me too – this is Flora)
Fun Fact 2: Henri Gaudier-Brzeska visited Epstein’s studio with Ezra Pound. When Pound began to over-enthuse about Rock Drill, Gaudier rounded on him and told him to “shut up, you understand nothing”
Giorgio de Chirico, The Melancholy and Mystery of a Street, 1914

Italian Metaphysical School
1. De Chirico’s work links 19th century Romanticism and Symbolism with 20th century Surrealism: he retained the perspectival space and sculptural figures of Renaissance reality but infused them with a sense of strangeness, surprise, shock or fear
2. De Chirico was born in Greece to Italian parents, studied in Munich, where he was exposed to Böcklin, Klinger and the beginnings of German Expressionism; this work was made during his years in Paris, when he was attracting considerable attention in the Parisian avant-garde
3. Importance of Theosophy and other mystical philosophies (see also Kandinsky) as well as a contemporary popular interest in psychoanalysis’ interest in dreams and the subconscious
4. De Chirico used the word “metaphysical” loosely or inaccurately to describe effects of strangeness, surprise and shock (rather than the philosophical meaning of questions of causality, being or time). The aim is to impart surprise by juxtaposing the normal and everyday with the improbable.
5. This painting exemplifies de Chirico’s use of deep perspectival space to achieve an emotional effect and his use of extreme foreshortening to create a dramatic aura: deeply receding arcaded building, harsh line of the shadow, threatening sky, looming black specter of a sculpture, empty carnival van with open doors, railway tracks in lower left corner (typical motif). Familiar components create an ominous mood, a strange and sad loneliness typical of de Chirico’s squares.
6. Left Paris when WWI broke out to return to Italy, met the Futurist Carrà in an army hospital and founded with him the Metaphysical School (1917-1918) = depiction of reality beyond the physical realm; the Metaphysicists did not share the Futurists’s faith in technology or their interest in the dynamism of modern life, nor did they reject the art of the Italian past. But the group soon fell apart during a quarrel of de Chirico with Carrà over who can take credit for ideas.
7. Like many other artists, de Chirico abandoned experimentation after WWI in favor of mainstream post-Renaissance painting; had a quarrel with the Surrealists who hailed his early work as a crucial forerunner of their own, but rejected his late academicism.
Pablo Picasso, Glass of Absinthe, spring 1914

Cubist sculpture
Painted bronze with silver absinthe spoon
  1. This bronze sculpture was, unlike his constructed sculptures  (Maquette for Guitar) which were essentially reliefs, conceived in the round and originally modeled in wax.
  2. Kahnweiler had the wax work cast in bronze in an edition of six, to each of which the artist added a perforated silver spoon and bronze sugar cube. This incorporation of the readymade was one year after Duchamp’s first use of the readymade in Bicycle Wheel (1913).
  3. He hand-painted 5 editions and coated one with sand, a substance that he and Braque had been adding to their paint medium. His lack of discrimination between high art media (painting) and low material culture would be of particular inspiration to Pop Art.
  4. Picasso cut deep hollows in the glass to reveal the interior, and the liquid it holds, both finding a way to maintain the transparency inherent to glass, while playing with the representation of volume as he did with his cardboard maquettes. In this way he adapted collage methods to the medium of sculpture.
  5. Picasso treats the glass as a distorted human head - the opening in the wall the equivalent of a human eye with a projecting eyelid, which is repeated on the opposite closed side of the "face" as well, by modeling a great nose which begins between the two eyes and curves around the face of the glass. The influence of African masks are still identifiable here.
Ernst Barlach, The Avenger, 1914

Expressionist sculpture
1.     German expressionists believed communication of emotions to be the primary purpose of art and employed distortions of shape and form to accomplish this. The angular form and passionate gesture of this sculpture is exemplary of the Expressionist vision.
2.     Ernst Barlach was a German sculptor, graphic artist and writer. Although he was a supporter of the war in the years leading to WWI, his participation in the war made him change his position,  and he is mostly known for his sculpture protesting the war. 
3.     The Avenger was made after the outbreak of the  First World War in 1914. The sculpture represents the inexorable force of the German army. The dynamic sculpture in the form of a Beserker  (an ancient Norse warrior who fought with ferocity) is a symbol of the way and the dissatisfaction with the political, economic and social conditions at that time. Described as Barlach as the “crystallized essence of War,” the sculpture was in direct response to the vengefulness and devastation of the war. 
4.     The powerful scene of a warrior striding forward and holding an enormous sword over his back accentuates the expressive language and the aggressivity characteristic of Barlach’s work. 
5.     Based on lithographs of 1914, the image passed through a number of stages before it was realised in bronze. While indebted to medieval wood statuary in mood and texture, Barlach’s work was also a significant precursor to the development of kinetic sculpture.

Stanton MacDonald‐Wright, Abstraction on Spectrum (Organization, 5), c. 1914
Des Moines Art Center, Iowa

Synchromism
  1. MacDonald-Wright was a modernist painter and one of the first Americans to paint in a purely abstract manner.
  2. Married at the age of seventeen, Macdonald-Wright moved to Paris with his wife to immerse himself in European art.  He studied at the Sorbonne, Académie Julian, École des Beaux-Arts and Académie Colarossi.
  3. He and fellow student Morgan Russell were deeply influenced by color theory, as well as by the works of Delacroix, the Impressionists, Cézanne, and Matisse that placed a great emphasis on juxtapositions and reverberations of color. Together they co-founded the avant-garde movement Synchromism, the first American avant-garde art movement to receive international attention.
  4. The theoretical basis of Synchronism began with the principles of French color theorists such as Michel Eugène Chevreul, Ogden Rood and Charles Blanc.  The movement called for abstract works in which color and shape are arranged in a harmonious way like chords in rhythmic patterns, thus appearing like a visual representation of music.  As MacDonald-Wright described it, “Synchromism simply means ‘with color’ as symphony means ‘with sound’, and our idea was to produce an art whose genesis lay, not in objectivity, but in form produced in color.”
  5. Synchromist exhibitions were staged in Munich in June 1913, Paris in October 1913, and New York in March 1914. These established Synchromism as an influence in modern art well into the 1920s, though followers of other abstract artists (principally, the Orphists, Robert and Sonia Delaunay) later claimed that the Synchromists had merely borrowed the principles of color abstraction from Orphism, a point vehemently disputed by Macdonald-Wright and Russell. The movements happened concurrently.
  6. Abstraction on Spectrum's brilliant orchestrations of bright, loud colors with softer, darker tones, create a sense of depth and movement, as do the blending of sharply painted circles with radiating color wedges that meld into one another, resulting in a dynamic composition.
  7. Throughout his career MacDonald-Wright was also an influential teacher.  He had a direct and marked influence on the work of Thomas Hart Benton, Andrew Dasburg, Stuart Davis, and Alfred Maurer.

Marsden Hartley, Portrait of a German Officer, 1914
Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York City

American Modernism influenced by Cubism and German Expressionism
  1. Marsden Hartley (1877-1943) first travelled to Europe for the first time in April 1912, and he became acquainted with Gertrude Stein's circle of avante-garde writers and artists in Paris. Stein, along with Hart Crane and Sherwood Anderson, encouraged Hartley to write as well as paint. 
  2. Hartley spent part of his career in pre-war Europe, living both in Paris and Berlin, where he became acquainted with Western European avant-gardes, in particular, Cubism and Expressionism this painting, having a collage-like appearance as well as evoking a sense of dynamism, fuses vocabularies from both of these movements. 
  3. Assimilation of both Cubism (the collagelike juxtapositions of visual fragments) and German Expressionism (the coarse brushwork and dramatic use of bright colors and black).
  4. Painted in the year when World War I broke out, this work is an abstracted portrait of Karl von Freyburg, a Prussian officer whom Hartley loved and who died in the war.
  5. In this large scale painting, Hartley represents von Freyburg through symbols: KvF are his initials, 4 is his regiment number, 24 is his age of death, and the Iron Cross represents a military recognition he received posthumously; repeated letter "E" represents Bayerische Eisenbahn, von Freyburg's regimen; the appearance of the Bavarian flag also suggests growing nationalism in Germany at the time.
  6. The artist denied that the objects in the painting had any special meaning (perhaps as a defensive measure to ward off any attacks provoked by the intense anti-German sentiment in America at the time). However, his purposeful inclusion of medals, banners, military insignia, the Iron Cross, and the German imperial flag does evoke a specific sense of Germany during World War I as well as a collective psychological and physical portrait of a particular officer.
  7. In its use of the pictorial fragmentation of Cubism and the dynamic and emotional language of German Expressionism, Hartley's abstract portrait offers a radical reinterpretation of the genre.
  8. Freyburg's subsequent death during the war hit Hartley hard, and he afterward idealized their relationship. Many scholars interpreted his work regarding Freyburg as embodying his homosexual feelings for him.
  9. A likeness no longer has to represent a person and his features, the canvas is the height of a person and embodies him in a way that is not linked to his physical appearance. 

Fun Fact: I am unfortunately not related to Marsden Hartley, but I like to call him “cousin Marsden” in my head and I am always very proud when I see his paintings in museums.

Francis Picabia, Ici, c’est ici Stieglitz, 1915
The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York

New York Modernism / Proto-Dada
  1. Published in 1915 as the cover of the avant-garde American journal 291, the original collage was one of a series of witty “mecanomorphs,” or machine portraits, by Franco-Cuban artist Francis Picabia.
  2. Owned by Alfred Stieglitz, who exhibited it at his 291 Gallery (which gave the aforementioned publication its title) in a solo exhibition of Picabia’s work ("Exhibition of Recent Paintings–Never before Exhibited Any Where–by Francis Picabia, of New York," January 12–26, 1915). 291 was a hub in the New York modern art scene.
  3. The collage is inscribed (upper left, printed, on pasted strip of paper): ICI, C'EST ICI STIEGLITZ/ FOI ET AMOUR (Here, This Here is Stieglitz / Faith and Love); inscribed (upper center, collage of printed letters): IDEAL
  4. Stieglitz was a photographer, and Picabia used the imagery of machine parts and technical manuals to deflate his subject’s pretentions. He depicts Stieglitz as a limp and broken camera striving toward, but not reaching, the “Ideal.” The portrait also includes an automobile gearshift lodged in neutral and an engaged hand brake, suggesting that Stieglitz was going nowhere. (This rather brutal reading brought to you by the National Portrait Gallery) 
  5. “IDEAL” is collaged from a typeface that recalls earlier movements’ backward-looking affinity for Renaissance ideals and aesthetics (eg, Symbolists, Academic art)
  6. Collision between the utopic view of machines’ potential (see: Vorticists) and the dystopic view of their potential for destruction (WWI - new technologies deployed for warfare).
  7. Soon after, Picabia would be a founding member of the New York Dada group. New York Dada was less overtly political than German (Berlin) or French (Paris). In Europe, Dada sought to actively interrupt dominant systems, including of order, perception, politics, and typology. In New York, where the scene was predominantly made up of expat artists, Dada was more playful and sardonic. Both European and American Dada emphasized visual punning and wordplay. 
Fun fact: Picabia was a gear head, who owned lots of cars and liked to drive fast - so coming from him, a machine stuck in neutral was a particularly pointed dig.

Max Weber, Rush Hour, New York, 1915
National Gallery of Art, Washington, D. C.

American Modernism / Cubism
1. The American Max Weber spent three years in Paris where he absorbed the interests of the avant-garde, developing his individual Cubist style upon return to New York; adapts both the shallow fragmented spaces of Cubism and the rapid-fire repeating forms of Italian Futurism
2. Weber was among the several avant-garde artists associated with the Stieglitz circle (alongside Marin, Dove, Hartley, O’Keefe), who were among the earliest Americans to embrace modernism. Weber was included in the 1910 group show “Younger American Painters” at Stieglitz’ 291 gallery, a show that attracted much attention and was denounced by critics who raged against the insanity and anarchy of this new art; helped spread modernism in America
3. Rush Hour captures the ultramodern spirit and frenetic pace of New York City at the turn of the century, inspired by its elevated railways, skyscrapers and underground subways, manifestations of the new urban age. The mundane annoyances and frustrations of commuting give way to the vast abstractions of space and time.
4. Like Duchamp, Weber was influenced by the innovations in photography of Muybridge and Marey.
