Joan Miró, The Kiss, 1924

Biomorphic surrealism
  1. Joan Miro (1893-1983) Began in the late teens in Barcelona as a Fauve-derived painter, absorbed the lessons of Cubism, arrived in Paris in the early twenties and by 1923 was assimilated to the circle of poets and artists around André Breton.
  2. The mid-1920s "dream paintings" such as The Kiss are read by some as erotic recordings of Matisse's work from around 1911.
  3. In The Kiss, fields of intense color are allowed to spread uninterrupted over the surface, so disembodied is the drawing within them. The drawing within is performed as a kind of calligraphy that converts all bodies to the transparency and weightlessness of the written sign.
  4. Typical of his use of biomorphic forms that evoke living forms (cells), or geometric shapes and semi-abstracted objects that call forth poetic associations/metaphors. Compared to his more complex paintings like The Hunter (1924), it employs more elementary forms that are open to plural meanings.
  5. The calligraphic/biomorphic form at the center evokes the number eight, the sign of infinity; with the red bar at the center, it also indicates joining of two cells in erotic contact.
  6. In this way, the picture could serve as an emblem for all Surrealist image-making: the emotional force released by the contact of two sexually charged "distant realities."
  7. Biomorphic Surrealism models artistic design elements on naturally occurring patterns or shapes reminiscent of nature and living organisms. Taken to its extreme it attempts to force naturally occurring shapes onto functional devices. Often associated with automatic abstraction (in comparison to Freudian/pschyological Surrealists)
Eugene Atget, Magasin, avenue des Gobelins, 1925

French Documentary Photography
  1. Atget was not an artist in the conventional sense but a specialized craftsman, who (for more than 30 years) supplied pictorial records of Parisian life and French culture to artists, antiquarians, and librarians. Over time, his eye as an artist came to be recognized, particularly as avant-garde artists looked to his photographs as visual reference points for modern life. 
  2. Atget’s photographs captured both modern Paris and disappearing traces of historic France - its ancient streets and monuments, and vernacular architecture. 
  3. Atget’s work served as inspiration for artists from a wide swath of modernist groups: his “found” montages of shop-window reflection were Surrealist for the Surrealists, but his vastly varied body of work also inspired Neue-Sachlichkeit painters and “straight photography” practitioners. 
  4. This picture of the front of a men's clothing store belongs to a series of photographs of store windows that Atget made in the highly creative last years of his life. 
  5. Atget easily could have minimized the reflection in the window, in which we see part of the Gobelins complex, where tapestries had been made for nearly three centuries. Instead, he welcomed it: a fusion of modern fashion and centuries-old artistic tradition.

Albert Renger­‐Patzsch,
Irons Used in Shoemaking, Fagus Works, c. 1925

New Objectivity / Straight photography
1. In its sharply focused and matter-of-fact style Renger-Patzsch’s work exemplifies the esthetic of New Objectivity that dominated the arts in Germany during the Weimar Republic.
2. New Objectivity = a post-WWI Social Realist movement in Germany characterized by embittered disillusionment and scathing cynicism in reaction to the atrocities of the war (Dix, Grosz, Beckmann)
3. Renger-Patzsch worked in a straight photographic tradition: avoided the double exposures and photographic manipulations of Man Ray and Moholy-Nagy, as well as the soulfulness of the Pictorialists
4. Despite his stark realism and his commitment to factuality, Renger-Patzsch’s photographs are so enlarged and crisply purified that they border on pure design
5. In in 1928, he published a photo book called The World is Beautiful: a collection of 100 of his photographs in which natural forms, industrial subjects and mass-produced objects are presented with the clarity of scientific illustrations.
6. Believed in the camera's innate ability to depict the Industrial Age: Irons used in Shoemaking is a study of the materials of identically shaped, finished wooden handles and industrially produced steel heads
7. Celebrates the beauty of the commonplace object: wrote in 1927 that “we still don't sufficiently appreciate the opportunity to capture the magic of material things. The structure of wood, stone, and metal can be shown with a perfection beyond the means of painting. To do justice to modern technology's rigid linear structure: only photography is capable of that.”
8. Not as scathingly satirical or openly political as his painter colleagues (Grosz, Dix), but the arrangement–representing the flatirons as an army of tools standing at attention–might still contain a commentary on war and militarism:
9. Reflects the increasing shift to the right of German politics in the mid-20s as well as the fierce antimilitarism of artists on the left; an uncanny premonition of how the manufacturing and war industry would flourish under Hitler (who promised and partially achieved an economic upswing through the militarization of the country for WWII).
Walter Gropius, Workshop Wing, Bauhaus, 1925‐26

Bauhaus
  1. Gropius was committed to functionalism, Constructivist ideas, and a utopian potential for architecture.
  2. Emphasis on the unification of architecture, artistry and craftsmanship insisting that the architect, painter and sculpture should be craftspeople first and foremost. In this way the Bauhau philosophy was dependent upon the breaking of barriers between “fine art” and craft, and advocated for a reconciliation between craft and industry.
  3. Facing drastic budget cuts in Weimar under a conservative government, Gropius was forced to close the Bauhaus school and relocate to the industrial town of Dessau, a more liberal region that would also better allow for his desire to knit the aims of art and industry.
  4. The buildings reflect Gropius’s philosophy of functionalism. The form of the Workshop wing suggests the uninterrupted spaces of its interior while the dormitory wing, with its smaller window units reveal the compartmentalization of the interior apartments.
  5. Gropius sought the most efficient organization of the interior while maintaining an abstract organization of the rectangular geometric exterior inspired by de Stijl design. The workshops consisted of load bearing concrete skeleton and his signature glass curtain wall freely suspended from sculptural steel elements. The glass wall allows for a view of the interior workings of the building and its construction and wrapped around the corner of the workshop, creating a lightness and openness to the space. 
  6. The entire building was intended to be a Gesamtkunstwerk, with all the interior fittings, lighting, furniture, made in the Bauhaus workshop itself.
  7. “We want to create buildings as clear, organic bodies, naked and radiant by virtue of their own inherent laws, free of falsehood and extravagancies,” wrote Gropius in 1923.
Grete Schütte-­Lihotzky, Frankfurt Kitchen, 1926

International Style
1.     War and inflation  precipitated a housing crisis in all major German cities including Frankfurt where the response was an ambitious program known as the New Frankfurt. This initiative encompassed the construction of affordable public housing and modern amenities throughout the city. At the core of this transformation were about 10,000 kitchens designed by Schütte-­Lihotzky, constructed as an integral element of the new dwelling units. 
2.     The Frankfurt Kitchen was a milestone in domestic architecture, and was considered a forerunner of modern fitted kitchens: it realised for the first time a kitchen built after a unified concept, designed to enable efficient work and to be built at a low cost.
3.     It featured a rational, unpretentious and socially oriented design. It was conceived as one of the first steps towards building a better, more egalitarian world in the late 1920s.
4.     The Frankfurt Kitchen was designed like a laboratory or factory and  based on contemporary theories about efficiency, hygiene and workflow. In planning the design, she conducted details  time-motion studies and interviews with housewives and women’s groups. Her primary goal in the design was to reduce the burden of women’s labour in the home.
5.     Each kitchen came with a revolving stool, a gas stove, and built-in storage. Careful thought was given to the choice of materials: oak containers to repel mealworms and beech cutting surfaces to resist staining. The result is one of modernism’s most famous cooking spaces. 
6.     Her design was strongly influenced by ideas of Taylorism (the theory of management that synthesizes workflow and improves economic efficiency). The growing trend that called for viewing household work as a true profession enabled the industrial optimisation pioneered by Taylorism to spill over in the domestic area.
André Masson, Battle of Fishes, 1926

Surrealism/Automatism
  1. Masson was the most passionate revolutionary amidst the Surrealists; by nature an anarchist and anti-conformist; he collaborated on and off with both Breton and Bataille.
  2. Masson often worked after long periods of time without food or sleep, or under the influence of drugs. He believed forcing himself into a reduced state of consciousness would help his art be free from rational control, and hence closer to his subconscious.
  3. He regularly contributed automatic drawings to the journal, La Révolution surréaliste.
  4. In 1926 he developed sand paintings, a technique that allowed him to achieve the freedom and spontaneity of automatic drawing, involuntary actions and processes not under the control of the conscious mind, on canvas. Battle of Fishes was made by freely applying gesso to areas of the canvas, throwing sand on it, then brushing away the excess. The resulting contours suggested forms "although almost always irrational ones," according to the artist, around which he rapidly sketched and applied paint directly from the tube (allowing chance to help determine his compositions, which Surrealism inherited from Dada; compare to Arp’s Collage of Squares Arranged According to the Laws of Chance 1916-7).
  5. The image that emerged suggests a savage underwater battle between sharp–toothed fish, two that seem to be gushing blood. Masson believed that, if left to chance, pictorial compositions would reveal the sadism of all living creatures.
  6. Seriously wounded, mentally and physically, during World War I, he suffered a spiritual crisis and was briefly confined to a hospital for mental illness. This work has been read as an allegory of his war experience.
  7. Recognized as his most significant works, Masson's 20 sand paintings are all "to one degree or another hallucinatory marine landscapes," full of hybrid figures, symbols of dissolution and destruction. (William Rubin)
  8. Masson lived in the US during WWII, where his automatism directly influenced the drip and allover of the gestural Abstract Expressionists, including Pollock (Masson: Pollock carried automatism to the extreme), returning to Paris in 1946

Edward Hopper, Eleven A.M., 1926
Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, Washington, D.C.

Urban Realism
  1. Edward Hopper (1882–1967) was an American realist painter and printmaker. While he is widely known for his oil paintings, he was equally proficient as a watercolorist and printmaker in etching. Both in his urban and rural scenes, his spare and finely calculated renderings reflected his personal vision of modern American life.
  2. Hopper studied under Robert Henri at the New York School of Art from 1900-1906 and acquired fascination with the urban scene. He relied on commercial art to support himself, and the imagery of signs and advertising art later appeared in many of his paintings.
  3. This painting shows a typical Hopper interior - a sense of loneliness and isolation with a scene of windows looking out onto the city, the view closed off by tall buildings.
  4. The subject is an unidealized nude woman, who represents the darkly erotic element often present in Hopper's paintings. Her face is hidden but there is a sense that she is lost in the loneliness of her thoughts. Silence fills the scene.
  5. The low-keyed palette contributes to an atmosphere of depression and the mood of introspective isolation has affinities with European Surrealist art.
  6. The cropped composition with objects in the immediate foreground cutting into the scene - contributes to a sense of hemming-in, compactness, isolation and there is an influence from stage set design.
Edward Weston, Shell, 1927

Straight Photography / Pure Photography
  1. Shells is an example of the ‘pure’ or ‘straight’ style that characterised Weston’s still life photographs. These terms first emerged in the 1880s to refer to a photographic approach that prioritised high contrast, sharp focus and an emphasis on the formal qualities of the subject, as opposed to the pictorialist tradition, in which subjects were photographically manipulated through soft focus, cropping and composite image techniques.
  2. Unlike the nonrepresentational compositions of photographers like László Moholy-Nagy, Weston’s abstractions always remained grounded in objects from the real world. He wrote in 1930, "To see the Thing Itself is essential."
  3. The image features a nautilus shell balanced within an abalone shell that rests upon a semi-reflective surface. In the photograph’s title, “Shells,” the plural prompts the viewers to look closely and identify the divisions between the carefully placed objects, which may be mistaken for one single shell.
  4. Weston took this photograph in his studio in Glendale, California, in 1927. He carefully placed the two shells into position and photographed them using a long exposure time of several hours, a process that lead to the intense contrast between light and shadow in the image. 
  5. Weston’s interest in nautilus shells was prompted by a 1927 meeting with the Californian painter Henrietta Shore, for whom Weston was a sitter at the time and who often featured shells in her paintings. Weston wrote in his diary of seeing these shells in her studio, stating that that he ‘never saw a Chambered Nautilus before. If I had, my response would have been immediate!”
  6. Throughout 1927 he took twenty-six still life images of shells, particularly nautilus shells, against a variety of grounds including “glass, tin, cardboard – wool, velvet, even my rubber coat!” 
  7. For other object-based, abstract-seeming works, see Georgia O’Keefe’s paintings.

Ansel Adams
Monolith, the Face of Half Dome, Yosemite National Park
1927

America straight photography
1. Adams amongst those American photographers associated with the American West (alongside Paul Strand and Imogen Cunningham): Adam’s work, largely marked by photographing Yosemite National Park, shows the spectacular unspoiled vistas of the West in a close-up frame that reveals the textures of the earth
2. Adams was an experienced mountaineer and dedicated conservationist; Monolith was used by the Sierra Club as a visual aid for the environmentalist movement (the Sierra Club is one of the first large-scale environmental preservation organizations in the world)
3. Influence: Adams met Paul Strand in 1930 and was supported by Stieglitz
4. Monolith is an example of straight photography: exploits the intrinsic properties of the camera to make photographs that look like photographs and not like paintings
5. Adams used a deep-red filter for Monolith to transform the bright sky into a dark black background to achieve a stark contrast between the white snow and black sky and make smaller details more clear
6. Monolith prompted Adams to coin the term "visualization", which broke away from straight photography proper: visualization is a method in which a photographer envisages what they want the photo to look, and carefully controls aspects of the scene, film, filter, and developmental process to create their exact vision. Adams stated, “I realized that only a deep red filter would give me anything approaching the effect I felt emotionally” (introduces emotions into photographic practice)
7. Monolith is crucial to the development of modern photography, the environmentalist movement, and photography's role in social movements; further important for the expansion of audience for photography (his images were available on cards, posters, photomurals to a wider public than that of the museumgoers)
8. Monolith has also physically endured the test of time as the original film negative and glass plate are still intact and printable
9. Adams helped establish the Department of Photography at MoMA in 1940
Yves Tanguy, Mama, Papa is Wounded!, 1927

Surrealism
Oil on canvas
  1. In this work, Tanguy establishes a set of obsessions that would occupy him throughout his career: infinite perspective depth rendered simply by graded color and a sharp horizon line, and the creation of space with both vast emptiness and intimate enclose as a result of this illusion of deep space that does not behave according the laws of geometrical perspective.  
  2. The figures are ambiguously placed within the vertical space, and Tanguy uses light to create the sense that the object coast in the air above their shadows.
  3. The influence of earlier Metaphysical painter Giorgio de Chirico is evident in the falling shadows and a figure that recalls a classical torso.
  4. He took the title of this painting and others from psychiatric textbooks, emphasizing the importance of Freudian psychoanalysis in his work.
  5. Entirely self-taught, Tanguys early works are “naïve” in their flatness, but in 1927 he abruptly matured, producing this as one of his first paintings in his new style. This painting solidified Tanguy’s entry into the Surrealist circle, contributing to all the Surrealist exhibitions and appearing in their publications from that point on.

Marcel Breuer, Armchair, model B3, Dessau, Germany
Designed late 1927 or early 1928

Bauhaus
1.     Marcel Breuer created many furniture  designs at the Bauhaus that have become classics including this first tubular-steel chair. Unlike heavily upholstered furniture, his simple, machine-made chairs were airy, penetrable, and easy to move. Through Breuer’s influence, a new vocabulary of simple, functional shapes was established in metal design. 
2.     The Bauhaus commitment to integrating art and industry led to technical and formal experimentation. Materials that had been developed for purely industrial purposes, like steel tuning, were adopted for their aesthetic as well functional properties. A familiar material through its use in bicycle handlebars, tubular steel is light-weight and durable.
3.     The model for this chair is the traditional club chair, but all that remains is its mere outline, an elegant composition traced in steel. The canvas seat, back and arms seem to float in space; the body of the sitter does not touch the steel framework. 
4.     Breuer claimed to have drawn inspiration from tubular steel handlebars of his bicycle, which were strong, lightweight and mass-produced. 
5.     The chair was dubbed the “Wassily” after the painter Kandinsky, Breuer’s friend and fellow Bauhaus instructor, who had praised the design when it was first produced.
6.     Breuer spoke of the chair as his “most extreme work… the least artistic, the most logical, the least ‘cozy’ and the most mechanical.”
Richard Neutra, Lovell House, Los Angeles, 1927‐29

International Style
  1. Richard Neutra was a prominent Jewish Austrian-American modern architect; he lived and built primarily in Southern California.
  2. Neutra's masterpiece, The Lovell Health House, is an International style modernist residence located in the Los Feliz neighborhood of Los Angeles sited on a steep hillside.  Designed and built between 1927 and 1929 for naturopathic doctor and Los Angeles Times health columnist Dr. Philip Lovell. It is an icon of modern architectural history and was a turning point in Neutra's career.
  3. It reflects Neutra's interest in industrial production. It is thought to be the first US residence with a prefabricated steel structure integrated with tension cables. It was also the first to use gunite (spray-on concrete). Many of the building's components, like the factory-made window assemblies, were ordered from the manufacturer's catalog; part of architecture revolution, as machine-made, pre-fabricated parts replaced the earlier handcrafted, custom-made work produced by artisans on site.
  4. The large glass windows and interior reflects Neutra's interest in Cubism, transparency, and hygiene. In another nod to industrial production, Neutra installed two Ford Model-A headlights in the main stairwell.
  5. Neutra's psycho-physical architecture pioneered the incorporation of modern psychology in the field.  He embraced Freud's principles of projection and psychic energy and combined them with Gestalt's views that the psyche and its environment are a dynamic and interactive whole.
  6. Known for his relationships with his clients—he thought of himself as a therapist and the client his patient, he adapted his buildings to the heterogeneity of their personal experiences.
  7. The Lovell Health House was enveloped in nature, as Dr. Lovell, its visionary patron, promoted vegetarianism, exercise, drugless healing, and a healthy sex life. It was commissioned to be the first helio-therapeutic modern home, with spaces for medical demonstrations and experiments.  It boasted windows that let in extra UV rays, sleeping porches, areas for nude sunbathing, an outdoor gym and schoolroom, and a kitchen designed for vegetarian cooking.
  8. It was included in MoMA's 1932 'Modern Architecture' exhibition that gave the International Style its name retrospectively.

Fun fact: The home is currently for sale.  However, the owners are seeking a preservation-minded buyer as it needs significant cosmetic and structural repairs.
James Van Der Zee, Harlem Billiard Room, n. d. (likely between 1916-1930)

Harlem Renaissance photography
  1. James Van der Zee (1886-1983) was an African-American photographer best known for his portraits of black New Yorkers. He was a leading figure in the Harlem Renaissance. Aside from the artistic merits of his work, Van Der Zee produced the most comprehensive documentation of the period.
  2. Van Der Zee created a visual portrait of Harlem at the time. earned his living as a portrait photographer, created a visual portrait of Harlem, documenting weddings, funerals, graduations
  3. Van der Zee mostly did portraits (which were paid) so this is more unique because he is not getting paid for it. His studio portraits captured the aspirational dreams of his sitters, striking a balance between rich fantasy and confident modernity.
  4. This photograph of the pool hall is very carefully staged even though it is public pool hall.It is not candid, everyone knows the photo is being taken. Van der Zee creates the opportunity for Black people to be a part of their own narrative.
  5. One theme that recurs in his photographs was the emergent black middle class, which he captured using traditional techniques in often idealistic images. 
  6. In helping to create the image of the New Negro, styling and retouching the photographs to create uplifting images of black Americans, Van Der Zee produced photographs of Harlem's residents that capture the optimism, style, pride, and sophistication associated with this new urban identity. He retouched his own negatives. 
  7. Historic background: between two world wars, African Americans migrated to urban, industrialized north, fleeing racial and economic oppression. This gave rise to the New Negro Movement which encouraged African Americans to become politically progressive and radically conscious. It stimulated a flowering of black art and culture known as the Harlem Renaissance.
  8. The Harlem Renaissance grew out of the ideas of thinkers like W. E. B. du Bois, who helped to found the New Negro movement earlier in the century. Fundamental to the movement was the insistence that any conception of "the negro" had to be formulated by Blacks themselves; the characterizations of African-Americans by whites, which often relied on denigrating stereotypes, had to be eliminated from black consciousness and replaced with a positive self- image.
Buckminster Fuller, Dymaxion House, 1928

Futuristic/Utopian Architecture
  1. In the 1920s, architect and practical philosopher R. Buckminister Fuller designed a sustainable, autonomous single family dwelling that he called the Dymaxion house. The word “Dymaxion,” which combines the words dynamic, maximum and tension, was coined by Fuller.
  2. The Dymaxion house represented innovations in prefabrication and sustainability, which went on to influence later architects (see the wedge-shaped rooms of Bertrand Goldberg’s Marina City and Prentice Hospital). If it had gone into broad production, it could have been mass-produced in light-weight aluminum, flat packed, and shipped worldwide. As Fuller put it, “that is the Dymaxion principle of doing ever more with ever less weight, time, and ergs per each given level of functional performance.”
  3. The 100 sqm hexagonal house (Fuller’s later versions of the designs were rounded) was an earthquake and storm resistant structure, supported by a central pole from which cables would be suspended, allowing the outer walls to be non-bearing. The Dymaxion's round shape minimized heat loss and the amount of materials needed, while also lending it strength. 
  4. By grouping all permanent utilities in the central pole, and letting the rest of the interior space remain modular, Fuller created a flexible plan that would allow tenants to transform the space according to their needs.
  5. The Dymaxion was abandoned by Fuller until 1944, when the post-War housing shortage urged Fuller to revisit his previous idea of mass production of residential units. To make the house a reality, Fuller soon signed a two year research contract with Beech Aircraft industries, who held an abundance of aluminum in the aftermath of World War II. In 1946 Fuller completed two prototypes: the Barwise prototype and the Danbury prototype, though neither were assembled nor mass produced, mainly due to Fuller’s unwillingness to compromise. 
  6. Fuller was accused of being overly technical at the expense of aesthetic merit, a charge to which he responded, "I never work with aesthetic considerations in mind, but I have a test: if something isn't beautiful when I get finished with it, it's no good."
  7. Fuller went on to teach at Black Mountain College, a nexus of modern art where students included Ruth Asawa, Elaine de Kooning, Willem de Kooning, Robert Rauschenberg, Dorothea Rockburne, and Cy Twombly. Other teachers included John Cage, Merce Cunningham, and Josef and Anni Albers.
Fun fact: The Dymaxion only weighs about 3000 pounds versus the 150 tons of an average home (Fuller liked to ask people how much their house weighed), and would have cost about the same as an average car.
Laszlo Moholy‐Nagy, Berlin, 1928

Bauhaus straight photography
Gelatin silver print
1. Moholy-Nagy was an important advocate for abstract art, Constructivism, design, architecture and experimental photography. He was born in Hungary and trained in law; became professor at the Bauhaus where he taught the foundation course in 1920s; later became director of the New Bauhaus in Chicago in late 1930s; his writings are important documents of modern artists’ search for a place in technology and industry
2. Like Man Ray but apparently unaware of his inventions, Moholy-Nagy developed his own camera-less images (which Ray had called ‘Rayograms’) in the early 1920s and called them ‘photograms’ – testimony to the highly experimental nature of photography in the 1920s
3. Berlin was made in the year Moholy-Nagy left the Bauhaus in Dessau to relocate to Berlin (1928)
4. An example of Moholy-Nagy’s practice of straight photography: interest in sharply angled, vertiginous views resulting in dynamic compositions similar to Constructivists (compare Rodchenko’s Assembling for a Demonstration 1928)
5. From a series of nine views looking straight down from the Berlin Radio Tower, which was itself a symbol of new communication technology and architectural innovation: one of the newest constructions of the Weimar Republic (finished in 1926, 450 feet high, but with a base 7x smaller than the Eiffel Tower); Moholy-Nagy had already photographed the Eiffel Tower from below looking straight up – an angle he now reversed
6. Exhibition history: Moholy-Nagy hung Berlin just above his name in a room devoted to his work at the Berlin showing of Film und Foto (1932), a mammoth traveling exhibition that he had helped to prepare
7. Moholy-Nagy understood the camera a means for disclosing the underlying purity of form (achieving a level of abstraction reminiscent of the photogram)
8. Famous Moholy-Nagy quote: “the illiterate of the future will be ignorant of camera and pen alike”
Aleksandr Rodchenko, Assembling for a Demonstration, 1928

Russian Constructivist Photography
  1. After 1921, Rodchenko dedicated himself to the Soviet experiment, abandoning sculpture for graphic, textile, theater design and photography.
  2. He determined that the most interesting angle shots were those taken looking down form above, or looking up from below often on a diagonal to gain a new perspective on the world, and to allow for a more abstracted image. In this image, he constructs a composition of sharp diagonals, light-dark contrasts and asymmetrical patterns, a seeming metaphor for a new society where outdated perspectives have given way to new ones.
  3. He presents his subject, a public demonstration, as a concept, rather than a factual document, embracing a broader symbolic dimension filled with enigmatic detail.
  4. Similar to straight photography, Rodchenko did not manipulate his images, instead relying oh the purity of the form itself, abstracted as a result of his physical angle. (Similar to Moholy Nagy’s Berlin)

Bruno Taut and Martin Wagner, Britz­‐Siedlung,
Berlin, 1928

The Hufeisensiedlung (Horseshoe Estate) is a housing estate in Berlin. At the beginning of the 20th century Berlin was growing dramatically. From 1850 to the end of the 1920s  its population had roughly doubled every 25 years, caused by the advance of industrialisation and the end of WWI. The overcrowded and dirty conditions of Berlin’s tenements called for the improvement of the living conditions of poor people, and led to the reformation of urban planning and new housing estates. 
2.     The main horseshoe building was built around an interior garden with a pond at its centre. His intention was that the inhabitants of the estate would have contact with nature, by creating the wide balconies and windows which opened out to  the gardens. The construction is historically considered as one of the first to humanise high density housing.
3.     To keep with the cost-effective construction, the flats were standardised with just four floor plans. The emphasis was on maximum utility: the concept of isolation and separation is discarded. Taut’s concept of the horseshoe derived from his desire to fulfil the needs of its inhabitants for socialisation.
4.     Yet, the monotony was broken with asymmetries and a staggered arrangement of the blocks of building. The apartments were further individualised through the use of contrasting colors for the interior design, which later become Taut’s trademark.
5.     However, the project was not  able to fulfil its social function as planned. The buildings costs were higher than estimated, and as a result the rent was set high and unaffordable for workers and craftsman; politically engaged artists and intellectuals moved in instead.

Charles Demuth, I Saw the Figure 5 in Gold, 1928
Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York City

Precisionism
Oil, graphite, ink, and gold leaf on paperboard (Upson board)
  1. Demuth was one of the major figures of Precisionism, the first modern American art movement, highly influenced by the fractured visual language of cubism and the dynamism of futurism, but applied to distinctive American places like cities and the factories that built the industrial landscape. Precisionists created art characterized by geometric simplification, smooth surfaces, clean lines, stripped of detail, and often based on sharp-focus photographs.
  2. Between 1924 and 1929, Demuth completed a series of eight abstract or symbolic portraits of his friends, modern American artists, writers, and performers; made up of images, words, and letters, these "posters" as he called them, were related to the Dadaists' symbolic portraits.
  3. This is a conceptual portrait of his friend, poet William Carlos Williams, whose initials and nickname ("Bill") appear in the painting, and his middle name emanates from a skyscraper in the distance like Broadway lights. The title, images, and colors were inspired by his poem, "The Great Figure," about a fire engine emblazoned with a golden #5 racing through the city streets. Demuth derived the imagery and title from the poem.
  4. The diagonal, intersecting lines, repeated "5" in different sizes conveying a sense of movement, round forms of the numbers, lights, street lamp, and the red fire engine infuse the painting with a vibrant, urban energy.
  5. Like other postwar artists, Demuth was searching for intrinsically American subjects and became interested in the advertising signs on buildings and along highways, as images with a certain abstract beauty.
  6. Demuth's work influenced that of Stuart Davis, Jasper Johns, and Robert Indiana
Stuart Davis, Egg Beater #4, 1928

American Modernism
  1. Stuart Davis (1892-1964) was an American modernist painter. Faced with the choice between realism and pure abstraction early in his career, Davis invented a vocabulary that harnessed the grammar of abstraction to the speed and simultaneity of modern America.
  2. This is the final work in Davis's "Egg Beater" series of 1927-8, where he achieved an original abstract style. The series became increasingly more two-dimensional and well integrated.
  3. By merging the bold, hard-edged style of advertising with the conventions of European avant-garde painting, he created an art endowed with the vitality and dynamic rhythms that he saw as uniquely modern and American.
  4. In the process, he achieved a rare synthesis: an art that is resolutely abstract, yet at the same time exudes the spirit of popular culture.
  5. Although realism dominated the American scene between the wars, Davis maintained an abstract style. Davis, although committed to socialist reforms, did not exploit painting as a public platform for political beliefs. He made art that would appeal and exists between regionalist conservative and abstract art.
  6. His 1920s works explored consumer-product packaging in a Synthetic Cubist style. Egg Beater is one in a series called Egg Beater 1927-28 in which he painted an eggbeater, fan, and rubber glove repeatedly until he had worked his way out of illusion and embraced color, line, and shape relations. They are clearly defined, fragmented objects in a geometric abstract organization.
  7. Unrelated objects—eggbeater, electric fan, and rubber glove—are brought together to focus on relationships of color, shape, and space. These objects were the sole elements of the entire series. This unexpected combination of modern appliances reminiscent of the Dada appreciation for absurd juxtapositions became the sole focus of Davis's craft for a year.
  8. The shapes overlap, giving an impression of collage, and they are interlocked into the flat surface of the painting. But the composition also suggests a spatial dimension, giving the impression of both interior and exterior spaces. The angled line of on the left may be interpreted as the edge of the studio wall, while the white lines against the dark background along the top edge of the painting resemble building tops against the night sky. These interplays of inside-outside, surface and depth are complemented by the lively contrasts of color: light and dark, vivid and pale, all working together to create a variety of rhythms reminiscent of jazz music.
Mies van der Rohe, Barcelona Pavilion, 1928‐29

International Style
  1. Mies van der Rohe is regarded as one of the most influential architects and architectural theorists of the 20th century. He served as the third and last director of the Bauhaus in Dessau from 1930 to 1933. (thanks Monica!)
  2. Mies’ edict was “less is more”: he emphasized rationalism and refinement of design and eschewed ornament (a hallmark of both International Style and Bauhaus teachings). 
  3. Mies was in charge of Germany’s entire contribution to the Barcelona International Exposition in 1929. His design is regarded as paradigmatic of International Style, along with Le Corbusier’s Villa Savoye (Poissy, France). 
  4. Unlike other pavilions at the exposition, Mies’s building would not house art or sculpture. Rather, the pavilion was designed to be a place of tranquility and escape from the exposition, in effect transforming the pavilion into an inhabitable sculpture.
  5. The roof was supported by a series of slender chrome columns,  and projected out over the exterio, blurring the line between interior and exterior. 
  6. The marble walls were used not for support but rather to define space, framing views and choreographing movement. Unlike his earlier work in which the outer boundaries of spaces were typically rendered in glass, end walls served to define a free-flowing interior space within an overall rectangle - a hallmark of his later work. 
  7. The German Pavillion was one of Mies’ final realized projects in Europe, before the closing of the Bauhaus by the Nazi government in 1933. 
Fun fact: The pavilion was destroyed at the end of the exposition (as was often the case with temporary exposition architecture), but in 1986, in celebration of the 100 year anniversary of Mies’ birth, it was completely reconstructed in Barcelona according to the original plans.
Moisei Ginzburg and Ignati Milinis, Narkomfin Apartment building, Moscow, 1928‐30

Russian Constructivist architecture
1. Architects of the 1920s in Russia had to face the social reality of an overcrowded socialist city: any single-family apartment unit with more than one room (on the same level) would eventually be converted to a multi-family kommunalka. Ginzburg thus designed vertically separated units (bedroom above and kitchen/living room below) to retain single-family status for these units (called “cells”).
2. This reinforced concrete block of flats in the central district of Moscow was designed for high rank employees at the Commissariat of Finance (called Narkomfin). Conceived as a transitional type of experimental house, it is a renowned example of Constructivist architecture and avant-garde housing design.
3. As advertised by the architects, the apartments were to form an intervention into the everyday life of the inhabitants. By offering Communal facilities such as kitchens, creches and laundry as part of the block, the tenants were encouraged into a more socialist and, by taking women out of their traditional roles, feminist way of life. The utopianism fell out of favor with Stalin’s consolidation of power and was rejected as being too ‘leftist’ or ‘Trotskyist’.
4. Le Corbusier, who studied the building during his visits to the Soviet Union, was vocal about the debt he owed to the pioneering ideas of the Narkomfin building, and he used a variant of its duplex flat plans in his Unité d'Habitation.
5. The building is currently in a very dilapidated state, although still partially inhabited. It is at the top of the UNESCO 'Endangered Buildings' list and there is an ongoing international campaign to save the landmark.
William Van Alen, Chrysler Building, 1928‐30

Art Deco
  1. Commissioned by real-estate developer William Reynolds, but sold during construction under financial pressure to Walter Chrysler, founder of the car manufacturing company. Chrysler had founded Chrysler corps three years earlier and wanted to make a visible statement about his prominence in business. They sought to make the building the tallest in the world, one of many participating in a “race to the sky” in 1920s New York. It was briefly the tallest building in the world until 1931 when the Empire State Building was completed.
  2. The 1916 Zoning Resolution imposed a setback law – restricting the height of a building before it had to be setback from the street, ushering in the silhouette of the skyscraper with its broad base and setback slender tower, topped by a pyramidal cap or spire. The Chrysler follows this structure
  3. Art-Deco design was more geometric, incorporating chevron, sunburst, fountain and arc motifs, more rectilinear than art nouveau. This manifests in the Chrysler building in the black and white horizontal stripes delineating each floor in the brickwork, the crown with seven layers of crescent setbacks inset with triangular windows.
  4. References to the automobile company are made throughout the design, in the frieze of the brickwork, to the streamlined metal eagle heads and winged radiator caps that protrude from the corner of the building
  5. The stock market crashed in the midst of the building’s construction. While it was able to be completed, the building was considered the epitome of modernity and progress in architecture, but it quickly became a symbol of a lost, hedonistic era, associated with the economic decisions that led to the market crash. Some however saw the building in its upward thrust, and reflective crown as a symbol of hope for future prosperity.
 Fun fact: learning about this building has made me hate it :)
Le Corbusier, Villa Savoye, Poissy, 1928‐31

International Style architecture
1.     Swiss architect Le Corbusier’s principal exploration throughout his career was the reconciliation of human beings with nature and the modern machine. This was addressed largely through the question of the house, which he famously described as “a machine for living.” While his villas in the early 1920s demonstrated the precision of architecture, his later designs like this were more free form.
2.     Villa Savoye is a modernist villa on the outskirts of Paris, originally built as a country retreat for the Savoye family; known as an exemplar of the International Style, defined by Corbusier’s Five Points of a New Architecture, published in 1926 (characterised by supporting pillars to elevate the building and extend space, free plan allowing interpenetration of inner and outer space, roof garden- flat roof as an additional living area, long horizontal windows for more illumination etc.)
3.     Corbusier had learned the properties of ferro-concrete (concrete reinforced with steel) with Perret in Paris, which he incorporated here. By the exploiting the lightness and strength of ferro-concrete, his aim was to maximize the interpenetration of inner and outer space and create plans of utmost freedom and flexibility.
4.     The enclosed ground level has a curved glass end wall containing a garage, set under the hovering second story. The Savoye family would drive right under the house– the curve of the floor was determined by the turning radius of the car. This design concept was based on the notion of the car as the ultimate machine and the idea that the approach up to and through the house carried ceremonial significance. 
5.     The complex volumes and planes in the Villa Savoye relate to Le Corbusier’s Purist paintings. Unlike what they saw as ‘decorative’ fragmentation of objects in Cubism, Purism proposed a style where elements were represented as robust simplified forms with minimal detail, while embracing technology and the machine.
René Magritte, The Treachery of Images, 1929

Surrealism
  1. Magritte was a Belgian artist, one of the most prominent Surrealists.  His reconfiguring of commonplace elements formed a quest to ’establish a profound link between consciousness and the external world.’
  2. Heavily influenced by Freudian psychology, Surrealism represented a reaction against the oppressive "Rationalism" that some believed led Europe into the horrors of World War I. It attempted to join the realm of dreams to the everyday world. Surrealists often juxtaposed seemingly unrelated objects to suggest cryptic meanings and otherworldliness. Magritte did too, rendering in meticulous detail, recognizable scenes and objects taken out of their natural context, distorted and combined in fantastic ways as they might appear in dreams.
  3. From the 1920s onwards, Magritte made a series of word-image paintings that interrogated conventions of language and visual representation, using methods that included the misnaming of objects, doubling and repetition, mirroring and concealment, and the depiction of visions seen in half-waking states. Magritte's treatises on the impossibility of reconciling words, images, and objects, cast doubts on the nature of appearances, both in paintings and in reality itself.
  4. The Treachery of images [This is not a pipe] is one of the most iconic images of Surrealism. It challenges the linguistic convention of identifying an image of something as the thing itself, as well as the illusionistic history of Western art. The tension between the symbols of a pipe create a playful questioning as to what has more power to represent, language or image? 
  5. Magritte’s successful career in advertising [he ran an agency, Studio Dongo, with his brother] helped to hone his idea of how to make an image stick. This work's realistic style and perfectly written script of the caption recall advertising but subvert the clarity of advertising with paradoxical messages.
  6. His exploration of how we "read" visual images as part of a code, or system of signs and his inquiries into perception, coincided with the linguistic and philosophical investigations of semiotics.
  7. Called the invisible man of the Surrealists, he maintained a low-key personality and withdrew from Paris to Brussels, therefore his paintings did not initially receive much attention.  Magritte's use of text in his word-image paintings influenced a younger generation of conceptually oriented Pop artists, including Jasper Johns, Roy Lichtenstein, Robert Rauschenberg, Edward Ruscha, and Andy Warhol, who appreciated his capacity for irony, uncanny invention, and deadpan realism.
  8. Many of his works became icons for big business; this work was appropriated for a series of Allianz insurance ads.
Imogen Cunningham, Two Callas, 1929

Straight Photography
  1.  American photographer known for her botanical photography, nudes, and industrial landscapes. Cunningham was a member of the California-based Group f/64, known for its dedication to the sharp-focus rendition of simple subjects
  2. Rather than attempting to manipulate the photograph to capture aesthetic effects of paintings, Cunningham sought the abstract qualities that occur within nature. She was part of the Western school of photography that captured images of the west and were nature-oriented. (Strand, Cunningham, Adams, Weston).
  3. Whereas Weston and Adams viewed nature from a distance, Cunningham looked at it closely, as in images like Two Callas, capturing abstract qualities with close-up views of plants and flowers.
  4. The view suggests an affinity for the sensuous floral paintings of Georgia O'Keeffe. She helped found Group f.64 - a loosely knit group devoted to 'straight' photography as an art form that was led by Weston and the name refers to the f-stop on the camera that allows for images of great detail.
  5. Part of a series of sharply detailed studies of plant life and other natural forms. This image conveys a sensuous delight in nature, as opposed to narrative or sentimental content. Some anthropomorphic treatment of natural imagery.
  6. Shading accentuates grainy details. Emphasis on on photographic resolution. Composition uses rule of thirds; image is balanced through dual composition.
  7. Dark edges of photo act as effective frame. Interest in depicting objects in their unadulterated states.

Tina Modotti, Number 29: Hands of Marionette Player, 1929
The Museum of Modern Art, New York

Modernist Photography / Revolutionary Photography (?)
  1. Modotti was an expat (b. Italy, 1896), who moved to Mexico in 1923. With her came her longtime lover, photographer Edward Weston.
  2. Modotti and Weston opened a portrait studio in Mexico City. Along with others, they helped to shift the conception of photography in Mexico City from public heritage-oriented mechanical practice to artistic practice.
  3. Modotti’s practice was defined by attention to the nuance of shadow, dramatic light and shade, contrast of texture, and the creation of a sinuous tension. Many of her works were printed full bleed (like Weston, she believed that a carefully considered composition and good printing were the foundations of a true photograph). 
  4. In 1925, Weston left Mexico, and Modotti’s practice became increasingly politically engaged. Modotti joined the communist party in 1927, and associated with artist-reformers and intellectuals like Sergei Eisenstein, Frida Kahlo, Leon Trotsky, and Diego Rivera.
  5. In 1929, Modotti met Louis Bunin, a Russian-born painter and puppeteer who had come to Mexico to be an apprentice to Riviera, and began to collaborate with him on a series of photographs, including this gelatin silver print, perhaps the best-known of the series.  
  6. Puppetry performed in public was sometimes conceived as a form which brought together people from a variety of social classes. The image can be read as a political metaphor, perhaps indicating Modotti’s waning faith in the possibilities of overturning the capitalist class structure through communism: the hands wield power, pulling the strings from above of those below. In 1929, the promise of peasant reform and autonomy for the working classes seemed distant amid the reported re-emerging right-wing government and evidence of the growing exploitation of the ethnic and working classes. 
(Not so) Fun fact: This reproduction is flipped and cropped: I assume that the original slide was scanned backwards and didn’t reproduce the work in full for some reason. This is particularly infuriating because Modotti placed a strong emphasis on using the camera to frame the image precisely (hence why she printed full bleed - a real photographic flex). The original can be found here: https://www.moma.org/collection/works/51458

Fun fact 2: Pablo Neruda, a friend of Modotti’s, composed her epitaph. (She died in 1942 on her way home from a dinner at his house).

Arshile Gorky, The Artist and His Mother, c. 1929­‐36
National Gallery of Art, Washington, D. C.

Proto-Abstract-Expressionism / early Picasso-esque (?)
1. Gorky constitutes a critical link between European Surrealism and American Abstract Expressionism. Armenian-born, Gorky arrived in the United States in 1920, a refugee from the Turkish genocide against the Armenians (1914-1923), which gave him firsthand experience of the brutality of militarized, nationalist regimes. His work often addresses these experiences, either literally or metaphorically.
2. While in his later career (in the 40s) Gorky turned to a mature style of expressive biomorphic imagery, The Artist is an example of his early distinctive figural mode. Though rendered with semiabstract shapes that indelibly mark it as modern, the painting draws on visual precedents from Armenian, Egyptian, and medieval memorial portraiture as well as from portraits by Cézanne and Picasso (i.e. loose and dry brushwork, structuring of the composition through broad areas of color rather than lines).
3. It is a haunting portrait based on an old family photograph in which the artist posed beside his mother, well before she died of starvation in his arms when he was 14. Gorky, however, did not simply copy the photograph, but painted a meditation on remembrance: the white apron worn by Gorky’s mother makes her appear statue-like. Her chalky complexion and expressionless gaze, framed by the halo-like headscarf, suggest that she inhabits an idealized, eternal realm, while the boy’s evident brushwork and deep-set eyes situate him in the land of the living.
4. Gorky’s life ended as tragically as it had begun: a devastating studio fire destroyed more than 20 paintings and scores of drawings was quickly followed by a painful operation for cancer, a debilitating car accident, and the disintegration of his marriage. He hanged himself in his studio in 1948, just as his fellow Abstract Expressionists, whose work was indebted to his (i.e. De Kooning), were gaining momentum in New York.
5.   Gorky does not paint his mothers hand, leaving unfinished the feature through which tactile presence and comfort are given. Significant as this is a post-mortem portrait of mourning.
Alvar Aalto, Paimio Sanatorium, Finland, 1929­‐33

Functionalism?
  1. Aalto’s architectural approach is characterized by an awareness of the human form. He used materials that are warm to creating welcoming, individualized spaces harmonized with human scale. His structures are conscious of their site, seeming to grow out of it. His was a creative rather than reactionary response against the machine aesthetic.
  2. Aalto was influenced by Taylorism (Scientific Management method developed by Frederick Winslow Taylor a reformer who introduced rational work methods) which had been applied to architecture by Gropius and le Corbusier. This demand for rationalism laid the groundwork for functionalism.
  3. The Paimio Sanatorium was originally a tuberculosis sanatorium, and later became a general hospital. With the principles of functionalism in mind, Aalto sought in his design to make the building itself a contributor to the healing process, describing the building as a “medical instrument.”
    1. Particular attention was paid to the design of the patient bedrooms to ensure maximum comfort and privacy in shared room. Aalto designed “silent basins” that meant one patient could bathe while not disturbing their roommate
    2. Because at the time clean air and sunshine were seen as the only cures of TB, Aalto designed each floor to have a sunning balcony where weak patients could be pulled in their beds.
    3. He designed communal facilities, chapel, staff housing, promenade routes with the understanding that patients typically spent several years at the sanatorium.
    4. Soothing non-glare colors used throughout the building according to a special color scheme designed with the help of artist Eino Kauria
    5. He ensured that all surfaces were able to be easily cleaned so as to limit the spread through bacteria – no sharp edges, unnecessary ornament, or shelves that gathered dust.
László Moholy‐Nagy, Light­‐Space Modulator, 1930

Kinetic sculpture
1.     Moholy-Nagy was an important educate and advocate for Constructivism, functional design, and experimental photography. By 1921, his interests had begun to focus on elements that dominated his creative expression for the rest of his life– light, space and motion. Then on, he explored transparent materials, the possibilities of abstract photography and cinema.
2.     Beginning in 1922, he pioneered the creation of light and motion machines built from reflecting metals and transparent plastic. The first of these kinetic, motor-driven constructions which he names “light-space modulators” went into production only in 1930 when it was financed by an electric company in Berlin. 
3.     Powered by an electric motor, the work consists of a large circular based supporting the various moving components, a number of metal rectangles which move in an irregular fashion, a glass spiral which rotates to create the illusion of light. Central to the mesmeric effects are the 130 light bulbs which shine through  different sections to create complex patterns of light and shadow on the surrounding surfaces. 
4.     It was never intended to be a unique art object. Produced in collaboration with the German electronics company AEG, it was intended for commercial use in theaters and festivals. 
5.     In 1930s, Moholy-Nagy created a film showcasing the capacities of the machine, Light Play Black-White-Grey. The film captures the reflections and shadows created by the sculpture, and gives the impression of a whirring machine, a factory pumping out futuristic products, and an urban landscape.
6.     It embodied the principles of his 1922 “Manifesto on the System of Dynamico-Constructivist forms.” It represents an extension of Constructivist abstraction and stands at the forefront of subsequent developments in Kinetic art. It sums up his utopian vision for a total work of art that would transcend all media, approaching the complexity of living, biological form.

Charles Sheeler, American Landscape, 1930
Museum of Modern Art, New York

Precisionism
  1. Sheeler was an American painter and commercial photographer. He is recognized as one of the founders of American modernism, developing a "quasi-photographic" style of painting known as Precisionism, and as a quiet master of photography, whose visual “stamp” translated across subject matter, media, and different commissions.
  2. In late 1927-1928, Sheeler spent six weeks documenting the Ford Motor Company’s factory in River Rouge, Michigan, as part of a promotional campaign for the release of the Model A. Sheeler’s thirty-two photographs of the Ford plant depict acres of gleaming, massive machinery, rather than the human process of labor. They celebrate the company’s—and, by association, America’s—ideals of power and productivity, although there is also a strangely forbidding atmosphere to the unpopulated scenes.
  3. These photographs served as sources for later works in other media, like this painting. In addition to providing a quintessential subject of the American industrial age, the River Rouge project allowed Sheeler to consider further the relationship between the exactitude of photography and the layered, re-created perceptions of painting or drawing.
  4. By cropping the photographic image, Sheeler could be highly selective in his record of the details provided by reality, thus creating arbitrary patterns of light and shadow and flat color that transform themselves into abstract relationships.
  5. While these works experiment with arrangements of hard–edged forms and shifting planes, they also make clear how innovative American industry was during these years, how it was generating a radically new American landscape and experience.
  6. The artists who came to be known as the Precisionists never formally organized as a group or issued a manifesto; rather, they were associated through their common style and subjects. Around 1920, several artists began experimenting with a highly controlled approach to technique and form. They consistently reduced their compositions to simple shapes and underlying geometrical structures, with clear outlines, minimal detail, and smooth handling of surfaces. Their works also showed the influence of recent work by American photographers, who were utilizing sharp focus and lighting, unexpected viewpoints and cropping, and emphasis on the abstract form of the subject.
  7. Much of Sheeler's work was a celebration of the modern industrial age, with majestic views of factories, power plants, and machines. Sheeler left behind a body of work that explored the balance between abstraction and representation, photography and painting, an increasingly mechanized present and a more homespun past, uniting all these aspects in a skillful, and occasionally ambivalent, tension.

Grant Wood, American Gothic, 1930
Art Institute of Chicago

Regionalism
  1. Wood was an American painter best known for his paintings depicting the rural American Midwest, particularly American Gothic, which has become an iconic painting of the 20th century. American Regionalist painter, specializing in Midwestern subject matter. Born in Iowa in the late 19th century, Wood studied art in Europe in the 1920s, first in Paris then in Munich.
  2. In Munich, he discovered fifteenth-century Flemish and German painting, the rigid, highly-detailed style of which would influence his American-themed painting upon his return to Iowa. Flemish masters as Jan van Eyck and Rogier van der Weyden influenced him, especially their meticulous rendering of detail.
  3.  Wood was a socialist and although considered politically radical, his art like American Gothic labeled him a rightwing conservative. Other critics saw it as praising the purely American spirit in the face of the 'insanity' of the modern Cubist and Fauvist movements.
  4. In the image, Wood's sister and his dentist are models and shown in front of a 19th c. 'Carpenter Gothic' house. The composition shows the backbone of rural Midwestern America. The Carpenter Gothic style of the house symbolizes that religion played an important role in their lives.
  5. Both Heroic and Humorous, an homage to the plain folk of the Midwest who preferred matter-of-fact realism. Not interested in depicting modernity or contemporary national concerns, like the Dust Bowl, Grant focused on depicting midwestern traditions and culture.
  6. The painting won Wood $300 in a contest, bringing him immediate fame as well as widespread recognition to the painting. Much of the public thought the painting was intended as a satire of the Puritanical American couple, but Wood maintained that it was a work of affection. Sought to portray a type that he perceived to be the backbone of rural Midwestern America. 
  7. The Regionalist school of painting developed in the Midwest. Regionalists worked in a naturalistic tradition influenced by abstraction. Foremost among these artists were Benton, Curry, and Wood. Just as Urban Scene painters depicted city life, Regionalist artists found their subject matter in the Midwest farm, creating a heroic vision in the midst of a national depression.
Piet Mondrian, Composition with Red, Blue, and Yellow, 1930

Neo-Plasticism
  1. Piet Mondrian (1872-1944) called his style Neo-Plasticism or “The New Plastic Painting,” after the title of his 1917 essay promoting abstraction for the expression of modern life. This essay attempted to define the aims of the De Stijl (The Style) movement, which Mondrian founded in Holland with with Theo van Doesburg. De Stijl sought to combine art and living space, ultimately resulting in a total environment. Although the two parted ways and Mondrian lived in Paris beginning in 1919, Mondrian continued to pursue Neo-Plasticism in his paintings.
  2. Mondrian believed in the dynamic opposition and balance between the dual forces of matter and spirit, theories that likely grew out of his exposure to Theosophy (which believed that opposites were the expression of a hidden unity) and Hegel’s theories of the dialectical progress of art and civilization. 
  3. Mondrian claimed the particular to be associated with a Romantic, subjective appeal. He sought instead to paint using a universal means of expression: an asymmetrical, dynamic equilibrium of a vertical and horizontal structure rendered through black, white, and primary hues. 
  4. Mondrian viewed the black lines in his paintings from this time not as outlines but rather as planes of pigment in their own right; an idea seen in the horizontal black plane on the lower right of the painting that stops just short of the canvas edge (at top edge of the yellow rectangle). The black areas functioned as a counterpoint to the fields of color. 
  5. In Composition, the red field is often described as being balanced by the fields of black, white, blue, and yellow.
  6. Mondrian made several variations on the square format beginning in the late 1920s, including Composition. These paintings refused to be read as portraits or landscapes in the customary visual language of canvas orientation, furthering his push towards a universal language of abstraction. 
  7. Mondrian once told a collector that his paintings with more red were “more real” and those with little or no color were “more spiritual.” 
  8. Mondrian typically prefered to paint on a horizontal surface; he used his easel for display.
  9. Even after his break with van Doesberg, Mondrian’s living and working spaces evidenced his ongoing interest in the spatialization of the concepts of dynamic balance and opposition that explored in his paintings. The spare, white walls in his studio were punctuated by colored squares and rectangles.
Salvador Dalí, The Persistence of Memory, 1931

Surrealism
1. Of Catalan origins, Dalí received an academic training in Madrid where he was influenced by Millet, Böcklin and Meissonnier, Picasso, de Chirico. Met the Surrealists in 1929 through his friend Miró. By 1930 Dalí had left behind De Chirico’s metaphysical landscape for his own world of violence, blood, and decay. Emigrated to US in 1940.
2. Influenced by his readings of Freud, Dalí referred to his paintings as “hand-painted dream photographs”. He saw his art as a specific documentation of Freudian theories applied to his own inner world.
3. Developed his signature paranoiac-critical method = “spontaneous method of irrational knowledge based upon the interpretative-critical association of delirious phenomena” (or: the creation of a visionary reality from dreams and visions through free association); a method to systematize confusion and help discredit completely the world of reality
4. Persistence employs a miniaturist technique which goes back to 15th century Flemish art (painting is only a foot wide); renders his fantastic visions with meticulous verisimilitude, giving them a credible appearance; space is as infinite as Tanguy’s (compare Mama, Papa is Wounded! 1927)
5. Dalí was obsessed with the morphology of hard and soft. Persistence shows watches in unusual context, scale and attributes; large head in profile devoid of bone structure (apparently resembling his own face); hard objects become limp, time bends, metal attracts ants like rotting flesh
6. Described the scene as a “soft, extravagant, solitary paranoiac-critical Camembert cheese of space and time” (supposedly painted after watching the Camembert melt after a dinner party); pictorial metamorphosis (objects transformed from one state into another) is central to Surrealism.
Kurt Schwitters, Hanover Merzbau, Photo c. 1931 (destroyed)

German Dada
Assemblage
  1. Schwitters conceived of the Merzbau space as specifically ritualistic in its achievement of a Gesamtkunstwerk in which all the senses would be unified in an overall intensified form of visual, cognitive and somatic interaction with the objects and structures of the room.
  2. The word bau carried connotations of an animal burrow (original meaning of Bau) to the Bauhaus invocation of the structure of the collective, even inserting into the various layers of the structure bodily materials such as hair, and bottles of urine from his friends. In doing this he fabricated a non-rational, nonarchival, noninstitutional space. In contrast to the functionalism of the Bauhaus, he proposed a space of total inefficiency and dysfunction a refusal of all the tenets of Bauhaus functionalist design.
  3. He began the Merzbau in Hanover around 1920 as an abstract plaster sculpture with apertures dedicated to his Dadaist and Constructivist friends and containing objects commemorating them. It grew throughout the 1920s with successive accretions until it filled the room, and grew upwards into a second story. The structure took over 8 rooms by the time it was destroyed when Schwitters was driven from Germany by the Nazis
  4. The space was constantly in flux, growing and evolving, almost like an organic growth.
  5. The work transformed the viewer into a participant, as they navigated the work physically with all senses activated. This phenomenological approach would gain particular momentum 20 years later with Happening environments, and later installation art.

Ben Shahn, The Passion of Sacco and Vanzetti, 1931­‐32
Whitney Museum of American Art, New York

Social Realism
1.     Social realist painter who immigrated to New York from Lithuania. His work as an artist was inextricably tied to his social activism. His  paintings, murals and posters addressed fascism, social injustice and the hardships endured by the poor working class. His works are often critical of American life, but by exposing social problems, Shahn hoped to inspire reform.
2.     The subject of this painting was prompted by the arrest, trial and execution of Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti, who were accused of murdering two men during an armed robbery in 1920. The pair’s conviction was met with widespread opposition, believed to  have been convicted because of their political sympathies. At the time, many laborers, artists and intellectuals embraced leftist or socialist ideas and Sacco and Vanzetti were seen as symbols of the government’s suppression of political opposition.
3.     Shahn followed the case closely and participated in protests in support of their release. He made 23 images about the subject, based on photographs that appeared  in newspapers. These paintings were bitter denunciations of the American legal system, which had condemned them to death despite official doubts about their guilt. 
4.     In this image, Sacco and Vanzetti lie in coffins in the foreground in front of a colonnaded neoclassical courthouse. On the porch behind them hangs a portrait of the trial judge Webster Thayer. Towering over the bodies are the members of the committee that reviewed their convictions. Shahn’s portraits are embedded in irony– Thayer raises his right hand as if taking an oath of justice, but faces a lamppost  that resembles the bundle of sticks known as fasces, a symbol for Italian fascism and oppression in the 1920s.
5.     The  title of the work draws a connection to Christian martyrdom (Passion of Christ). Shahn also painted in tempera, a matte medium used by Italian Renaissance artists for Christian panel paintings. His composition invokes the images of the Lamentation of Christ but the expressions of the Committee members reveal a placid resolve rather than sorrow.
Alberto Giacometti, Woman with her Throat Cut (Femme égorgée), 1932

Surrealism
  1. Giacometti was a Swiss sculptor and painter, best known for his sculptures of solitary, lanky figures made after WWII. His work has been compared to that of the existentialists in literature.
  2. This sculpture is from an earlier phase in the early 1930s when he associated with the Surrealists, for whom metamorphosis, sexual duality, irrationality and shock had far-reaching philosophical and social implications.
  3. Part woman, part crustacean, and part insect, Woman with Her Throat Cut is rigorously horizontal. Designed to be placed on the floor without a base and looked at from above, it suggests a crime scene or a potential man-trap into which the unwary viewer might stumble. This was a stunning solution to the problem of the base and a rebuke to the tradition of vertical, monolithic sculpture.
  4. The dark side of surrealist desire is represented in this powerful image of sexual pleasure and violence, despite the abstract nature of the work. The body, which includes the spoon shape of a female torso, a spiky rib cage and backbone, is splayed open, disemboweled, as if simultaneously in the throes of sexual ecstasy and the spasms of death—embodying the phrase petite mort (little death), a French term for orgasm. Arched in a paroxysm of sex and death, the work suggests the image of a woman raped and murdered and is a disturbing example of the misogynistic imagery frequently present in Surrealism.
  5. The thin stomach and bulbous breasts recall the praying mantis, an insect revered by the Surrealists because of the tendency of the female to devour the male during or after the sexual act.
  6. The fatal wound on the figure's phallic neck makes clear the Freudian displacement of castration fears onto the female body.
  7. The sense of metamorphosis is overwhelming. The right foot turns into a combination pine tree and shell. One arm ends in a giant spoon-like hand or claw, the other flails over the exposed neck in a mobile pod-like form that Giacometti mounted on a swivel mechanism so that it could be positioned at different angles.
  8. The work's fetishistic quality is enhanced by its portability. Roughly 3 feet long and 9 inches high, it has been likened to Gregor Samsa's size in Kafka's ''Metamorphosis.''
  9. Numerous sources of inspiration have been suggested, ranging from the artist’s nightmares to a short story about the serial killer Jack the Ripper written by his friend, the Surrealist poet, Robert Desnos.
  10. It reflects Giacometti's ongoing dialogue with Picasso and Matisse; the stomach and breasts suggest Matisse's sculpture The Serpentine (1909) and the forms bear a resemblance to Picasso's Seated Bather (1930).
  11. Its sculptural imagination is matched by its formal mastery. There is an equilibrium between sharp points and flowing rhythms, concave and convex, closed and open, that creates a sense of rocking, whereby the figure seems to be both stretching and contracting.
  12. He created the plaster model in 1932 and it was later cast in five bronze versions between 1940 and 1949. The original plaster, documented in photographs by Brassai, was destroyed in the casting process.
Raymond Hood, RCA Building, Rockefeller Center, New York, 1932

American Streamline Moderne
  1. The Radio Corporation of America (RCA) skyscraper is the centerpiece of several skyscrapers constituting Rockefeller Center.
  2. Form shaped by the economic context of the Depression (John D. Rockefeller initially intended Rockefeller Center as a large open square, surrounded by office towers and a new home for the Metropolitan Opera that would be more fashionable than its original Broadway location)
  3. The building's cascading setbacks cater to the restricted real estate market of the time, ensuring that daylight would filter in (the Center's project manager had told Hood that gloomy office space would prove impossible to rent)
  4. Form also reflects break away from the imported style of Art Deco and replacement with the specifically American Streamline Moderne (Hood was committed to the development of a particularly American modernist language of forms)
  5. Art Deco replaced by this simpler and more economical style. In contrast to the ideologically exclusive Art Deco, which had relied on custom handicraft, Streamline Moderne was stripped of ornament. RCA building itself also largely stripped of ornamentation (the Chrysler's Art Deco aesthetics now passé) simple façade, clad with white Indiana limestone, decoration reduced to dark aluminum spandrels connecting one floor's windows to the next
  6. Stepped form gives a "flavour" of Art Deco- American Streamline Moderne was an international style of Art Deco architecture and design that emerged in the 1930s. It was inspired by aerodynamic design. Streamline architecture emphasized curving forms, long horizontal lines, and sometimes nautical elements. In industrial design, it was used in railroad locomotives, telephones, toasters, buses, appliances, and other devices to give the impression of sleekness and modernity
Side note: Rivera fresco mural for the lobby of the RCA, destroyed in 1934 because it contained a portrait of Lenin. Rivera controversy reinforced the fact that the Rockefeller Center was, first and foremost, an international symbol of capitalism.

Diego Rivera, Detroit Industry, 1932‐33
Detroit Institute of the Arts (fresco, North wall)

Mexican Muralism 
  1. Rivera believed in the politically transformative power of a social art movement, along with David Alfaro Siqueiros and José Clemente Orozco. This group of muralists drew on Mexico’s precolonial past, and in 1924, signed a declaration repudiating easel painting as an aristocratic, colonial form. They favored “monumental art in all its forms, because it is public property...art must no longer be the expression of individual satisfaction, which it is today, but should aim to become a fighting, educative art for all.” To this end, the muralists often depicted the lives and history of the proletariat in their work. 
  2. Rivera, Siqueiros and Orozco became known in the US in the 1920s. The first English-language book about Rivera’s work was published in 1929, and he was awarded the second-ever retrospective at MoMA in 1931 (Matisse had the first, earlier that year.)
  3. Detroit was a leading industrial center on a global scale, but was also the city hit hardest by the Great Depression: industrial production and the workforce were a third of what they had been before the 1929 Crash. Rivera arrived days after an infamous Hunger March where thousands of unemployed workers walked from downtown Detroit to the gates of the Ford Motor Company River Rouge plant to demand employment. Armed Ford security guards met them, panicked, shot into the marchers and killed six people. This confrontation became known as the Battle of the Overpass. 
  4. In his mural at the DIA, Rivera chose to depict the evolution of technology. He captured the manufacture of the 1932 Ford V-8 at the Ford Motor Company’s River Rouge factory in the large lower panels on the north and south walls. He explained, “the steel industry itself has tremendous plastic beauty,...it is as beautiful as the early Aztec or Mayan sculptures.” The assembly of the motor is depicted on the bottom half of the North wall. Like a Renaissance fresco (a form that influenced Rivera and others), the bottom panel on the North wall shows consecutive events in a single composition: the major processes related to the manufacture of the motor of the car (from mold-making in the upper left to the final assembly of the motor on the assembly line in the foreground) are accurately and precisely rendered. 
  5. On the upper panels of the north and south walls, Rivera painted gigantic red, black, yellow and white figures symbolic of the diverse workforce. Each is symbolically associated with one of the raw materials that form the basis for the automobile industry—iron ore, coal/diamonds, sand and limestone. The red figure (top left) is paired with iron ore (depicted below it), and the black figure (top right) with coal and diamonds. 
  6. Rivero’s work and that of his fellow muralists above was an important influence on American Regionalists including Thomas Hart Benton and social realists including Ben Sahn. 
Fun fact: The upper-right hand panel depicts a child being vaccinated, and is based on nativity scenes: Rivera thought that medicine would be the savior of modern man. It caused an uproar - the Detroit City Council even considered a vote to whitewash them. Early anti-vaxxers! If you’re curious, the Khan Academy link below has the whole (fascinating) story.

José Orozco, The Epic of American Civilization: Modern Migration of the Spirit, 1932‐34
Dartmouth College

Mexican Muralism
1. After the armed revolution of the 1910s, Mexican artists turned to their own history and artistic heritage, contributing to a veritable renaissance of Mexican painting, and specifically, mural painting.
