But he castigated this as "extract art," having nothing to do with real abstraction, which, he said, "cannot be 'used' in education, communication, perception, foreign relations, etc." It was for this reason that Reinhardt truly wanted a "new academy," which would function like those of the seventeenth century: protecting a notion of aesthetic purity and maintaining the difference between high art and its applied derivatives. Such an academy would make clear, he said, that art is essentially "'out of time,' art made fine, art emptied and purified of all other- than-art meanings."
  2. His own attempt to purify abstraction took the form of marrying the two major paradigms of abstraction: the grid and the monochrome. In the black paintings, Reinhardt approaches the unbroken surface of monochrome painting, which eliminates the possibility of distinguishing any figure from ground.
  3. Within the monochrome surface, one can eventually make out a barely perceptible grid, created by strokes of a slightly different shade of black. In pairing the monochrome with the grid, he guarantees the self-referentiality of the work – they describe nothing but the surface of the work itself (similar to Stella’s positivism)
  4. Reinhardt like many abstract artists sought a timelessness in his work. There was a sense of a progression toward the ultimate, or purist version of painting in abstraction, the creation of the “last work of its time,” that propelled Mondrian, for example to an ever purer sublation of oppositions. With the Black paintings Reinhardt said: "I'm merely making the last paintings which anyone can make."  (lol)
  5. Although Reinhardt applied his colors with brushes, he did so without leaving the slightest trace of his implement on the surface. His stated purpose was the elimination of all associations, all extraneous elements, all symbols and signs, and the refinement of paintings to a single dominant experience.
Asger Jorn, L’avant‐garde se rend pas (The Avant‐Garde Doesn’t Give Up), 1962

1.     Between 1959 and 1962, Asger Jorn created a series of modified works by painting on top of old, kitschy paintings and reproductions he had found in flea markets. This image is part of a set of modifications that Jorn produced in 1962, called “new disfigurations.” These were mostly portraits of proper subjects disfigured by childish doodles or deranged doubles. 
2.     For some critics, the “modifications” crack open traditional genres that have become academic kitsch in order to make them live again as contemporary signs. In doing so, they overcome, symbolically at least, the split between avant-garde and kitsch that long deformed modern culture.
3.     The original painting depicts a young girl in a white confirmation dress. She is clutching a skipping rope and fixing the audience in her gaze with a smile. Jorn embellished this picture, an amateur version of a classical 19th century academic portrait, by painting a moustache and a goatee on the girl’s face and scrawling the words ‘L’avant-garde se rend pas’ across the black background. 
4.      ‘L’avant-garde se rend pas’ has been interpreted as a paraphrase on Marcel Duchamp’s work L.H.O.O.Q in which he added a moustache and goatee to a reproduction of the Mona Lisa. The disfiguration of the painting indicates that the bourgeois conception of art and artistic genius has become outdated, that the drawing of a mustache on the Mona Lisa is no more interesting than the original version of the painting.
5.     In a statement accompanying his show on modifications in 1959, Jorn writes, “Painting is over. You might as well finish it off.” One can read the disfiguration as an admission of the pathetic status of bourgeois art– that the avant-garde should give up.
Tony Smith, Die, 1962

Minimalism

  1. Smith was a Minimalist artist and architect best known for his large-scale modular sculptures, among Minimalism’s most iconic forms. He developed his style by exploring issues of scale, material, and the geometry of nature in studio prototypes for fabricated sculptures.
  2. Die was one of his first steel sculptures and the inspiration for much of his later work. He made a six-inch cardboard model in black in 1962, but did not have it fabricated until 1968. To have it made, Smith telephoned and ordered it from the Industrial Welding Company in Newark, whose sign, "You specify it; we fabricate it," had caught his eye.
  3. The specifications were: "a six-foot cube of quarter-inch hot-rolled steel with diagonal internal bracing." The dimensions were determined by the proportions of the human body. The form was inspired by da Vinci’s drawing of the Vitruvian Man, which shows the ideal proportions of the human figure set within the perfect geometry of a circle and a square.
  4. Hollow and raised off the floor so that all twelve edges are visible, the sculpture is experienced sequentially, one or two sides at a time. Die’s volume suggests the form of a grave (size is 6x6, connotations of '6 feet under'). He explained that a larger scale would have endowed Die with the stature of a "monument," while a smaller one would have reduced it to a mere "object." This simple yet profound observation about scale placed Die at the center of artistic debates.
  5. Rich in allusions, the title invites multiple associations: it alludes to die casting (a method of fabrication used by Smith), to one of a pair of dice, and ultimately, death. Meaning becomes relative, generated through the interplay of word and object.
  6. Weaving together strains of architecture, industrial manufacture, and the found object, Smith radically transformed the way sculpture could look, how it could be made, and understood. The form, materials, and impersonal surfaces relate to Smith’s architectural background and to minimalist art of the mid-1960s. However, he bridged two generations as he also embraced the heroic and humanistic attitudes associated with abstract expressionist art. 
  7. His work was included in the genre-defining “Primary Structures” exhibition at the Jewish Museum in 1966.
Robert Watts, Robert Watts Events (Fluxus Edition), 1963

Fluxus

  1. Robert Watts was an experimental artist and founding member of Fluxus, an international network of anti-establishment artists who embraced the banal, heralded the unconventional, challenged authority, and rejected the distinction between high and low art.
  2. Fluxus resisted transformations of life into art, believing that the two were already inseparable. Performance pieces served best to demonstrate the commingling of life and art, and Fluxus members staged various events ranging from Fluxus festivals
  3. The highly diverse projects of the group's members helped bring about the most crucial change by shifting artistic production from the register of the object to registers operating somewhere between theatricality and musicality.
  4. When Robert Watts retrospectively defined the "Yam Festival"—a year-long festival planned for 1962-3, during which one performance or event was to be delivered each day—his description echoed Duchamp's statement almost exactly: "a loose format that would make it possible to combine or include an ever expanding universe of events.”
  5. Simulating "institutional" and "commercial" frames of presentation and distribution
Gerhard Richter, Atlas, panel no.11, 1963

Capitalist Realism*
  1. Gerhard Richter began his career painting murals in East Germany. He crossed over to the West in 1961; in 1962-3 he was in Düsseldorf with Sigmar Polke, where he learned from Joseph Beuys, Fluxus, and American Pop artists’ exhibitions. 
  2. David Hickey argues that “painting changed after the advent of photography not because photography usurped its descriptive function, but because photography prioritized it, thus valorizing the referent over what it signified.” For Richter, however - catalyzed by the anti-art movements of the 1960s including Fluxus - “I had had enough of bloody painting, and painting from a photograph seemed to me most moronic and inartistic thing one could do.” His work does not so much replicate the exact content of individual photographs as it does seek to replicate photographic effects - photographic visuality.
  3. Richter's Atlas is an ongoing, monumental work. In 1964, Richter began amassing onto panels photographs that he had collected over the previous few years--sometimes as possible source materials for his paintings and sometimes on their own account. The panel shown here is from this early initial collection, likely mostly gathered while he was in Düsseldorf. Richter’s collection of amateur and newspaper photos soon expanded to include portraits, pornography, and Richter’s own sketches, project plans and proposals, and photos. 
  4. Atlas was first exhibited in 1972 at the Museum voor Hedendaagse Kunst in Utrecht under the title Atlas der Fotos und Skizzen. At the time it included 315 parts. As of 1995, when it was exhibited at Dia, Atlas was composed of approximately 4,000 photographs, reproductions, or details of photographs and drawings, grouped together on 583 separate panels. It is typically installed in a way that is loosely chronological, but responds to site and changes over time. 
  5. As time went on, Richter began to institute an internal logic, with larger rhythms and references among the part, as well as a more rigidly gridded layout. The Atlas has gained an increasingly encyclopedic character, albeit one peculiar to the artist.
  6. Atlas recalls the unruly internal logic of Aby Warburg’s Mnemosyne Atlas, which attempted to trace archetypal symbols on a cross-cultural, global scale. 
NB: I have no idea why this is the particular panel we’re looking at, but assume it’s meant to stand in for the whole.

Roy Lichtenstein, Whaam!, 1963
Tate Gallery, London

American Pop Art
1. Beginning in the late 1950s, Lichtenstein took as his primary subject the most banal advertisements or comic strips (frequently representing violent action and sentimental romance) and enlarged them faithfully in his paintings, using limited, flat colors and hard, precise drawing. The resulting imagery documents, while it gently parodies, familiar images of modern America.
2. Whaam! is rendered in the formal tradition of machine-printed comic strips: thick black lines enclosing areas of primary color and lettering, with uniform areas of Ben-Day dots (purple for shading on the main fighter plane, blue for background of the sky).
3. Whaam! became a kind of history painting for the Pop generation: two-canvas, monumental scale (nearly 14 feet / 4 m across), dramatic subject (based on heroic images in the comics of World War II battles)
4. The choice of cartoon to represent military action also renders the scene ridiculous and juvenile. Although the intention of the original publication of the comic may have been to show glorious, action-filled images of ‘All-American Men of War’, through Lichtenstein’s quasi-absurdist treatment, the scene is turned into what art critic Alastair Sooke has described as ‘a tongue-in-cheek male daydream of aggression, conquest and ejaculatory release’.
5. Considering Whaam! was created just as the Vietnam War was gathering steam, and taking into account Lichtenstein’s own service in the US Army in 1943–6, this deconstruction of military heroism could be read as a statement on the folly of war.
6. Full of contradictory dualities: highly charged subject matter rendered in a dispassionate, detached style; commercial art in a fine art context; the mass-produced image painstakingly rendered by hand in a unique painting; the familiarity of the imagery and its alien application in scale and medium. Many of these dualities chime with ideas explored in the wider Pop Art movement by the likes of Andy Warhol and Claes Oldenburg.

Ed Ruscha, Standard Station, Amarillo, Texas, 1963
Hood Museum of Art, Dartmouth College

Pop Art
  1. In 1963 Ruscha published Twenty-six Gasoline Stations a book containing unremarkable photographs of the filling stations along route 66 between Oklahoma City (his birthplace) and LA. This painting is based on one of those images, transforming the mundane motif into a dramatically foreshortened composition, slicing the canvas diagonally, turning the sky black, and rendering the station a sleek, gleaming structure that recalls Precisionist paintings of the 1930s. In monumentalizing the gas station he turns it into a symbol of American vernacular landscape.
  2. Ruscha was trained as a commercial illustrator and in his move to “fine art” explained that he wanted “absolutely neutral material.” He said that “My pictures are not that interesting, nor the subject matter. They are simply a collection of ‘facts’; my book is more like a collection of readymades.”
  3. Ruscha was inspired by Johns’s flat, self-contained, objective, immediate paintings and responded with his own variety of word-image combinations in an attempt to explore “the idea of visual noise.” In this image, he plays with the word “Standard” in its typeface immediately referring to Standard Oil but also serving as a banner or rallying point and an established level of quality
  4. As Pop art sought to dehierarchize painting from other art forms, Ruscha, cross-pollinates painting with cinema, giving his colors a celluloid gloss, and creating spaces that are at once deep and airy, and flat and word-inscribed like a screen.
  5. Following this first painting, Ruscha continued to play with this image throughout the 1960s, rendering it through different printing techniques, e.g. overlapping the reverse image, exchanging colors, eradicating color, and even incorporating foodstuff into the ink. In this way the originally imagery becomes further detached from its place in the landscape, serving as a flat and immediately recognizable symbol, much like Jasper Johns’s Flags in their various iterations.
  6. While we would classify Ruscha under Pop Art for his elevation of mass culture to cross-pollinate with fine art, and interest in the vernacular, his early work anticipated Conceptual art of the 1970s in its interest in systems of information and semiotics.

Lucio Fontana, Spatial Concept: The End of God, 1963
Gallerie dell’Ariete, Milan

Spatialism

1.   As the son of an Italian commercial sculptor who emigrated to Argentina, Fontana was exposed to the epitome of kitsch: 19th century pompier sculpture. Kitsch was embedded in his works from the very beginning of his career: with him, the wall separating commercial kitsch from avant-garde art had become utterly porous.
2.   As a participant and witness to the carnage of the world wars, Fontana harnessed the existential dread of a battle-worn generation and slashed through his monochrome canvases starting in 1949. Fontana’s proposal is the abolition of illusory space and its substitution with real space, by piercing, or slashing canvas with a razor to create an actual dimension of space. He developed these principles in his concept of Spatialism, published in the Manifiesto Blanco (1946), and Manifiesto Spaziale (1947), which called for an art that embraced science and technology.
3.   From the start of the 1960s, he began a series of “Olii” (oils) on canvas, where the thick painting layer is perforated with holes or gashes. In a quest for iconographic renewal, he developed a series of paintings titled “the End of God,” a series of monochrome canvases, at times covered in sequins and cut through with holes or gashes. 
4.   In Fontana’s hands, oil paint, a material of pictorial art, becomes a repugnant past. The myriad holes that puncture his canvases highlight the materiality of the support. 
5.   The fake gems, diamond dust sparkles and acidic colors of the oval shaped canvases from the End of God series adds a playful twist to the kitsch– taking the forms of marvelling of the domains of postwar spectacle: television, fashion, commercial fairs and discotheque decors.
Robert Venturi, Vanna Venturi House, Chestnut Hill Philadelphia, 1963

Post-Modern
  1. Venturi was an anti-universalist American architect and theorist whose buildings and books proposed a course that led to postmodern architectural design, in which historic elements enliven contemporary forms.
  2. His book Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture (1966) was among the first to question the authority of modernism and the International Style. If Mies van der Rohe said, "Less is more," Venturi countered "less is a bore."
  3. An icon of post-modernism, this house was designed for his mother, Vanna Venturi, and constructed in Chestnut Hill in Philadelphia between 1962 and 1964. It is a manifesto of his beliefs regarding form and symbolism in architecture. It embraces awkwardness not rationality, as Venturi was against the idea that an architect could come up with the "perfect form," itself a flawed idea.
  4. He designed and redesigned the house for four years, using both references to historic architecture and vernacular prototypes as inspiration; the sloping roof and shape recall Shingle-style houses, like McKim, Mead and White's design for the William Low House in Bristol, RI (demolished in 1962); while the monumental street facade alludes to Michaelangelo's Porta Pia in Rome.
  5. The house was an open challenge to Modernist orthodoxy, displaying nonfunctional elements like the non-structural arch motif. He painted it coppery gray-green after reading Marcel Breuer’s advice never to paint a house green; the gable was a blow to the modernist flat roof; the square, asymmetric windows went against the aesthetic tyranny of transparent walls; while inside he played with ideas of scale and symmetry and a stairway that leads nowhere.
  6. Inspired by the idea of a house as shelter (not space), the façade echoes a childlike, simplistic idea of a house, acting as a billboard for what lies behind.
  7. Inspired by Pop artists, he embraced vernacular sources and praised America's pop culture, signs and symbols as a source of inspiration. 
  8. Venturi and Denise Scott Brown married in 1967 and partnered in the Venturi, Scott Brown and Associates architecture firm until they both retired in 2007 (the firm lives on as VSBA).  They accommodated their practice to each client's vision, embracing the plurality of American life and cultures.
Fun fact: An oversized fireplace competes for space at the center of the home, sticking up "like a middle finger" to modernism and symbolic of his self-definition as "the Dennis the Menace of architecture."
David Smith, Cubi XVIII, 1964, Cubi XVII, 1963, Cubi XIX, 1964

Constructed sculpture

  1. David Smith (1906–65), a pioneer sculptor of his generation working in welded steel, said of his medium: “The material called iron or steel I hold in high respect.… The metal itself possesses little art history. What associations it possesses are those of this century: power, structure, movement, progress, suspension, brutality.”
  2. During much of his career Smith worked on sculpture in series, with different sequences sometimes overlapping chronologically and individual sculptures within series varying widely in form.
  3. In contrast with most sculptors who used found objects in the 1960s, Smith integrated such objects in the whole structure so that their original function was subordinated to the totality of the new design.
  4. In his last monumental series, with the generic name of Cubi, Smith assembled monumental, geometric volumes in stainless steel. Always sensitive to the surfaces of his sculptures. 
  5. In the Cubi series he exercised particular care in polishing to create effects of brilliant, allover calligraphy out of the highly reflecting, light-saturated surfaces. 
  6. even the works of the Cubi series, with their machine-like precision, were constructed and finished by the artist.
  7. Despite this concern for the personal, his art was critical to the development of the more impersonal creations of Minimalist artists in the 1960s.
Allan Kaprow, Household, 1964

1960s Performance Art / Fluxus 
  1. Kaprow studied painting under Hans Hoffman, Abstract Expressionist painter, in the 1940s. He was less interested in the object, however, than in the process: the performative possibilities of painting. 
  2. Kaprow was inspired by Hans Nemuth’s 1951 photographs of Jackson Pollock painting. After Pollock died, Kaprow wrote in the essay “The Legacy of Jackson Pollock’ (1958): “We were a piece of him: he was perhaps, the embodiment of our ambition for complete freedom.” He suggested that the art to come was one that incorporated everyday life, and everyday objects.
  3. In 1957 Kaprow went on a mushroom hunt with artists, composers and founder members of the Fluxus group George Brecht and John Cage. Struggling with some of the sound elements in his own works (which he called action collages), Kaprow asked Cage’s advice. Cage invited him along to his composition class at the New School for Social Research in New York and, fascinated by what he heard about recording, editing and looping tape, Kaprow asked if he could attend regularly. Cage’s weekly homework was to create a piece of work and in response Kaprow began to create full-scale events that he called happenings.
  4. Kaprow chose the word happening to suggest “something spontaneous, something that just happens to happen.” Happenings incorporated chance and participation, and were actually very tightly planned. They unfolded according to a brief recurring catalogue of guidelines (or a ‘grammar”). His scores are composed only of loose words detached from a more complex poem and punctuation signs (brackets, dashes and full stops) or straightforward commands (“People shout in subway just before getting off, leave immediately”)
  5. The happening had its roots in Hugo Ball’s Dada Cabaret Voltaire, Surrealist performances and the Italian Futurists in the 1910s-30s. 
  6. This is Sol Goldberg's photograph of participants in Kaprow's “Women licking jam off a car,” from his 1964 happening Household. In it, Kaprow addressed the mise-en-scène of America’s daily lifestyle and consumerism. 
  7. Household was commissioned by Cornell University and presented May 3, 1964. The men in the group were told to go for the “smoking wreck” of a car which had been delivered a bit earlier in the Happening, roll it into the dump where the Happening was occuring, and cover it with strawberry jam while the women went into a nest that they had built of saplings and screeched. Later, as the women licked the jam, the men destroyed the nest, shouting and cursing. 
Fun fact: In Tokyo, Jikken Kobo (Experimental Workshop), a collective of visual artists, composers, photographers, musicians, designers, writers and others were experimenting with cross-discipline presentations around the same time. Working between 1951 and 1958, Jikken Kobo members mixed dance, poetry reading, music, painting displays and architecture. From 1952, they used the term happyōkai (literally a recital), for all their events, regardless of the traditional art forms the events included.

Romare Bearden, The Prevalence of Ritual: The Baptism, 1964
Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D.C.

American post-Harlem Renaissance photomontage
1. Bearden grew up in the thriving artistic milieu of the Harlem Renaissance and strove to create art based on his own cultural experiences; studied for a time with the German artist George Grosz at the Art Students League and was drawn to the artist’s reputation as a political satirist.
2. Bearden’s early work of the 40s coincides with Social Realist trends; his early paintings were often of scenes in the American South, and his style was strongly influenced by the Mexican muralists, especially Diego Rivera and José Clemente Orozco.
3. Experimented with AbEx in the 50s but struggled to express his experiences as a Black man through an abstract language; turned to more representational forms and found his distinctive visual language when he adopted collage and photomontage technique in the 60s. He first combined images cut from magazines and colored paper, which he would often further alter with the use of sandpaper, bleach, graphite or paint; enlarged these collages through the photostat process.
4. His images are taken from mainstream magazines such as Life and Look but also black magazines such as Ebony and Jet (in the contemporary Pop Art tradition, compare Hamilton Just what is it 1956).
5. At center of The Baptism shows at center is the one being baptized, his body constructed of brown-toned paper, his face partially covered by an African mask. Bearden admired the formal beauty and stylized forms of African masks and statuary and felt strongly connected to African art, especially during the 1960s when the civil rights and black pride movements engaged American society (compare Picasso Demoiselles 1907).
6. Bearden’s collage work also draws from a tradition of African American slave crafts, such as patch-work quilts, bound by the necessity of using whatever material is available (potential alternative genealogy of the history of collage).
7. In 1971 MoMA had a solo show of Bearden’s work in response to demands made by the Art Workers Coalition for greater diversity within the museum, including that a “section of the Museum, under the direction of black artists, should be devoted to showing the accomplishments of black artists.”
Andy Warhol, Little Electric Chair, 1964‐65

Pop Art
  1. Warhol’s “Death in America” images of car wreck, suicides, civil rights confrontations as well as the electric chair series apply a disturbing sense of impersonality to images of death and disaster.  In doing this he suggested that familiarity and overexposure to such images breeds indifference.
  2. For this series he appropriated grainy images sourced from headlines and newspapers and blew them up and repeated them in silkscreen, retaining the grainy quality of the newsprint and ramping up the contrast through the silkscreen process. The image of “old Sparky” the electric chair at Sing-Sing prison in NY is after a January 1953 press photograph announcing the execution of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg who were convicted of espionage.
  3. He made several works with this image, either singly as here in this rose hue, or in monotonous repetition, or paired with a monochrome painting of the same size. In each of these iterations Warhol explores the way that this image signifies and creates emotional meaning, or doesn’t. Through this manipulation of the image, the scene becomes increasingly chilling, as much through the abstract austerity of its organization as through its associations
  4. Readings of Warhol’s work, and particular his Death in America works interpret the image as either referential or as simulacral
    1. Simulacral reading is informed by poststructuralism – the idea that pop art wants to desymbolize the object and release the image from deep meaning into simulacral surface. This reading was advanced by Barthes, Foucault, Deleuze and Baudrillard for whom referential depth and subjection interiority were annihilated under the superficiality of Warhol Pop
    2. Referential reading advanced by critics in social history who tie the work to thematic issues, e.g. Thomas Crow who disputes the interpretation of the Warhol images as impassive and indiscriminate, arguing that in his works he exposed the “open sores in American political life,” belonging to the popular American tradition of “truth-telling”
  5. Hal Foster describes that in Warhol’s reproduction and repetition of this image, he produces a second order of trauma, when one realizes the detached way that one has been compelled to view this material. This creates a paradox, he argues, not only of images that are both affective and affectless, but also of viewers that are neither integrated nor dissolved.
Robert Morris, installation view of Green Gallery exhibition, New York, December 1964‐January 1965

Minimalism
1.     During the 1960s and 70s, the monumental size of Minimal sculpture inevitably led to the concept of sculpture designed for a specific space or place. This in turn resulted in ideas such as the use of the gallery space itself as an element in an architectural-sculptural organization.
2.     An early experiment in this direction was Morris’s 1964 exhibition at the Green Gallery in New York, where large geometric sculptural modules were integrated within the room. Set on the floor or in relation to the gallery walls, these polyhedrons defined the gallery’s architecture as sculpture rarely had before, directing the viewer’s focus to the space itself. 
3.     Between 1962 and 1964, Morris produced seven grey painted, simple plywood sculptures intended for this landmark exhibition. With this body of work, Morris introduced a minimal art that was fundamentally sculptural and intended to draw attention to the contingencies of space and site. 
4.     Morris’s sculptures often consisted of industrial or building materials and were commercially fabricated according to his specifications. The value of the artist’s hand was inimical to Morris, and the work of art became, in theory, not an original object but a representation of the idea from which it was conceived. This notion allowed for the creation and destruction of the piece when necessary, allowing for it to refabricated each time it was exhibited.
5.     The exhibition was critiqued by Judd, who did not find the work to be environmental, “The work looks well together, but it isn’t an environment; there are seven separate pieces. If Morris made an environment, it would certainly be one thing.”

George Segal, The Diner, 1964‐66
Walker Art Center, Minneapolis

Environmental Assemblage/Pop Art
  1. Segal was a painter and sculptor, recognized for his life-size white plaster sculptures made from casts on living models begun in 1961. Though best known as a Pop artist, he was also a humanist who addressed historical topics and religious themes in commissioned public monuments (Great Depression, Holocaust, Kent State Massacre).
  2. Segal closely associated with Allan Kaprow, who stimulated his interest in sculpture as a total environment. Diner creates such an environment, a life-sized restaging embodying Edward Hopper's classic for the loneliness of postwar America. Rothko once remarked that Segal's sculptures were like "walk-in Hoppers."
  3. Diner holds key ideas Segal explored throughout his career: the contrast between the real environment and the spectral presences that inhabit it; and waiting, an overarching theme in his work. The man sitting at an empty diner, the quintessential symbol of middle-class America, appears to be waiting for something, creating a quiet drama that permeated his everyday scenes from the 1960s.
  4. Segal worked with assemblage, incorporating found objects from junk yards like the fluorescent lamp, bar stools, table, and familiar items such as coffee cups, sugar, napkin dispensers, and a coffee urn, unmodified, into his environments. 
  5. Segal's signature medium were his figure sculptures made of bandages dipped in plaster. The sculptures look like what they are: inert shells of real people. They're blank but emotionally fraught, specific but anonymous, ordinary but strange. Bandages imply healing, vulnerability of the body, and intimacy of relationship with the live model/actor.
Marcel Breuer, Whitney Museum of American Art, 1964‐66 NYC

Brutalism, midcentury museum architecture
  1. Marcel Breuer (1902-1981) was a Hungarian-born modernist architect, and furniture designer. At the Bauhaus he designed the Wassily Chair and the Cesca Chair which is “among the 10 most important chairs of the 20th century.” Breuer extended the sculpture vocabulary he had developed in the carpentry shop at the Bauhaus into a personal architecture that made him one of the world's most popular architects at the peak of 20th-century design. He designed the Whitney at the height of his popularity as a midcentury New York architect. 
  2. Known for its use of functional reinforced concrete and steel, modular elements, and utilitarian feel, Brutalist architecture was primarily used for institutional buildings. Imposing and geometric, Brutalist buildings have a graphic quality that is part of what makes them so appealing today. The word Brutalist doesn’t come from the architecture’s fortress-like stature, but from the raw concrete it is often made from—béton brut. 
  3. The street level is wide open, as Breuer wanted to acclimatize the visitor from the hustle of Madison Avenue to a profound engagement with art. The entrance experience is a slow procession that begins with a walk under a low concrete canopy and over a sunken garden, which reveals great glass walls into the lower ground spaces, before entering the grand lobby.
  4. The desire for a flexible exhibition space determined the large, open galleries that now remain. Three of its floors suspend precast concrete, open-grid ceilings designed to allow movable wall panels and flexible lighting that can be rearranged for each new exhibition.
  5. Utilizes the utmost in flexibility in installation space and artificial lighting. Natural daylight has been ignored except for that emanating from a few trapezoidal-shaped windows functioning as relief accents.
  6. “It should not look like a business or office building, nor should it looks like a place of light entertainment. Its form and material should have its own identity and weight in the neighborhood of fifty-story skyscrapers, or mile long bridges, in the midst of a dynamic jungle of our colorful city... . It should transform the vitality of the street into the sincerity and profundity of art.” (Marcel Breuer)
  7. Resembling an upside-down ziggurat, the front of the structure is surrounded by a moat looking trench, occupied by a sunken sculpture court, creating a gap between the sidewalk and the entrance, only connected by a concrete bridge.
  8. Exterior is concrete faced with granite. For the interiors, Breuer used a vast array of materials including terrazzo, board-formed and bush-hammered concrete, bluestone for the floors, walnut parquet, and suspended precast concrete coffers for the ceiling. (Not really a fun fact: I love the bluestone and terrazzo so so much, that’s the only reason I put this here.)
Georg Baselitz, Die grossen Freunde (The Great Friends), 1965

German Neo-Expressionism
  1. Georg Baselitz (b. 1938) is the senior among the German Neo-Expressionists. He was born Georg Kern, but in a nationalist, nostalgic gesture renamed himself for the village where he was born (Deutschbaselitz in Saxony) after he moved in 1958 from USSR-occupied East Germany to West Berlin. There, he studied under abstract painter Hann Trier. 
  2. West Berlin was dominated by America’s capitalist presence, bolstered by an influx of economic and cultural goods. In 1958, it hosted New American Painting, traveling from MoMA, a propegandistic effort which included Jackson Pollock, Willem de Kooning, and Yves Kline. 
  3. Rejecting both the Americans’ Abstract Expressionist painting and the Socialist Realism of the Russians, Baselitz revived the narrative, symbolic, and emotional tradition of painting (see Matthias Grünewald and others) that was seen as specifically German. For an earlier example of Germans seeking to develop a national identity in painting (and taking inspiration from similar early Christian sources) see the Nazarenes.
  4. Baselitz’s style - in contrast to the coolness of American abstraction - was brilliantly-colored and aggressively painterly. The figures in his canvases often appeared upside-down. 
  5. In 1964-66, Baselitz developed an iconography of heroic men personifying the German psyche, monumental albeit battered figures towering over the devastated landscape. In the course of a single year – 1965/66 – Baselitz produced 60 paintings, 130 drawings and 38 prints on the same theme. He explained, “I was born into a destroyed order, a destroyed landscape, a destroyed nation, a destroyed society.”
  6. In February 1966 several of the “Hero” paintings were shown at Galerie Springer in Berlin. The Great Friends was the core work in the exhibition, featured on the exhibition poster. It was substantially larger than the previous “Hero” paintings, and different in that it depicted two figures. 
  7. Beneath the illustration on the exhibition’s poster, Baselitz had a manifesto reprinted with the heading “Why the work The Great Friends is a good painting!” He wrote, “The picture is an ideal picture, a gift from God, inevitable - a revelation. [...] It is ambiguous because there is more behind the screen than you might think. The principles of the picture, color, structure, shape etc. are wild and pure.” He derived important aspects of the manifesto from criteria for the art of the mentally ill introduced in a book about the characteristics of schizophrenic painting by Helmut Rennert, 1962.

Joseph Kosuth, One and Three Chairs, 1965
The Museum of Modern Art, New York

Conceptual Art
1. Where Minimalism had taken a preconceived intellectual approach (creating art from “readymade” mathematical systems), Conceptual artists proposed that the next logical move lay in taking art beyond the object into the realm of language, knowledge, science, or data.
2. Kosuth was a co-curator of the 1970 “Information” exhibition at MoMA, which acknowledged that ideas had come to the fore in art and taken precedence over concrete form.
3. One and Three Chairs presents one of the earliest conceptual explorations of language as a means of representation. The piece consists of an actual chair accompanied by a full-scale photograph of it and a dictionary definition of “chair” (object, image, word).
4. These three representations of “chairness” evoke Plato’s Theory of Forms, which holds that the true form of something exists only in the idea of that thing—all representations of the idea are degraded versions (mere shadows on the wall of a cave).
5. In a deliberate evocation of Plato, Kosuth uses a piece of furniture to show that each representation of the chair conveys a slightly different idea: all sign systems are inherently imprecise, inevitably producing as much misapprehension as understanding (hence Plato’s scorn for artists in his Republic). Kosuth’s cheeky reference to Plato here seems to suggest that modern society has finally achieved the state of Plato’s utopian republic and has no further need for artists.
6. One and Three Chairs is indebted to Duchamp’s objets trouvés, but Kosuth is interested in lifting objects into a gallery space not to test the limits of art, but to expose the mechanics of meaning, which involves linking an ideal mental concept with an imperfect visual image or verbal signifier.
Shigeko Kubota, Vagina Painting, 1965

Fluxus
  1. Kubota (Japanese, 1937-2015) started her career as part of avant-garde groups in Japan who pushed art’s boundaries, incorporating music, performance and movement into their work and questioned the centralized authority of the postwar Japanese government. Their experiments were in keeping with Fluxus activities happening in the US, whom Kubota joined upon her arrival in New York. She became intensely involved with the Fluxus ground, organizing events and distributing mail art alongside Maciunas.
  2. Fluxus emerged as a radical critique of conventional concepts of identity and authorship, often taking an antimasculinist (if not yet explicitly feminist) stance. In Kubota’s Vagina Painting she brushed red, menstrual-like paint onto a sheet of paper on the floor with a brush attached to her underwear, thereby dismantling the seemingly never-ending mythology of Pollock’s virile painting performances with a single scandalous gesture.
  3. In this act she feminized the phallus-as-paintbrush image of the Action Painters, also speaking to the Freudian phallic lack, positing the paintbrush as her own “lacking” ejaculating penis.
  4. It may also have been a reference to the practice of lower-class geishas who sometimes entertained customers by writing calligraphy with brushes inserted in their vaginas. Kubota’s performance fused dichotomies, combining high and low arts, masculine and feminine elements and eastern and western cultures.
  5. She first publicly executed the work at the Perpetual Fluxus Festival held in 1965 at new York Cinemathèque.
  6. Her performance fit with Maciunas’s mission for “Fluxus Art-Amusement”: “Therefore, art-amusement must be simple, amusing, unpretentious, concerned with insignificances, require no skill or countless rehearsals, have no commodity or institutional value. The value of art-amusement must be lowered by making it unlimited, massproduced, obtainable by all and eventually produced by all.”
Agnes Martin, Leaf, 1965

Abstract expressionist? 
1.     Coming to New York in the early 1950s from the open planes of Northern Saskatchewan, Canada, where she grew up and of New Mexico, where she studied, Agnes Martin gravitated towards the part of the New York School that had avoided gestural painting, adopting instead fields of unbroken color and vastly simplified, geometricizing compositional strategies.
2.     The method she developed in 1963, that she continued with for the rest of her career, consisted of pencilling a fine linear, edge-to-edge grid onto 6ft canvases treated with a thin layer of gesso. In the first of these grids, she used colored pencils but by 1964, she had switched to simple graphite so that monochromatism took over these pictures, which were nonetheless, were able to achieve an extraordinary visual variety.
3.     Because she endowed that variety with titles evocative of the natural world, and because of the strong impression of effulgence generated by the gridded fields, as if emanating indefinable lights, Martin’s paintings were seen as analogues of nature.
4.     Her work began to be read along the lines of thematized abstract art, that insisted on interpreting even the starkest grid or most ascetic monochrome phenomenologically, in iconographic terms associated the Sublime. The grid itself is seen as potentially limitless, identical units capable of generating metaphysical, no matter how mechanical or automatist such a schema may be. 
5.     Martin’s art characterized as structuralist, mobilizes the very spiritual/material ambivalence built into the grid. In this sense, her compositions are not involved in picturing anything specific, as clouds, sky, light or sublime immensity. Instead, she generates a structural paradigm in which atmosphere becomes less a question of intuition and more a unit in a system. This makes a reductive reading of Martin’s work as “pure spatial immensity” or “pure spirit” impossible.
Yoko Ono, Cut Piece, Carnegie Hall NYC, March 1965

Fluxus / Feminist Performance art

  1. Ono is a Japanese artist, musician, filmmaker, and peace activist who influenced the international development of Fluxus and Conceptual art, and pioneered participatory art.
  2. Ono's works often blur the boundaries between art, politics, and society. In this performance, she sat on a stage in Carnegie Hall and invited the audience to approach her and cut away her clothing, so it gradually fell away from her body, theirs to keep. Some people approached hesitantly, others boldly, yet Ono remained motionless and expressionless throughout, until, at her discretion, the performance ended.
  3. Challenging the neutrality of the relationship between viewer and art object, Ono presented a situation in which the viewer was implicated in the potentially aggressive act of unveiling the female body, which served historically as one such ‘neutral’ and anonymous subject for art. Emphasizing the reciprocity between viewers and subjects, Cut Piece demonstrates how viewing without responsibility has the potential to harm or even destroy the object of perception.
  4. The work is a key piece within the Fluxus art movement, because it engages the artist’s body as performance, and it breaks down the distinctions between art and life, echoing George Maciunas' Fluxus Manifesto, where cut out dictionary definitions of ‘flux’, which emphasize its bodily character – a flow of fluids and discharge – were interrupted by his handwritten statements calling for a fusion of art and reality. Fluxus transformed art from an object of aesthetic contemplation to a gesture of political action.
  5. Julia Bryan-Wilson: the piece critiques voyeurism and sexual aggression toward the female body and confronts the influence of Hiroshima and Nagasaki on postwar Japanese art. Ono's body has a racial/national inflection. JBW suggests focusing on violence/sadism alone is reductive. Significance of documentation, repetition, clothing scraps offered as "souvenirs" or "gifts" to preserve the memory of the event (memory of war/disaster).
  6. Ono debuted the piece in Kyoto, in 1964, and has reprised it in Tokyo, New York, London, and Paris, most recently in 2003. As with most of her work, the participation of others is key. Equally conceptual and physical, it relies upon audiences’ willingness to interpret and follow the instructions outlining their role.
Mark Rothko, The Rothko Chapel, Houston, TX, 1965‐66

Color field painting, site specific
  1. The Rothko Chapel is a non-denominational chapel in Houston, Texas, founded by John and Dominique de Menil. In 1964, Rothko was commissioned by John and Dominique de Menil (also founders of the nearby Menil Collection) to create a meditative space filled with his paintings. The works are site-specific, one of the requirements of the program.
  2. In his late career, Rothko was painting on a huge scale, something that contributed to the effect of enclosing, encompassing color. At the end of the 1950s, Rothko began to move away from bright, sensuous color toward deeper, more somber hues. 
  3. This last series consists of fourteen large panels, almost uniform in their deep black and red-brown, almost filling the entire available space. The canvases are designed to be homogeneous with the octagonal building (designed by Philip Johnson)
  4. The paintings respond to the changing light of the chapel interior. Thus, the forms have a less amorphous, harder-edge appearance than Rothko’s earlier abstractions. 
  5. They represent a total architectural–pictorial experience in a sense analogous to that attempted by the religious muralists of the Baroque seventeenth century. Rothko, who even adopted the triptych format long associated with religious subjects, never intended his abstractions as mere formal experiments, but rather wanted to provoke emotional and even transcendental experiences in the viewer.
  6.  As Rothko was given creative license on the design of the structure, he clashed with the project's original architect, Philip Johnson over the plans for the chapel. The plans went through several revisions and architects. Rothko continued to work first with Howard Barnstone and then with Eugene Aubry, but ultimately he did not live to see the chapel's completion in 1971.
  7. Rothko always refuted assertions that his paintings represent something. Rothko instead stated that he was striving for “the elimination of all obstacles between the painter and the idea, and between the idea and the observer.”
Carl Andre, Equivalent (VIII), 1966

Minimalist Sculpture
  1. Minimalism was interested in sculptures that became part of the surrounding environment, invading the lived space of the viewer - hence why this work is placed on the floor rather than on a pedestal. You’re able to walk on a lot of Andre’s works (not sure about this one.) 
  2. Clement Greenberg thought this type of work was theatrical - and it was, in the Brechtian sense, I suppose (though if I’m putting my October psychoanalytic hat on, this has always felt more like a gay panic than a real aesthetic critique.)
  3. Hal Foster compares Andre’s work (along with LeWitt’s and Flavin’s) to Constructivism for its transparency of construction - and also, presumably, for its use of architectural materials. In Andre’s work, these materials are (as the sculptor wrote) “combined to produce space” - defining rather than simply occupying space. The viewer and the sculpture exist in the same field - heightened by Andre’s use of quotidian construction materials.
  4. According to David Bourdon, “'For some time it had been apparent to Andre that his sculpture should be low. In summer, 1965, while canoeing on a New Hampshire lake, he realised his sculpture had to be as level as water. For his second show at the Tibor de Nagy Gallery in March 1966, Andre created an astringent environment by setting eight rectilinear mounds of 120 bricks each on the gallery's parquet floor.” 
  5. Each of Andre’s Equivalent series consists of a rectangular arrangement of 120 firebricks. Although the shape of each sculpture is different, they all have the same height, mass and volume, and are therefore “equivalent” to each other.
  6. Andre’s sculptures are often assembled using common industrial materials (cf Marcel Duchamp’s ready-mades), which he arranges into a simple geometric pattern. The original bricks were sand-lime bricks from the Long Island City Brickworks. None of the Equivalents was sold from the Tibor de Nagy exhibition and Andre afterwards returned all but 200 of the bricks to the brickyard to get his money back. When he decided to reconstruct the pieces several years later he found that this brickworks had closed, so he used firebricks instead. These are approximately the same size, but yellowy-brown (seen here) instead of bluish white.

Diane Arbus, A Young Man in Curlers at Home on West Twentieth Street, New York City, 1966
The Museum of Modern Art, New York

American Documentary Photography
1. Transgressing traditional boundaries, Arbus is known for her controversial portraiture taken primarily in the American Northeast during the late 1950s and 1960s. Famous for establishing strong personal relationships with her subjects, Arbus’ evocative images capture them in varied levels of intimacy. Whether in their living rooms or on the street, Arbus’ photographs transcend the common distance found in documentary photography.
2. Arbus began her career working in commercial photography; abandoned in late 1950s; encouraged by her mentor Lisette Model; awarded two Guggenheim grants in 1963 and 1966;
3. Since 1960, Arbus was photographing for magazines such as Esquire and Harper’s Bazaar; captured the world at which one was not allowed to stare: transvestites, circus performers, nudists, mentally disabled; revealing that at which others had been taught to turn their back on
4. A Young Man reflects Arbus’s interest in gender and identity. Arbus often photographed transvestites and transsexuals, but instead of photographing the men fully dressed and made-up, while on stage performing or socializing, she preferred to photograph in more domestic settings, creating intimate portraits behind the scenes.
5. The photograph emphasizes the ambiguity of her subject’s gender: his strong, masculine jawline, large hands and the pitted skin on his cheeks contrast with his groomed, arched eyebrows, curlers and long fingernails, all captured in impressive detail through Arbus’s lens.
6. This image was included in the 1967 exhibition “New Documents” at MoMA, representing a new generation of photographers who took the documentary approach to more personal ends.
Dan Flavin, Monument for V. Tatlin, 1966

Minimalism?
  1. In his signature use of fluorescent light fixtures, Flavin combined his fascination with technology and light with other concerns arising from the negotiation of Greenbergian modernism im the 1960s including an interest in materials, leading to an unwillingness to disguise in any way the nature of the medium. Also derived from Greenberg was the attention paid to the environment in which an artwork was installed, which would become central to Minimalism
  2. In Flavin’s works the glass tubes of fluorescent light functions as a sculpture both when illuminated and when unlit, creating different effects. In turn he recognized that light itself could transform and environment
  3. Flavin, along with young sculptors in the 60s such as Judd and Andre sought to find a “great alternative to the semi-Surrealist work of the fifties such as Giacometti’s and the late Cubism of David Smith,” and found it in the Constructivism of Tatlin and Rodchenko. This ultimately trumped the model of a medium-specific modernism advanced by Greenberg.
  4. Flavin was drawn to Tatlin for his demonstration of industrial material, exposed production, and architectural siting. Furthermore Flavin, like Tatlin, was interested in the Byzantine icon which carried with it a “physical feeling” and “magical presiding presence” that impressed him. The icon provided Flavin with an alternative model of the picture, one which was assertively material but also spectrally spiritual. In this work Flavin pays homage to Tatlin in a pyramid of fluorescent lights that recalls the proposal spiral of metalwork of Monument to the Third International.
  5. But unlike Constructivism, Flavin’s industrial material here was not futuristic but found precisely in the readymade. Flavin regarded his light as “a modern technological fetish.” In this way he held together two contradictory imperatives of modernist art: the imperative to materialize the work of art, declare light as light and expose its physical support, and also to dematerialize the work, to irradiate it with light, to wash space with color.

Edward Kienholz, The State Hospital, 1966
Moderna Museet, Stockholm

Pop
1.     Los Angeles based artist Edward Keinholz’s constructions embody a mordant and gruesome view of American life. For Keinholz, modern life could be characterized by inadequacy, breakdown and tragedy. His grim and hopeless environments illustrate the fallacy of America being considered the apex of modern Western culture.
2.     His works are saturation with the desolateness and alienation of man in modern society. He wanted his art to function in the capacity of a social conscience, and draw attention to facets of society considered taboo. 
3.     This work was inspired by Kienholz’s experiences working as an attendant in a mental hospital in Washington in the late 1940s. The conditions that the patients were subject to affected him, and this piece was constructed as a form of indictment of all such institutions. 
4.     In this tableau, two naked, life size figures are bound to their metal bed frames in  identical positions. Their mattresses are grimy and the floor is encrusted in filth. In place of their faces are two illuminated fish bowls with two live black fish, serving as allegories of confinement and the mental and physical decay born from it. The figure in the upper bunk is encased in a neon thought bubble from the figure in the lower bunk– indicating that the figure can comprehend its existence only in the present. 
5.     His tableaux is encased in a box form, visible to the viewer only through a barred window in the cell, thus implicating the viewer as a voyeur in the painfully grim scene. The room itself was designed to resemble a prison cell, portraying the prison like conditions in which the patients were placed.

Bridget Riley, Drift No. 2, 1966
Albright‐Knox Art Gallery, Buffalo

Op art

  1. Riley is an English painter, one of the foremost proponents of Op art, a movement whose theories were first presented when Vasarely published his Manifeste jaune (Yellow Manifesto) (1955), which proposed the creation of “kinetic art," which sought to include movement using optical illusions that generated the sensation of a moving image.
  2. The movement's name was derived from a collective interest in the science of optics, and how our brains respond to colors, lines, and shapes and form the optical illusions. Op artists employed perceptual effects that sought the activation of vision through color contrasts, sequential changes, moiré patterns, and the incorporation of spectator movement, causing the impression of movement, brightness, and pulsation. These effects were increased under the influence of drugs like mescaline and LSD.
  3. In Drift No. 2, the precisely placed, wavy, repeated vertical lines modulate from dark to light to dark again in different values of gray, producing extremely effective illusions, seemingly making the picture plane vibrate, weave, and billow before our eyes. Riley's subtle gradations in tone (which Vasarely rejected) and undulating, hard-edged lines accentuate the illusion of three-dimensionality and movement.  
  4. This composition confounds the usual foreground/background arrangement of pictorial space by not privileging one over the other. It is difficult to ascertain if the black is on top of the white or vice versa, and instead the relation between the two colors never settles into an easy harmony.
  5. Op art had precursors in the impressionists' interest in light, the "optical mixtures" of the pointillists; drew on geometry, mathematical systems, and Gestalt psychology, as well as the graphic design instruction begun by the Bauhaus. Riley was particularly influenced by Seurat, whose works taught her about the importance of contrast and the interrelationship of color and tone.  
  6. In 1965, she was included in MoMA's exhibition The Responsive Eye, which first brought attention to Op art. In 1968, Riley received the International Prize for Painting at the Venice Biennale, making her the first woman and the first British contemporary painter to achieve that honor.
 
Quote: "In general, my paintings are multifocal. You can't call it unfocused space, but not being fixed to a single focus is very much of our time.”
On Kawara, The Today Series of Date Paintings, 1966

Conceptual art
  1. On Kawara (1932 – 2014) was a Japanese conceptual artist who lived in New York City from 1965. He took part in many solo and group exhibitions, including the Venice Biennale in 1976.
  2. From January 4, 1966, Kawara made a long series of "Date paintings" (the Today series), which consist entirely of the date on which the painting was executed in simple white lettering set against a solid background. The date is always documented in the language and grammatical conventions of the country in which the painting is executed.
  3. The originality of each work, its small difference from the others, becomes a possibility for a confrontation with the daily events of the world. Since its meaning is not predetermined, the real work of the piece lies ahead, in the encounter with the viewer, when it is exposed to the world. The vision it offers us is a moment in world history, yet it is an unnamed moment.
  4. The dates on the paintings, hand-painted with calculated precision, are always centered on the canvas and painted white, whereas the background colors vary. Four coats of paint are carefully applied for the ground and each allowed enough time to dry before being rubbed down in preparation for subsequent coats. 
  5. Eschewing stencils in favor of hand-drawn characters, each work is carefully executed by hand. Some days he made more than one. When Kawara was unable to complete the painting on the day it was started he immediately destroyed it. 
  6. When a Date Painting is not exhibited, it is placed in a cardboard box custom-made for the painting, which is lined with a clipping from a local newspaper from the city in which the artist made the painting; most clippings are from The New York Times. Although the boxes are part of the work, they are rarely exhibited. Each year between 63 and 241 paintings were made.
  7. Each Date Painting is registered in a journal and marked on a One Hundred Years Calendar. When Kawara finished a painting, he applied a swatch of the paint mixture he used to a small rectangle that was then glued onto a chart in the journal. The 48 journals record the details of the painting's size, color and newspaper headline, while the calendar uses colored dots to indicate the days in which a painting was made, and to record the number of days since the artist's birth. Kawara created nearly 3,000 date paintings in more than 112 cities worldwide in a project that was planned to end only with his death.
  8. The significance of these paintings lies in the fact that they depict not only a date, but also their own date. If, historically, paintings have been fixed in time by a date on the front or back of the canvas, the date itself for Kawara becomes the subject of the painting and the sole embodiment of the work's figurative imagery. 
  9. Kawara made the passage of time itself the all-important subject by each day starting a small black painting that simply set forth the current date in white block letters. With every panel an equal component in the series, the work can reveal its full meaning only as a total conception.

Nikki de Saint­‐Phalle, SHE—A Cathedral, 1966
Moderna Museet, Stockholm

New Realism
  1. Parisian born Niki de Saint-Phalle lived in New York 1933-51 and exhibited with the New Realists 1961-63. She was known at the time for her “Shot-reliefs,” for which she fired a pistol at bags of paint placed atop assemblage reliefs, resulting in drip paintings - a (pretty hilarious) commentary on the machismo of Action Painting.
  2. Saint-Phalle became known for her Nana figures, which (according to Arnason) “came to represent the archetype of an all-powerful woman.” Nana is French slang, meaning something like chick or broad. Black Venus, for example, was one of several Nanas that Saint Phalle made during this period as a statement of solidarity with the civil rights movement.  
  3. HON (SHE) was a temporary indoor sculpture installation for the Moderna Museet of Stockholm created in collaboration with Jean Tinguely (her lover) and Per Olof Ultvedt in 1966. The sculpture has a form of a gigantic pregnant woman, laying on her back with knees raised and heels planted. Visitors could enter the figure through a door-sized vaginal opening between her legs. Its structure references classic architectural theories about the entrances to cathedrals and their metaphoric and symbolic relationship to female genitalia, 
  4. Once inside, visitors found themselves in a body that included a love-seat sofa, a planetarium, a gallery with “fake” artworks in one of the thighs (paintings with the word “fake” painted in the styles of artists such as Paul Klee, Jean Dubuffet and Jean Fautrier by Ulf Linde), a 12-seat cinema screening a scene from the silent film ”Luffar-Petter” (Peter the Tramp, 1921) with Greta Garbo, an aquarium, a milk-bar inside a breast, a fish pond, a coin telephone, a sandwich vending machine, a brain with mechanical parts (by Tinguely), an art installation by Ultvedt, and a playground slide.
  5. The project has been interpreted from a feminist perspective; as a happening with roots in the medieval carnivals; and as a type of performative exhibition, where visitors were invited to interact with art.
  6. The scale of this work inspired Saint Phalle to begin working on a more architectural scale, culminating in her sculpture (actually a home that one can live in) The Empress.
Ed Ruscha, Every Building on the Sunset Strip, 1966

American Pop Art / proto-Conceptual Art
1. Ruscha was an American artist working on the West coast. His hard-edge technique and vernacular subject matter allied him with California Pop art in the 1960s (i.e. Twenty-Six Gasoline Stations), while his fascination with words and typography, exemplified by his printed books and word-paintings, corresponded to certain trends in Conceptual Art that surfaced in the following decade. He has a background as a graphic designer of books.
2. Book Every Building on the Sunset Strip documents exactly what its title indicates in a series of deadpan photographs. Unsigned and inexpensively printed, Ruscha's photography books are antithetical to the traditional limited-edition artist's book.
3. Ruscha: “I want absolutely neutral material. My pictures are simply a collection of facts. My book is more like a collection of readymades.” (importance of Duchamp who had his first major retrospective was held in 1963 at the Pasadena Art Museum).
4. His banal subject matter and documentary style are indebted to the remarkable pictures of signs and vernacular architecture that American photographer Walker Evans made in the 1930s, but his deadpan, cool aesthetic is radically different.
5. While each of his photo books chronicles an aspect of Los Angeles or the artist's round-trip drives between LA and Oklahoma, their use of photography as a form of map-making or topographical study signals a conceptual, rather than documentary, thrust.
Bruce Nauman, Self‐Portrait as a Fountain, 1966‐70

Color photograph
Conceptual art
  1. Nauman (American b. 1941) is a multi-media artist known for his use of the body (often his won) to expand the boundaries of traditional media, from sculpture to photography and video. He was among the first to take advantage of CCTV in his video installations, in turn bringing the body of the viewer into the work itself.
  2. In this photograph, Nauman makes himself into a living pun on Duchamp’s Fountain, further pushing the boundaries of Duchamp’s investigation 50 years prior of the possibility of what art may be. Here, he goes further than questioning the artwork itself to question the traditional role of the artist.
  3. He poses here in imitation of the nude statues traditionally found in decorative fountains, conflating the artworld with the artist. In this act he satirizes the cliché of the artist as a prolific genius or revelatory communicator who “spews” forth a steady stream of masterpieces and ideas.
  4. In conflating himself with Duchamp’s Fountain Nauman uses his body and the negative space around it as modernist objects, materials  that could be monitored, examined and exercised. He also explored the viewer’s body as an object in his work in the late 1960s and 70s in his Corridor works.
  5. The water-fountain has a particularly significant political position in American society, as a site of Jim Crow laws. This work was made just two years after the United States’ official desegregation of water fountains. Within this historical context, Nauman’s choice to exhibit his white body in relation to the fountain takes on a second meaning. Nauman’s intentions were rather tongue-in-cheek and nodded toward history; however, he knew his body was a font loaded with a metonymic chain muddy enough to merge the darkest of political concepts with the lightest of objective explorations—his body as sculpture.
  6. The image is one of eleven photographs in a portfolio called “Eleven Color Photographs” (1970) based on puns which reveal Nauman’s interest in the functions of language as he humorously depicts literal interpretations of common phrases.
Louis I. Kahn, Kimbell Art Museum, Fort Worth, TX, 1966‐72

Modern American architecture  
1.     Kay Kimbell and his wife Velma Fuller set up the Kimbell Art Foundation in 1935. Upon Kimbell’s death, his estate was bequeathed to the foundation with the intentions of building a new museum. The foundation director Richard Brown set clear guidelines regarding the new building as a work of art. He interviewed several architects including Mies Van der Rohe and Marcel Breuer, but the commission was awarded to Kahn in 1966.
2.     American architect Louis Kahn’s work emerged amidst the uncertainty and loss of idealism of the 1930s and 40s. Born in  Estonia, Khan emigrated with his family to Philadelphia in 1905. He received architectural training in the Beaux Arts tradition at the University of Pennsylvania. His  later work reflected a fusion of modernism’s passion for technology and abstract form along with a profound awareness of history and its role in architecture.
3.     His Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth, Texas is considered one of the most dramatic as well functionally effective art museums in the world. The design is based upon a parallel series of self-supporting cycloidal vaults that eliminate the need for interior supports and facilitate and unobstructed and very flexible use of the spacious interior. 
4.     Interior and outdoor spaces are integration through the inclusion of a sculpture garden that creates a fluid interchange between the museum and its environment, thereby altering the traditional notion of a museum as a place that cloisters works of art. 
5.     Kahn is also noted for the close attention paid to the issues of lighting and display. By combining natural and artificial light, and breaking up the cavernous heights of the gallery space by low hanging lights and shorter partitioning walls, the Kimbell becomes both a practical space for the display and conservation of art and an aesthetically pleasing environment that is simultaneously monumental and intimate for the gallery visitors.
6.     In his guidelines, Brown emphasised that “natural light should play a vital part” in the design. The distinct form of the Kimbell Museum’s cycloid barrel vaults are rimmed with narrow plexiglass skylights, providing room for natural light to penetrate into the spaces. To diffuse this light, pierced aluminium reflectors shaped like wings hang below, illuminating the smooth surfaces of the concrete while providing elegant light conditions for the artworks.
Karel Appel, Angry Landscape, 1967

CoBrA

  1. Appel was a Dutch painter and sculptor of turbulent, colorful, and figurative abstractions.  He was a cofounder of the CoBrA group of northern European expressionists (Copenhagen, Brussels, Amsterdam), who sought new forms of elemental expression, unconstrained formal experimentation, emphasis on brush gesture, and rejection of rationalism and geometric abstraction. The name CoBrA was taken from the first letters of the cities where the founders lived. However, they welcomed the reference to the snake, since animal imagery was common in their work. The short-lived but influential group lasted from 1948-51, unique for its internationalism and for infusing tremendous energy into abstract painting after WWII.
  2. In 1952, Michel Tapié included him in his now legendary exhibition Un art autre and in the eponymous book. Appel was the only CoBrA member chosen by Tapié.
  3. This painting focuses on two pervasive themes in his work: the figure and the landscape, and demonstrates his commitment to the ideals of expressive, spontaneous painting. Appel worked with the paint at high speed and with no preconceived scheme, turning the large canvas around from time to time. The figurative elements were added last. Influenced by Dubuffet, their appearance recalls the naivety of paintings made by children, whose intuitive, untrained and unadulterated approach was also admired by CoBrA artists.
  4. After settling in Paris in 1950, Appel visited the great "International Exhibition on Psychopathological Art" at the Sainte-Anne hospital of drawings by mentally ill patients. Deeply impressed by what he saw he covered the pages of the exhibition's brochure and its scientific descriptions of pathologies, with drawings. The resulting Psychopathological Notebook, part manifesto, part dictionary, was his own way, like Dubuffet, of inventing a pictorial language, his own form of Art brut. He kept the brochure with him all his life. 
  5. Appel was a reference for a few German painters of the following generation, like Baselitz or Lüpertz, who were keen to free themselves from the orthodox abstract style of the 50s without fully returning to figuration.

David Hockney, A Bigger Splash, 1967
Tate Gallery, London

Pop art
  1. Hockney (b. 1937) is a British painter, draftsman, printmaker, stage designer, and photographer. As an important contributor to the pop art movement of the 1960s, he is considered one of the most influential British artists of the 20th century.
  2. Emerging within the same period as the Beatles, Hockney—with his peroxide hair, granny glasses, gold lamé jacket, and easy charm—became something of a media event in his own right, a genial exponent of the go-go, hedonistic style of the 1960s. 
  3. Although Hockney projected a self-image that drew on pop culture, his art did not; instead, he used his own life and the lives of his friends and lovers—their faces and figures, houses, and interiors. These he rendered in a manner sometimes inspired by Picasso and Matisse, but often influenced by Dubuffet, in the delicate faux naïf manner of children.
  4. A Bigger Splash was painted between April and June 1967 when Hockney was teaching at the University of California at Berkeley. The image is derived in part from a photograph Hockney discovered in a book on the subject of building swimming pools. The background is taken from a drawing he had made of Californian buildings. 
  5. Hockney used small brushes to painstakingly reproduce the splash from the photograph: the shapes made by the upsurging cascade of water, the different areas of transparency and the details and traces of the tiny drips.
  6. Hockney moved to California in 1964. Between 1964 and 1971 he made numerous paintings of swimming pools. In each of the paintings he attempted a different solution to the representation of the constantly changing surface of water. 
  7. In contrast with several of his earlier swimming pool paintings, which contain a male subject, often naked and viewed from behind, the ‘splash’ paintings are empty of human presence, but imply the presence of a person beneath the water’s surface.

Donald Judd, Untitled, 1967
Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth, Texas

Minimalism
  1. Judd was a sculptor and theorist. In his influential 1965 essay “The Specific Object,” he wrote, “A work can be as powerful as it can be thought to be. Actual space is intrinsically more powerful and specific than paint on a flat surface...A work need only be interesting.” Judd believed that the “specific object” erases the distinction between painting and sculpture, It was less about creating particular structures and more about an attitude towards artmaking in real space.
  2. For Judd, the “specific object” functioned as a rejection of the transcendance or sublime that Abstract Expressionists like Newman located within their work. Instead, Judd was a proponent of rationalism.
  3. Judd insisted that Minimal sculpture constituted a direction essentially different from earlier Constructivism or rectilinear abstract paintings. Judd sought an absolute unity or wholeness through repetition of identical units in absolute symmetry. 
  4. Although hung on a wall like a painting, Untitled projects nearly three feet from the wall and climbs like rungs on a ladder from floor to ceiling. 
  5. Untitled is part of a series known as Stacks, all of which similarly iterate rectangular solids hung on a wall in a vertical stack, evenly vertically spaced. For Judd, these spaces were as vital to the work as the rectangular solids, creating a play between positive and negative.
  6. The box was one of Judd’s favorite forms, because he felt it was neutral and had no symbolic meaning. 
  7. Untitled is made of stainless steel boxes, each with a transparent orange plexi top and open bottom, all identical. The effect of the boxes, which are hung equidistantly from one another and from the floor, is to seem to illuminate the wall between them (this picture sucks), recalling Dan Flavin’s experiments with colored light.
Moshe Safdie, Habitat ‘67, Montreal, Canada 1967

Canadian Structuralist / Brutalist Architecture
1. One of the most distinctive examples of prefabricated housing design by Israeli-Canadian architect Moshe Safdie. This megastructure was commissioned as the Canadian pavilion for Expo ’67, the 1967 World’s Fair in Montreal, Canada.
2. The project originated from Safdie’s thesis at McGill University; when he was only 23 and interning in Louis Kahn’s studio, Safdie’s thesis advisor invited him to submit his project for the World Exposition of 1967; won the commission.
3. It was originally intended as an experimental solution for high-quality housing in dense urban environments. Safdie explored the possibilities of prefabricated modular units to reduce housing costs and allow for a new housing typology that could integrate the qualities of a suburban home into an urban high-rise.
4. It was designed as a permanent settlement of 158 dwellings made up of 15 types of independent, interlocking prefabricated boxes. By stacking concrete boxes in variant geometrical configurations, Safdie was able to break the traditional form of orthogonal high rises, locating each box a step back from its immediate neighbor.
5. This ingenious method provided each apartment with a roof garden, a constant flow of fresh air and a maximum of natural light, qualities which were unprecedented for a twelve-story apartment complex. Habitat 67 thus pioneered the integration of two housing typologies: the suburban garden home and the economical high-rise apartment building.
John Baldessari, This Is Not To Be Looked At, 1968

Conceptual Art
  1. Baldassari’s (American, 1931-2020) photo-text works enact an extreme form of “deskilling” photography that supplanted both the tradition of American documentary and that of American and European fine arts photography. Photography in Baldassari and the other conceptual photographer’s hands (Dan Graham, Kosuth Nauman) becomes a randomly accumulated set of indexical traces of images, objects, contexts, behaviors, or interactions.
  2. But unlike Kosuth and the other conceptual photographers who turned Duchamp and the readymade into doctrine, Baldessari took his subversive legacies and applied them to the false orthodoxies with which Conceptualism was about to install itself as the new authoritative movement. Baldessari’s work anticipated these new art-world pieties early on: he annihilated them with an antiartistic humor.
  3. In this photographic print on canvas Baldessari depicts an issue of Artforum magazine that features a reproduction of Frank Stella’s Union III (1966) on its cover. Beneath the printed photograph, he hired a professional sign painter to write the caption “This is not to be looked at,” paradoxically implying that visual contemplation is neither the best nor only way to engage with art.
  4. The title is a translation of “no se puede mirar,” the title of a work from Francisco Goya’s series of etchings The Disasters of War (1820). The pairing of the title with Stella’s painting on the ARtforum cover constructs a critique of formalist and literalism of high modernist painting, including reference to the statement of Frank Stella, “What you see is what you see.”
  5. His bald-faced appropriation and layering of preexisting images, as well as his hiring of another painter to complete the work, demonstrates his skepticism about artistic originality. He defiantly refuses to produce beautiful, original images, proposing instead that what is central is the artist’s concept or idea, irrespective of the work’s visual material form.
  6. In 1981 he wrote: “By late 65 I was finished with painting and by early 66 had begun these pieces. I was weary of doing relational painting and began wondering if straight information would serve, I sought to use language not as a visual element but as something to read. That is, a notebook entry about painting could replace the painting. And visual data less as pleasing artistically than as documentation, as in a store catalogue or police photograph […] Important was that I was the strategist.
