Someone else built and primed the canvases and took them to the sign painter, the texts are quotations from art books and the sign painter was instructed not to attempt to make attractive artful lettering but to letter the information in the most simple way.”
Louise Bourgeois, La Fillette, 1968

Neo-Surrealism
Latex over plaster

1.     Louise Bourgeois’ early work was influenced by Surrealism, in which she represented the female nude as an exposed, often violated shelter. It was in the early 1960s when she began to shape plaster, latex and fabric in ways that evoked abstract body parts. 
2.     Bourgeois gave another twist to the surrealist object, in this case the sexual fetish in La Fillette (Litte Girl). A dirty, penile object in latex over plaster, this work is a “disagreeable object” (a term used by Giacometti). By using  the materiality of latex, she achieves a fleshy, tactile texture in the sculpture
3.     According to Freud, women might associate penis and baby in order to compensate the lack of the first with the gain of the second. But this “little girl” is represented not as a fetish object or penis substitute but a personage in her own right. In this regard, the work is a bold gesture: as a feminist appropriation of the symbolic phallus.
4.     It is a work fraught with ambivalence. When hung by a wire, as it is often displayed, it appears as an object of hate, a castrated piece of meat. But when cradled, as it is by Bourgeois in a well-known photograph by Robert Mapplethorpe. Whether lovingly cradled or brutally dangled, the contrary nature of the work epitomizes Bourgeois’s intense and mixed feelings towards mother  hood, masculinity and sexuality.
5.     While there is much in her work that refers to her troubled relationship with her philandering father, as a wife and mother of three sons, Bourgeois also viewed masculinity as something more vulnerable; she says, “The phallus is a subject of my tenderness. Everything I loved had the shape of the people around me– the shape of my husband, the shape of the children. So, when I wanted to represent something I loved, I obviously represented a little penis.”

Chuck Close, Big Self‐Portrait, 1968
Walker Art Center, Minneapolis, Minnesota

Photorealism

  1. Close is an American artist known for his innovative conceptual portraits in painting, drawing, photography, collage, and printmaking, that depict his subjects, transposed from photographs, into visual data organized by gridded compositions. For over 5 decades he has painted large-scale portraits of family members, friends, and fellow artists, including Philip Glass, Richard Serra, and Cindy Sherman. But more than any other subject, he’s painted himself.
  2. This is his first self-portrait, which was followed by nearly 100 more, exploring different media, vantage points, and techniques. It is based on a photograph he took after he had leftover film from a nude shooting, that ended up being inadvertently tilted and out of focus.
  3. Close suffers from the neurological disorder prosopagnosia, or face-blindness, which impairs his ability to recognize faces. This may be why, unknowingly, he made photographs a working part of his technique to produce highly detailed portraits.
  4. After taking a picture of his subject, Close makes photographic prints that he uses to transfer the images to canvas. Utilizing a grid technique devised by Renaissance masters and adapted by contemporary billboard painters, he overlays a working print with a numbered and lettered grid, and then reproduces it block by block, like a mosaic. Working with airbrush and minute amounts of paint, along with the grid system, he achieves an image that rivals that of the photograph but is alarmingly confrontational and overwhelming in scale.
  5. Specific features like the illusion of light reflecting off the hairs of his beard were achieved by scratching paint from the surface with a razor blade.
  6. Close was inspired by the "allover" surface of American painting epitomized by Pollock or Stella, their commitment to the whole and to making every piece as important as every other piece.
  7. His was a rebellion against Abstract Expressionism, minimalist sculpture, and the disinterest in portraiture at the time. His choice of "anonymous" subjects also went against Pop's celebrity cult. 
  8. In 2005 the Walker Art Center and SFMOMA organized Chuck Close: Self-Portraits 1967-2005, an exhibition that provided a glimpse of the artist’s self-examination through time.
 
Quote: “There’s no question, I had some attitude about the way I wanted to be perceived... Now it seems very funny wanting to look like this tough guy with a cigarette sticking out of the corner of my mouth and a big, aggressive image of myself and saying to the viewer, ‘Hey, notice my painting, notice me.’ I think I was trying to find out who I was as an artist.”
Richard Serra, Splashing, 1968

Minimalism?/ process art
  1. Richard Serra was born in 1938 in San Francisco. While working in steel mills to support himself, Serra attended the University of California at Berkeley and Santa Barbara from 1957 to 1961, receiving a BA in English literature. 
  2. From 1968 to 1970 he executed a series of Splash pieces, in which molten lead was splashed or cast into the junctures between floor and wall.
  3. His works from the mid to late 1960s were intended to express the actions of “process.” In so doing, they demonstrate the deployment of basic procedures that activate the primary qualities of media derived from construction and industrial fabrication, such as fiberglass and vulcanized rubber.
  4. The production of a splash/cast work occurs in a series of basic steps. Tearing pieces of lead from industrial rolls, Serra heats them. He then transfers the molten lead from the pot and deposits it along the juncture of wall and floor. The artist has described the procedure as a largely methodical one that advances “ladleful by ladleful,” beginning at one end of the wall and finishing at the other. When the lead cools, it bonds to the site, converting the juncture into a kind of container, a mold for the lead.
  5. This interaction locks the work into a dependent relation to the space of the room. In some cases, the cooled lead is pulled away from the wall and displayed on the floor as an autonomous object—a cast.
  6. In assigning titles to the works from molten lead, Serra sometimes observes a strict distinction between the separate functions of “splash” and “cast.” The first work in the sequence (the one made at Castelli Warehouse) is called Splashing; images of it show that it consisted of a single continuous deposit of lead.
  7. The series also demonstrates Serra's evolving interest in site-specificity, as well as his preoccupation with the natural force of gravity, both of which have retained their importance in most of Serra's subsequent work.

Mario Merz, Giap Igloo—If the Enemy Masses His Forces, He Loses Ground; If He Scatters, He Loses Strength, 1968
Centre Pompidou, Paris

Arte Povera
  1. During the Second World War, Merz was involved with the anti-Fascist group Giustizia e Libertà (Justice and Liberty), leading to his arrest and imprisonment in 1945. He occupied himself by drawing on the humblest materials, including bread and cheese wrappers. 
  2. Throughout the 1950s, while in Italy, Merz worked in opposition to both the angst of the Informel and the earnest Socialist Realism espoused by his Communist compatriot Renato Guttuso. Instead, he invoked dispassionate images executed using industrial materials such as enamel and spray paint. In 1966, Merz moved away from painting, and instead started to penetrate bottles, umbrellas and raincoats with neon tubes to simultaneously imbue them with energy and destroy their functionality.
  3. Arte Povera was christened in 1967, and advocated the use of impoverished (abject?) and often ephemeral materials. Proponents included Mario Merz, Marisa Merz, Jannis Kounellis, and Michelangelo Pistoletto. 
  4. 1968, with its riots, demonstrations and strikes in Italy, France, and elsewhere, marked Merz’s adoption of what would become his signature form: the igloo. Igloo di Giap ("Giap Igloo") was the first of these, made from clay in plastic bags and neon (over a metal armature). Like other works that year, it references the uprisings. It bears a phrase inscribed in neon (another of Merz’s hallmarks) from the North Vietnamese military strategist General Vo Nguyen Giap: "Se il nemico si concentra perde terreno se il disperde perde forza" ("If the enemy masses his forces, he loses ground; if he scatters, he loses strength"). 
  5. The contradiction inherent in this phrase captures Merz’s conception of the igloo as a momentary shelter that, despite its perpetual relocation, remains a constant. Merz often used materials indigenous to the sites of his exhibitions to reinforce the nomadic essence of the igloo and its references to a “humble economic system close to nature” (according to the Guggenheim).

Joseph Beuys, The Pack, 1969
Staatliche Kunstammlungen Kassel, Neue Galerie, Germany

German Neo-Avant Garde
1. A major figure of the postwar German avant-garde, Joseph Beuys viewed art as a vehicle for social change (called his work “social sculptures”). Beuys counted debate and teaching as part of his art and was a leader in many socioeconomic reform movements (co-founder of German Green Party).
2. This strongly autobiographical work refers directly to Beuys’s plane crash over the Crimea during WWII. He often described being rescued by a band of Tartars who coated his body with fat and wrapped him in felt. Whether real or mythical, the story shows the symbolic importance of these materials in Beuys’s mind. It also suggests a fable of death and rebirth in which Beuys is purged (perhaps of his wartime guilt), and brought back to life by a nomadic people.
3. In The Pack, 24 sledges, resembling a pack of dogs, tumble from the back of a VW van. Each sledge carries a survival kit made up of a roll of felt for warmth and protection, a lump of animal fat for energy and sustenance, and a torch for navigation and orientation.
4. The Pack also bears some resemblance to the equipment of a military assault force or commando unit and in this way might assume a decidedly more aggressive than pacifist character: the sleds could also stand for the invasion of US troops in Vietnam, for police force used against student demonstrations in Milan, etc.
5. The VW—that symbol of Germany’s Wirtschaftswunder—appears to spew out the sleds like rats leaving a sinking ship; sleds, a more primitive means of transportation, suggesting that the marvels of modern consumer culture will not save us.
6. Through his artworks, Beuys sought to rehumanize both art and life by drastically narrowing the gap between the two. In this way, his project bore a kinship with that of the Fluxus artists, and in 1962, he was briefly an official member, but by the end of 1965 he had severed relations with the group, not finding the work sufficiently effective: “They held a mirror up to people without indicating how to change anything.”
7. The Pack was included at the 1979 Beuys retrospective at the Guggenheim, the first comprehensive show of his work in the United States.

Eva Hesse, Contingent, 1969
National Gallery of Australia, Canberra

Postminimalism / Process Art
  1. Hesse’s (b. Germany 1936-1970) Contingent is made of eight banner-like elements that hang from the ceiling. Each component is a large rectangular stretch of latex-covered cheesecloth embedded at each end in a translucent field of fiberglass. The units hang parallel to each other and at right angles to the wall. They appear as ‘skins lifted off the surface of a painting’, magically suspended in midair, a merging of light, colour, and gravity. Contingent blurs the boundaries between painting and sculpture; it is, in the artist’s terminology, a ‘non-work’ which exists as a ‘hung painting in another material than painting.’ By virtue of its hybrid form, Contingent, more than any of Hesse’s other works, successfully synthesises the qualities of both disciplines.
  2. In her constructions of latex, fiberglass and cheesecloth, Hesse evokes the body in extreme, visceral ways without ever imaging the body itself. As Briony Fer has written, “Hesse’s work may bear the marks of the body, or have bodily connotations, without being of the body, and without being symbols in the sense of individual forms standing in for parts of the body.”
  3. As Lucy Lippard had described, Hesse’s art stages “a forthright confrontation of incongruous physical and formal attributes: hardness/softness, roughness/smoothness, precision/chance, geometry/free form, toughness/vulnerability, ‘natural’ surface/industrial construction.” Contingent plays with all these oppositions and more in a way that renders then unstable, insistently material and metaphorical at once. Of particular contrast in this work is the liquid malleability of latex with the heavier, more brittle fiberglass creating a palpable material tension, the fiberglass pulling taught the latex midsections.
  4. In her use of latex, which decays over time, she knowingly created an ephemeral work, implying dynamism in her very use of materials.
  5. The work engages Minimalism forms like the grid and the cube as well as Postminimalist strategies of binding, hanging, dispersing. By internalizing these artistic languages, Hesse was able to transform them, introducing messy carnal associations into their clean conceptual assumptions.
Lynda Benglis, Bounce, 1969

Process art 

1.     Lynda Benglis was raised in Louisiana and moved to New York in 1964, where she trained as a painter in the Abstract Expressionist vein. Benglis admired the gestural style of the older generation of artists, but quickly began to adapt their methods to more extravagant ends. 
2.     In the late 1960s, Benglis became fascinated by the interrelationships of painting and sculpture and used Process as a route not only to new form but also new content. She invented a new format with her celebrated “pours” which resembled paintings but came off the wall to occupy the space of sculpture.
3.     Her works were created by pouring liquid rubber directly onto the floor. Instead of shaping it with a mold, she allowed the material to seek its own form. The swirls of the liquid retain a look of arrested motion, and their colors are gelled into a kind of psychedelic carpet. 
4.     Rejecting vertical orientation– as well as canvas, stretcher, and brush– the pours push the conventions of easel paintings to the point of near collapse. Her works extend Pollock’s drip technique into three dimensions. 
5.     Summarising her ambitions in the 1960s, she stated, “I wasn’t breaking away from painting but trying to redefine what it was.” Alongside peers like Eva Hesse and Richard Serra, she allowed the process of making to dictate the shape of her finished works, wielding pliant matter that “can and will take its own form.”

Michael Heizer, Double Negative, 1969‐70, Nevada
The Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles

Earthwork / Land Art

  1. In his monumental excavations, geometric paintings, and drawings, Heizer explores the relationship between positive and negative space, considering the profound effects of form and scale, and evoking feelings of awe and dread that constitute the sublime. He was influenced by accompanying his father on anthropological field work in rural California, Nevada, Peru, and Bolivia.
  2. By the late 1960s, artists responding to Minimalism and Conceptualism removed art from the gallery and society by fixing it in uninhabited nature as huge, immobile, often "permanent" Land or Earthworks.
  3. Land art encouraged a hyperawareness of the conditions of production, presentation, and distribution among those who engaged with it. Commissioned by art dealer Virginia Dwan and with the aid of a local realtor, Bryant Robison, Heizer drilled, dynamited and dug two trenches with bulldozers.  Double Negative's site is in the Moapa Valley near Overton, Nevada.
  4. Heizer and his construction team sliced up the surface of the Mormon Mesa and made two cuts facing one another across a deep indentation to create a site 1,500 feet long, 30 feet wide and 50 feet deep.  
  5. Two trenches straddle either side of a natural canyon (into which the excavated material was dumped). The "negative" in the title thus refers to both the natural and man-made negative space that constitutes the work. The work consists of what is not there, what has been displaced.
  6. The void provides an experience of great vastness, enclosing the space rather than displacing it. The viewer is inside, surrounded by the work, instead of outside and in confrontation with it.
  7. In Nevada, Heizer found "that kind of unraped, peaceful, religious space artists have always tried to put in their work."
  8. Dave Hickey: “It’s a sophisticated and intellectual idea based on the idea that in the West, positive and negative space is reversed. Instead of extending the earth up, he extended the sky down. It’s what I consider to be the best solution for outdoor sculpture in the West because you can’t beat the sky.” 
  9. Dwan gifted it to MoCA LA in 1985. The museum agreed to undertake no conservation of the piece as Heizer indicated that nature should eventually reclaim the land through weather and erosion.

Robert Smithson, Spiral Jetty
Great Salt Lake, Utah, 1970

Earth Art
  1. Robert Smithson (1938 – 1973) was an American artist known for sculpture and land art who often used drawing and photography in relation to the spatial arts. 
  2. Smithson moved from gallery installations back to site works and discovered a major inspiration in Utah’s Great Salt Lake, which the artist saw as “an impassive faint violet sheet held captive in a stony matrix, upon which the sun poured down its crushing light.”
  3. He deposited 6,000 tons (6,096 tonnes) of earth into the lake, forming an enormous raised spiral. 
  4. Spiral Jetty has disappeared—and reappeared—periodically amidst the changing water levels of the Great Salt Lake. The films and photographs that document the piece now provide the only reliable access to it.
  5.  "Land art" expanded boundaries of art by the materials used and the siting of the works. The materials used were often the materials of the Earth including for instance the soil and rocks and vegetation and water found on-site, and the siting of the works were often distant from population centers.
  6. Concerns of the art movement centered around rejection of the commercialization of art-making and enthusiasm with an emergent ecological movement.

Duane Hanson, Tourists, 1970
National Gallery of Scotland, Edinburgh

Hyperrealism
  1. Hanson’s earliest life-casts, which date from the late 1960s, had an overtly political edge, but in 1970 he began casting ordinary people doing nothing in particular: reading, shopping, hanging about. Like Andy Warhol, Hanson saw boredom and banality as key characteristics of post-war, consumer society (although the bored affect is perhaps a modern rather than postwar condition - see Neue Sachlichkeit.)
  2. This work is Polyester resin and fibreglass, painted in oil, and mixed media. The figures are dressed in real clothing, carrying an actual camera, binoculars, and handbag. Their clothing marks them as temporally-specific, rooted in the 1970s.
  3. Because of their materiality the figures are somewhat reminiscent of mannequins (we might think of the Dada and Surrealist fascination with mannequins, and Atget’s photographs of shop windows.) Rather than the idealized bodies of most mannequins, however, these figures have the lumps and bumps of real people. 
  4. Although these two figures are presented as a couple, they were cast from life, one after the other, and never met.
  5. Building on the legacy of Minimalism, which shared a real space with the viewer, these works have no clear delineation between viewer and artwork. Unlike minimalism (obviously?) they are preoccupied with simulation. 
  6. Simulation was a key tenet of Jean Baudrillard’s theory of the hyperreal - it’s a little anachronistic to apply Simulacra and Simulations here but let’s take a crack at it anyway. Baudrillard wrote, “Disneyland is there to conceal the fact that it is the ‘real’ country, all of ‘real’ America, which is Disneyland (just as prisons are there to conceal the fact that it is the social in its entirety, in its banal omnipresence, which is carceral). Disneyland is presented as imaginary in order to make us believe that the rest is real, when in fact all of Los Angeles and the America surrounding it are no longer real, but of the order of the hyperreal and of simulation. It is no longer a question of a false representation of reality (ideology), but of concealing the fact that the real is no longer real, and thus of saving the reality principle.”
Fun fact: Hanson lived in Florida, which - honestly totally tracks. Baudrillard would fucking love this guy.
Bruce Nauman, Green Light Corridor, 1970

Post-minimalist installation
1. Using an array of media including video installation, performance, sculpture, and photography, Nauman is known for conceptual works that explore space, language, and the body. Nauman infuses his pieces with irony and humor, creating verbal and visual puns to often unsettling effect, challenging viewers and making them aware of their own physicality.
2. If anything links Nauman’s diverse artistic endeavors since the mid-60s, it is his insistence that aesthetic experience supersedes the actual object in importance. His work takes an interest in perception itself, the viewer’s encounter with his or her body and mind in relation to the art object.
3. In the 1970s, Nauman started producing experimental films that investigate body positioning and performance in his studio. Corridors and rooms, which served as props for his digital products, later appeared in museums and galleries to recreate an environment for audience to participate in. Corridors were thus the first mixed product of his digital and physical works.
4. In Walk with Contrapposto (1968), a video Nauman made in his studio, the corridor width was determined by the movement of Nauman’s swaying hips. The subsequent exhibitions of the props then challenged its audience to do the same, to walk and “exercise” within the limits.
5. In contrast with the austere, Minimal fluorescent light-fixture works of Dan Flavin, Nauman’s work disarms the viewer and is intended to render them uncomfortable, evoking an experience of being locked in and of being abandoned.
6. He later introduces surveillance cameras into his corridor pieces, giving the claustrophobic spaces a more strongly political undertone.
Hans Haacke, MOMA‐Poll, 1970

Conceptual Art /  Institutional Critique
  1. For the exhibition “Information” at MoMA Haacke installed the first of his works that deals with “social systems” called Polls or Visitors’ Profiles. In these installations, Haacke subjected the processes of production and reception to elementary forms of statistical accounting and positivist information as a clear response to the actual principles governing experience in what Adorno had called the “society of administration.”
  2. The work asks visitors a question regarding the tragic and widely protested expansion of the Vietnam war into Laos and Cambodia: “Would the fact that Governor Rockefeller has not denounced President Nixon’s Indochina policy be a reason for you not to vote for him in November?” Respondents cast their votes in transparent boxes according to Yes or No, making it clear which is the more popular of the responses (YES). The work in turn prompted museum goers to question the museum’s role in this particular issue, as Governor Nelson Rockefeller was on the MoMA board.
  3. In this work Haacke repositions Conceptual art in a new critical relation to the socieoeconomic conditions determining access and availability of aesthetic experience, a practice later identified as “institutional critique”
  4. MOMA-Poll confronts the viewer with a sudden insight into the degree to which the museum as a supposedly neutral space guarding aesthetic autonomy and disinterestedness is imbricated with economic, ideological, and political interests.
  5. The work also reconstitutes a condition of responsibility and participation for the viewer that surpasses models of spectatorial involvement previously proposed. Here the spectators play an active, almost collaborative role in the creation of the artwork. At the same time however, the work recognizes the limitations of the spectators’ political aspirations and their psychic range of experience and self-determination.
  6. The work was an early and pioneering example of institutional critique, one that took place within the very institution it sought to critique, attacking from the inside. The work was accepted as a theoretical proposal and the question itself Haacke kept to himself until the night before the show opened. David Rockefeller (MoMA chairman and brother of the Governor) tried to have it taken down, but the museum director refused and was soon after fired.
Vito Acconci, Trademarks, 1970 (detail)

Performance (Body art)
1.     Vito Acconci was an American performance, video and installation artist, whose work was characterised by existential unease, exhibitionism and discomfort. By 1969, he had shift to a task model of performance, which he adapted into “performance tests” documented for an art public, first through reports and photographs and later through film and videos.
2.     Like the related performances of Bruce Nauman, Acconci subjected the body to apparently rational regimes for apparently irrational purposes. These performances did test the reflexes of his  body, but more, they exposed its mundane incompetencies to the point where a strange aggressivity against the self predominated the work. 
3.     Around 1970, Acconci began  to mark his body directly. In Trademarks, he bit into his flesh, turning it into a graphic medium of indentations, which were then inked and impressioned on to paper. 
4.     This is a reductio ad absurdum of  the autographic mark in art: as an act of absolute self-possession; “to claim what’s mine,” in his words.
5.     However, the mark further  splits Acconci into an active subject and passive object– a self-alienation deepened by the suggestion of a sadistic-masochistic polarity in play, as well as by the implication of the body (or of Body art) as a commodity “trademark.”

Walter de Maria, The Lightning Field 
near Quemado, New Mexico, 1970‐1977

Earthwork / Land Art
  1. In his sculptures, land works, and installations, De Maria explored the relationship between the relative and the absolute, using basic geometric components to produce sublime repetitions. By arranging forms according to mathematical sequences, he worked at the intersections of Minimalism, conceptual art, and land art—drawing attention to the limits of gallery spaces, prioritizing bodily awareness, and locating the content of an artwork in the viewer.
  2. Designed to celebrate the power and visual splendor of the natural phenomenon of lighting, the work comprises four hundred polished stainless-steel poles installed in a grid measuring one mile by one kilometer; the poles, meant to attract lightning, measure over twenty feet tall and have solid pointed tips that define a horizontal plane.
  3. Installed in a New Mexican basin ringed by mountains, the site was chosen for its limitless vista, sparse population, and frequent incidence of atmospheric electricity, offering a prime site to create a work that would involve both earth and sky, yet intrude upon neither, by articulating their trackless expanse with deliberately induced discharges of lightning.
  4. It is meant to be walked in, as well as viewed from afar and is intended to be experienced over an extended period of time.
  5. De Maria combined the pictorialness and ephemeral character of European Land art with the sublimity of scale and conception typical of American Earthworks. 
  6. Commissioned and maintained by Dia Art Foundation, it exemplifies Dia's commitment to the support of art projects whose nature and scale exceed the limits of traditional museums or galleries.
Fun fact: For the legendary group show When Attitudes Become Form, curated by Harald Szeemann in 1969, De Maria submitted an elusive black phone with a sign that read: “If this telephone rings you may answer it. Walter De Maria is on the line and would like to talk to you.” The phone never rang.
Nam June Paik and Charlotte Moorman, Concerto for TV, Cello, and Videotapes, 1971

Performative sculpture/performance
  1. Nam June Paik (1932–2006), internationally recognized as the ​“Father of Video Art,” created a large body of work including video sculptures, installations, performances, videotapes and television productions.
  2. Paik invented a new artistic medium with television and video.
  3. Both Paik and Moorman were musicians and collaborated throughout their respective careers.
  4. In TV Cello, Paik took the idea of performative sculpture further. This piece was also constructed from television picture tubes encased in Plexiglas boxes, and its screens were meant to show broadcast TV, prerecorded tape, or live, closed-circuit images, all of which could be manipulated by Moorman. But TV Cello, a proxy for Moorman’s traditional cello, was also a functioning musical instrument. 
  5. According to Moorman, it was “the first advance in cello design since 1600.” It had strings, tuning pegs, a bridge and tailpiece, and even a rudimentary peg, just like a standard cello. The strings, however, were amplified and produced crashing electronic sounds when she played it.
  6. During the 1970s, Moorman performed with TV Bra and TV Cello dozens of times, in venues ranging from museums and galleries to shopping malls and community centers. Both objects perfectly melded her brilliance as a performer with Paik’s artistic goal to “humanize technology.” They are also singular works in the history of interdisciplinary art: unprecedented fusions of sculpture, moving image, live performance, sound, and popular culture that blurred the lines between Moorman’s body and Paik’s artwork.
“What’s happening? NAM JUNE PAIK, CHARLOTTE MOORMAN, you, birth, death, love poems, television news, murder, spring, flowers, war, and income tax are happening, and you will get as much as you’re tuned up to get.”
– performance promotional materials, 1966
Hans Haacke, Shapolski et al., Manhattan Real Estate Holdings, a Real‐Time Social System, as of May 1, 1971, 1971

Conceptual Art (Institutional Critique)
  1. A landmark work of institutional critique, Hans Haacke’s (b. 1936, Germany) Shapolsky et al Manhattan Real Estate Holdings, A Real Time Social System as of May 1, 1971 chronicles the fraudulent activities of one of New York City’s largest slumlords over the course of two decades. 
  2. The work comprises 146 photographs of Manhattan apartment buildings, mostly tenements; maps of Shapolski’s holdings in Harlem and the Lower East Side; photographs and charts documenting real estate transactions; and texts with information about the location, ownership structure, and financial histories of the buildings.
  3. Haacke culled all of his data from the public record (available at the New York Public Library), adapting a neutral presentational style that resembles various contemporaneous projects in Conceptual art (and also the grid favored by Minimalism).
  4. The work led to the cancelation of Haacke's planned 1971 solo show at the museum, for which the work was commissioned, as well as the dismissal of its curator. (Said slumlord, Harry Shapolsky, may have had ties to the Guggenheim: rumors suggested that he was related to one of the board members.) The museum’s director argued that Shapolski et al was “work that violates the supreme neutrality of the work of art and therefore no longer merits the protection of the museum.”
  5. The idea of artworks’ - and museums’ - neutrality represents a privileged (and patently historically inaccurate) point-of-view. Rosalyn Deutsche argues that Haacke contrasted two types of architectural space, corresponding to two sociopolitical models of condition: the slum housing of New York’s underclass and the luxurious, oblivious “neutrality” of the uptown, exclusionary high-art institutions. 
  6. The work challenges viewers’ impulses to consider form as the initial mode of perception of visual art: the panels beg to be read. Like Minimalist works that succeed through the relation of the object to the beholder, Haacke invites and provokes a changing relationship between the reader and what is being read. (Haacke’s earlier work directly addressed Minimalist forms, undermining their integrity by subjecting them to the eroding forces of nature.

Daniel Buren, Photo­‐souvenir: “Peinture‐ Sculpture,” work in situ, at the Sixth Guggenheim International Exhibition,
Guggenheim Museum, New York, 1971

Conceptual Art
1. Buren reduced his painting to a uniform neutral and internal system of commercially printed vertical stripes, a formal practice that readily lent itself to infinite replication and exhibition in any environment. The initial concept would never have to change, and variety came not in the form itself but rather in the context: city streets, public squares, museums. The circumstances surrounding the display of art are as important as the work itself—his work thus transcending modernism’s long-standing attachment to originality and uniqueness.
2. So-called photo-souvenirs were used to document his in situ works. Buren insists that the photograph is not the work of art, but only a souvenir of the original, now lost, work.
3. Buren takes abstract and conceptual work into the public realm using the DIY technologies of fly posters and advertisement.
4. In 1971 Buren conceived one of his first largescale in situ pieces for the 6th Guggenheim International Exhibition. Peinture-Sculpture focused on the Guggenheim’s Frank Lloyd Wright architecture and the building’s orientation around an open spiral ramp. Daniel Buren’s proposal involved hanging a 66 x 32 ft / 20 x 10 m canvas banner with his signature vertical stripes in alternating blue and white, bisecting the rotunda from top to bottom. The banner could be experienced both as a painting and as a sculptural object. Emphasized the position of the viewer who circulated around the work.
5. Buren’s work engendered criticism from several other artists in the exhibition (Dan Flavin and Donald Judd), who protested that the banner blocked views across the rotunda, compromising their works. Buren, in turn, said Flavin's fluorescent lights colored his banner. The night before the opening, Buren’s banner was removed.

Richard Long, A Hundred Mile Walk, 1971‐2
Tate Gallery, London

Conceptual Art / Land Art
  1. Part of Long’s (British, b. 1945) practice involves several “Walked-line pieces” starting with this original 1967 piece A Line Made by Walking. In these works he “intervenes” in landscapes by walking through them, transforming the land he walks into art. Along the way he expresses his ideas about time, movement, and place by making small marks on the earth, e.g. “suck[ing] icicles from the grass stems.”
  2. This work records a walk he made on Dartmoor during New Year 1971-2, repeatedly following a  pre-determined circular route that he sketched out on the presented map. In the work he records his experience of sounds heard on the walk, how he became away of the presence of rivers as he approached them, pockets of sounds in gullies, and how the sound disappeared behind him as he walked on. The work incorporates both the internal feelings and thoughts of the artist and the external aspects of his experience.
  3. “Corrina, Corrina” is a reference to a song by Bob Dylan. The photograph below the text was taken during the walk, looking forward in the direction Long was walking.
  4. These works seem indebted to the instructional work of the Fluxus artists, in that the final texts works document, or perhaps even guide the action the artist’s take (unclear if he writes the text before or after doing the walk). It therefore is unclear whether the walk itself is the artwork or the text representing it is. In much of his work with the land, he broadened the idea of sculpture, photography, etc. to be a part of performance art and conceptual art.
  5. Also engages with the popular land art movement of the 1970s in which sculptors were altering or manipulating the land as artworks. Long’s work is one of the less invasive forms of land art of this group, and is far more aligned with conceptualism than that of Smithson, de Maria or Heizer. (Is it obvious how much I resent land art?)
Renzo Piano and Richard Rogers, Centre Georges Pompidou, 1971‐77

1.     The conception of the most sensational and debated building of the 1970s came from the Georges Pompidou, President of France from 1969 to 1974, who wanted to construct a cultural center in Paris that would attract visitors and be a monumental aspect of the city. Piano and Rogers (both not famous at the time) won an international competition and were chosen to be the architects of the project; their design was selected for exemplifying constructivism and a high tech modern structure. 
2.     It houses France’s national museum of modern art, a public library, an AV center, a rooftop restaurant and an internet café. The idea for a multicultural complex, bringing together in one place different forms of art and literature developed in part from the ideas of France’s first Minister of Cultural Affairs, André Malraux, a wester proponent of the decentralization of art and culture. 
3.     By making visible all the building’s mechanical and structural elements, the Pompidou Center would seem to fulfil the modernist preference for truth to materials and formal integrity. The Pompidou takes the Bauhaus pragmatism and technology as its point of departure, only to transform them into a surreal dream of pipes and trusses, marine funnels and vents, most of which festoon the exoskeleton. 
4.     Their design portrayed the museum itself as a movement. The skeleton engulfs the building from its exterior, showing all the different mechanical and structural systems, not only so they could be understood but also to maximise the interior space without interruptions. The different systems on the exterior are painted in different colors to distinguish their different roles.
5.     In its time, the design achieved a new standard in open-space flexibility. The structural and service functions were channelled along the outer walls, leaving the interior open to be freely subdivided, and suitable for a multitude of changeable institutional and public uses. 
6.     The building is considered a popular success, partly because of a five story outside escalator, whose transparent plastic tubes offer riders a moving, spectacular view of Paris and the immense open plaza below. The plaza has become a forum, like the parvis of a medieval cathedral, for artists displaying their works, jugglers, tourists and Parisians.
Richard Estes, Bus Reflections (Ansonia), 1972

Photorealism
  1. Estes is considered the foremost practitioner of the photorealists and has been celebrated as the premier painter of American cityscapes. Photorealism as the reproduction from one medium to another transfers the source image and transposes its system of perspective and visual perception; Estes often worked from two or more photos, combining them in various ways.
  2. This quintessentially Photorealist painting depicts one of his favorite landmarks, the turn-of-the-century Beaux Arts Ansonia building near his apartment in the Upper West Side, here seen from Broadway looking north, reflected on the storefront. The extraordinary detail and precision of the painting has led many to mistake it for a color photograph.  
  3. The Hotel Embassy sign functions as an axis on which the painting hinges, creating a rough symmetry. Estes throws the composition off balance by taking small pictorial liberties that are revealed in the cloud's reflection of the glass window.
  4. The image has a remarkable static, crisp quality. Besides a bus and yellow car that seem stopped at a red light, the painting includes very few signs of life—a near impossibility in daytime Manhattan; though traces of motion—transportation, transience, and time—emerge despite the snapshot conceit.
  5. The reflective glass reveals what is forward of the painting surface, achieving the effect of an inside-out world reflected from the viewer's own space.
  6. Uniformly sharp focus incorporates a vast amount of visual information; reveals the importance of the camera to this new variety of realism, as no painter could include so much information by merely studying the subject directly.
Harry Callahan, Cape Cod, 1972

1. Harry Callahan (1912–99), a friend and colleague of Siskind’s, generated photographs of such uncompromising spareness and subtlety that they often bordered on abstraction.
  2. His principal influence came from Ansel Adams and the former Bauhaus faculty at the Institute of Design in Chicago (including Moholy-Nagy), where he taught from 1946. He later founded the photography department at the Rhode Island School of Design. 
  3. Callahan worked continuously with three deeply felt personal themes—his wife, Eleanor; the urban scene; and simple, unspoiled nature. 
  4. In his later Cape Cod landscape, Callahan shifted from the isolated close-up of a motif in nature to seemingly limitless space. 
  5. This distilled view of the world, with its emphatic horizontality and nearly monochrome tonality, recalls late works by Rothko. “I think that every artist continually wants to reach the edge of nothingness,” Callahan said.
Marcel Broodthaers, “Musée d’Art Moderne, Départment des Aigles, Section des Figures,” installation at the Städtische Kunsthalle, Düsseldorf, 16 May‐9 July, 1972

Conceptual Art (Institutional Critique)
  1. Broodthaers was skeptical of the contemporary condition of the object-status (and commodity status) of the work of art. After participating in the May 1968 student uprisings in Brussels, Broodthaers continually emphasized the operations of the museum as institution in the discursive formation of the work of art, underscoring the contextuality and contiguity of the work of art (rather than its modernist autonomy) . 
  2. Broodthaers’ Musée was inaugurated in his private house-studio in Brussels in 1968. At a moment when the role of the artist as curator had relatively few precedents, the Belgian poet-turned-artist took that possibility even further, transforming himself into the artist as curator, administrator, press agent, and museum director, all in one. He created a convincing fiction, whereby he mimicked institutional approaches in the creation of no less than 12 “sections” for his ambitious museum. The first of these (Section XIXème siecle) exhibited materials used to stage museum and gallery exhibitions (eg, lamps, ladders, crates, signage)
  3. In 1972, Kunsthalle Düsseldorf director Karl Ruhrberg, together with junior curator Jürgen Harten, invited Broodthaers to install a section of the Musée at the Kunsthalle, which resulted in the creation of the “Section des Figures” (Figure Section), seen here. It was the largest and most spectacular of the sections.
  4. The artist presented more than 300 artworks from all eras and geographies including a number of new commissions (by artists including by Gerhard Richter), originating from some 50 museums and other collections, alongside a plenitude of vernacular objects and reproductions. All bore an image of the eagle (l’aigle), totaling some 500 “figures” of eagles in all. 
  5. Broodthaers listed the eagle’s attributes as “Greatness, authority, power. Divine spirit. Spirit of conquest. Imperialism.”
  6. As other Conceptual artists were rejecting the iconographic as a relic and seeking to transcend the historical strictures imposed by the museum and academy, Broodthaers reintroduced the taxonomic features and discursive formations that the museum represented as a mode of critiquing Conceptualism. Conceptualism had not, he seemed to argue, succeeded in establishing a truly egalitarian artform: Broodthaers exposed this as a typically avant-garde myth, pointing to the survival of the systems of classification and valuation that Conceptualism sought to discard. 
  7. Broodthaers’ project, Buchloh argues, was an antimodernist, conservative blague (joke): a reactionary response reasserting the contiguity of the present with the past (rather than treating the present as a rupture or break.

Christo and Jean‐Claude, Running Fence
Sonoma and Marin Counties, California 1972‐1976

Site-specific public art installation
1. Christo was born in Bulgaria, escaped from the Eastern bloc to Paris in 1957, where he met his future wife Jeanne-Claude, who became his artistic collaborator in 1961. The Christos are best known for their vast environmental projects, involving wrapping of buildings (German Reichstag in 1995) and significant portions of open nature.
2. Running Fence was made of 200,000 square meters of heavy woven white nylon fabric, hung from a steel cable strung between 2,050 steel poles stuck into the ground. The result was a luminous ribbon of white fabric undulating through fields, hills and valleys, leaving passage for cars, cattle and wildlife, finally tapering off into the Pacific Ocean. It was executed in the California coastal counties of Marin and Sonoma and stood for 2 weeks.
3. The Christos had to excel at public relations, since to carry out their epic proposals they had to secure the approval of countless public and private actors. Running Fence consisted of 42 months of collaborative efforts, the ranchers’ participation, 18 public hearings, three sessions at the Superior Courts of California, a 450-page Environmental Impact Report and the temporary use of the hills, the sky and the ocean. They hired 65 skilled workers and 350 students (project could be understood as a proto-delegated performance).
4. All expenses ($3.2 million) were paid by Christo and Jeanne-Claude through the sale of studies, preparatory drawings and collages, scale models and original lithographs. The artists did not accept sponsorship of any kind.
5. All parts of Running Fence’s structure were designed for complete removal and no visible evidence of Running Fence remains on the hills of Sonoma and Marin Counties.
Daniel Buren, Within and Beyond the Frame, 1973 (detail)

Conceptual Art / Institutional Critique
  1. By the early 70s Buren had reduced his painting practice to a type of readymade: canvases cut from commercially produced gray and white striped awning material (used for awnings on French state office bulidings) which he would “personalize” by hand-painting over one of the stripes at the edge of the swatch.
  2. For this installation at John Weber Gallery in New York, he ran the canvases through the gallery and out the window across the width of the street as a king of bannerlike advertisement for the exhibition. The “painting” extended almost 200 feet.
  3. In this work he challenged the power of frames by refusing to leave their presuppositions alone, implicit, unremarked. The frame referred to in the title was the institutional frame of the gallery, a frame that functions to guarantee rarity, authenticity, originally, uniqueness (among other attributes) of the objects it encloses. These values are what separates art from other objects in our culture, but are also the values to which a gallery attaches a price, in an act that erases any fundamental difference between what it has to sell and the merchandize of any other commercial space.
  4. As the paintings breach the limits of the gallery, Buren seems to ask his viewered at what point they cease to be “paintings” and start being another system of objects: flags, sheets hung out to dry, advertisement for the show, carnival bunting.
Gordon Matta‐Clark, Splitting, 1974

Anarchitecture
1.     Matta-Clark is best known for his bold, unconventional photographs, films and sculptures relating to the built environment. He studied architecture at Cornell University and which he moved to New York and became a well-known figure among artists in the burgeoning avant-garde scene centered in Soho. 
2.     Matta-Clark’s principal contribution was as a radical sculptor. He is recognized for his series of building-cuts, in which he carved out sections of entire structures, treating them as spatial compositions. 
3.     Calling these transformations as “Anarchitecture” he documented them in films and photographs that were subsequently exhibited in galleries, often alongside fragments of the buildings themselves. 
4.     One of his most celebrated sculptures consisted of a vertical slice into an old frame house located in Englewood, New Jersey. The home, owned by New York art dealer Holly Solomon, was slated for demolition. 
5.     The resulting film is composed of intentionally artless footage showing Matta-Clark and his friends making two parallel cuts down the center of the house; jacking up one half of the structure and beveling the cinderblock supporting it; and then lowering that half back down, bisecting the home and creating an ephemeral display of light inside the once-compartmentalized interior. 
6.     The movie’s documentary style is the result of the artist’s dramatically physical approach to filmmaking. It reveals Matta-Clark as a daredevil, climbing around a structure that has nothing but a few jacks preventing it from collapse. The sequences, which study the light effects produced by the building cut, reveal a domestic space transformed into a sundial on a grand scale.
7.     After the creation of the work, Matta-Clark  arranged for select members of the art community to travel by bus to the home. They were able to see it first-hand, wander around the home and jump across the gaps. Three months later the house was demolished. While the majority of his projects were meant to exist only temporarily, films such as Splitting preserve the ephemeral nature of his approach and also remain as important works of art in their own right.

Judy Chicago, The Dinner Party, 1974‐79
The Brooklyn Museum of Art

Feminist art / Installation art
  1. Chicago is an artist, author, feminist, educator, and intellectual whose career spans five decades. 
  2. The Dinner Party, an icon of 1970s feminist art and a milestone in twentieth-century art, comprises a massive ceremonial banquet, arranged on a triangular table (a geometric form responding to Minimalism) with a total of 39 place settings, each commemorating a historical female figure.
  3. The settings, executed in stereotypically feminine media, consist of embroidered runners, gold chalices and utensils, and china-painted porcelain plates with raised central motifs that are based on vulvar and butterfly forms and rendered in styles appropriate to the individual women being honored.
  4. The names of another 999 women are inscribed in gold on the white tile floor below the table. This permanent installation is enhanced by rotating exhibitions relating to the 1,038 women honored at the table.
  5. The 13 place settings on each side of the table make a wry comment on the Last Supper, replacing the all-male dinner party with women.
  6. Through an unprecedented worldwide grass-roots movement, The Dinner Party was exhibited in 16 venues in 6 countries on 3 continents to an audience of over one million people. It is permanently housed in the Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art at the Brooklyn Museum.
  7. Chicago’s goal was to introduce the richness of women’s heritage and "end the ongoing cycle of omission in which women were written out of the historical record." Her original concept was tripartite: a monumental work of art, a book, and a film because she had discovered so much unknown information that challenged the male-centered canon. She recently published a final, updated book, The Dinner Party: Restoring Women to History (The Monacelli Press, 2014). 
  8. Early on it endured critical dismissal for essentializing and defining each woman by her anatomy, and for visualizing female power as phallic energy in drag, “a lumbering mishmash of sleaze and cheese.”
Charles Moore, Piazza d’Italia, New Orleans, 1975‐9

Postmodern architecture/ installation
  1. Another student of Louis I. Kahn at the University of Pennsylvania and a close ally of Venturi and Scott Brown was Charles Moore (1925–93), who looked not so much to Las Vegas for inspiration as to Disneyland, praising it as an outstanding public space as well as an embodiment of the American Dream. 
  2. Concerned with the commercial or industrial sameness of the postwar world, and with it the lost “sense of place” that leaves so many American cities looking like Los Angeles, Moore became even more overtly historicist than Venturi and was fully committed to “the making of places.” In this, he often favored the “presence of the past” found in a Roman or Mediterranean kind of environment.
  3. One of the most remarkable examples of how imaginatively he could develop this theme is the Piazza d’Italia in New Orleans. Here he designed a public space to provide a small Italian-American community with an architectural focus of ethnic identity 
  4. Piazza d’Italia is an early example of the playful Postmodern use of classical forms. 
  5. An entirely decorative and symbolic construction, it is architecture that abandons the aim for permanence. Collaborating with architects well versed in the local culture, Moore took into account not only the taste and habits of the area’s inhabitants, but also the different styles of buildings around the new piazza. Thus, while the design incorporated the black-and-white lines of an adjacent modernist skyscraper in a graduated series of concentric rings, the circular form itself—essentially Italian Baroque in character—reflects the local community. 
  6. At staggered intervals on either side of a cascading fountain at the Piazza d’Italia are various column screens representing the five classical orders, the outermost and richest one, Corinthian, crowned by polished stainless-steel capitals supporting an entablature emblazoned with dedicatory Latin inscriptions. Over the waterfall stands a triumphal arch, polychromed in Pompeiian hues and outlined in neon tubing. With its eclectic mixture of historical reference and pure fantasy, such as water coursing down pilasters to suggest fluting, water spouts serving as Corinthian leaves, and stainless-steel Ionic volutes sitting on neon necking, Piazza d’Italia combines archeology, modernism, commerce, and theater to provide something for everyone—and above all a sense of place unlikely ever to be confused with another.

Jörg Immendorff, Café Deutschland 1, 1977‐78
Ludwig‐Forum für Internationale Kunst, Aachen

Neo-Expressionism / Socialist Realists
  1. Jörg Immendorff (B. 1945, Germany) was the Neo-Expressionist artist who most directly sought to reconcile his art with social activism, wrestling with the political divide within contemporaneous Germany within which the individual was trapped. 
  2. Café Deutschland is a series of 16 paintings by Immendorff, of which this is the first. This work demonstrates the influence of earlier German Expressionism (such as the work of Ernst Ludwig Kirchner) in the distorted perspective and use of 
  3. The space is that of a nightmarish underground nightclub, where all the people and objects refer to the divided Germany of the 1970s. At the left, the eagle of the German Democratic Republic grasps a swastika in its talons. 
  4. In the center of the painting is the artist himself. Behind him is the reflective surface of another column in which we can make out the silhouette of the Brandenberg Gate, dividing East and West Berlin. The artist holds his paintbrush in his left hand, while his right hand smashes through the "Berlin Wall," attempting to reach through to the other side.
The artist employed the heroic scale and representational imagery of Socialist Realism, a style applauded in East Germany but considered retrograde and suspect by his contemporaries at the Art Academy in Düsseldorf (West Germany), including his teacher, Joseph Beuys.

James Stirling with Michael Wilford,
Neue Staatsgalerie, Stuttgart, Germany 1977‐84

Postmodern Architecture
1. Already one of Britain’s most important architects in the 1960s, when he worked in a somewhat Brutalist vein, Stirling seems to have been liberated by Postmodernism into full possession of his own expansive genius.
2. For the Neue Staatsgalerie, Stirling took advantage of the freedom allowed by the revisionist aesthetics to solve the manifold problems presented by a difficult hillside site, hemmed in below by an 8-lane highway, above by a terraced street, and on one side by the original Renaissance Revival museum building.
3. The museum is a series of integrations, both contextual  with the site and periods of art and design.
4. Stirling decided to work in “a collage of old and new elements”: the three main exhibition wings repeat the U-shaped plan of the 19th century Renaissance Revival structure next door; external impression is that of a massive Egyptian structure, ramped from level to level like the funerary temple of the Old Kingdom Queen Hatshepsut; the building is faced with sandstone and travertine strips more suggestive of medieval Italy; these contrast with the bright pink and blue colored steel pipes and handrails, modern industrial materials.
5. Visually, the ramps and the masonry unify a jumble of disparate forms. Despite so many historical references and such diverse configurations, a sense of unity and distinctive place characterizes the building.
6. The Neue Staatsgalerie has been hailed as the epitome of postmodern architecture, rooted in the combination of historical elements with a modern vocabulary
Cindy Sherman, Untitled Film Still #21, 1978

Feminist photography?
  1. In her work Sherman combines the arts of Performance and photography, casting herself as the star of an inventive series of still photographs called Untitled Film Stills sometimes characterized as “one frame movie-making.” Complete with props, lighting, makeup, costume and script, most of the pictures exploited, with the eventual goal of subverting, stereotypical fame roles appropriated from popular culture (tv shows, advertisements etc.)
  2. In all of the 69 images in the series, Sherman presents a female heroine from a movie we feel we must have seen. Here she is the pert young career girl in a trim new suit on her first day in the big city.
  3. Only a handful of the stills are modeled directly on particular roles in actual movies, let alone individual stills. They are inventive allusions to generic types, and so our sure sense of recognition is all the more telling. In this way, Sherman not only examines the social construction of womanhood, but causes us to question our reliance on images and the authority they wield.
  4. In this image, Sherman does not depict herself as a fully self-possessed person, she exists in relation to something that is outside our frame of reference (outside the frame of the image itself).  
  5. Sherman’s images undermine the expected dynamic of the woman/model/subject being revealed through representation by the man/artist/observer. Not only is she the artist and the model—the watcher and the watched—but, as a subject, her identity is never secure. In this act, Sherman questions the notion of authorship, speaking to what Foucault and Barthes had analyzed in the 50s and 60s as “the death of the author.”
Frank O. Gehry, Gehry House, Santa Monica, California, 1979

1.     The Gehry Residence was originally an extension, designed by Gehry and built around an existing Dutch colonial style house. In 1977, Frank and Berta Gehry bought a pink bungalow originally built in 1920. It is considered to be one of the earliest deconstructivist buildings, although Gehry denies this association.
2.     In 1978, he chose to wrap the outside of the house with a new exterior while still leaving the old exterior visible; “I loved the idea of leaving the house intact. I came up with the idea of building the new house around it.” His solution was the involved a “balance of fragment and whole, raw and refined, new and old.” The house makes use of unconventional materials such as chain-link fences and corrugated steel. Gehry wanted to explore materials he was already using in his work.
3.     Gehry’s design wrapped around  three sides of the old house on the ground floor, extending the house towards the street. He hardly touched the rear and south faces and to the other sides of the house, he wedged in tilted glass cubes. 
4.     The interior went through a considerable amount of changes on both of its levels. In some areas, it was stripped to reveal the framing, exposing joists and wood studs. It was built to  show both old and new elements. This is especially evident when walking through the rooms of  the house, and passing by both new doors placed by Gehry and older ones originally in the house.
5.     The entrance is barely discernible amidst the jutting angles of the exterior. The  apex of the old house peeks out from within this mix of materials, giving the impression that the house is consistently under construction.
Leon Golub, Mercenaries (IV), 1980

Realism / Activist Art

  1. Golub was an American painter and antiwar activist known for his unflinching depictions of brutality and war, and the complex dynamics of power, violence, and politics. His emphasis on social awareness and his self-defined style of "barbaric realism" produced raw, awkward figurative works whose brute shapes with eroded surfaces serve to further his main theme, man's inhumanity to man. His work achieves the gravitas of great history painting and asserts its modernity through its power of protest linked to current events.
  2. Golub began painting expressionistic, but anonymous figures, solitary or engaged in existential struggles. He turned to the specificity of the Vietnam War after a six-year stay in Paris, from 1959 to 1964, where he and his wife, painter Nancy Spero, sought a more receptive climate for socially committed, figurative painting than the American art scene dominated by Abstract Expressionism and Pop.
  3. Mercenaries IV is from a series of the same name (1975-1987), where Golub responds to the unbridled authority and large-scale human rights abuses committed by covert American military actions, former Green Berets, and death squads in Central and South America. He was concerned with these groups because they often worked on behalf of governments that had been installed or supported by the CIA.
  4. In this massive painting, 10 x 19 ft (3x5.8m), a group of black and white soldiers stand combat ready, waiting for action. But there is an underlying menace in the taunting posture of a white soldier toward the black soldiers, who stand around, one smoking, others edgily watching, which shows where the power lies.
  5. The rigid figures, flattened like cut-outs against a solid-red-oxide background that denies retreat into an illusionistic distance, confront and overwhelm the viewer. Golub’s monumental figures are drawn from Greek pediment sculptures, Etruscan and Roman art, large-scale French history painting, and a vast media archive he amassed over forty years.
  6. Golub's technique mimicked the physical violence he depicted. Laying his huge, unstretched canvas on the floor, he built up his figures with acrylic paint, then poured solvent on top and scraped it down, sometimes using a meat cleaver, "skinning the canvas," until only a raw, eroded paint film remained. The process resulted in a highly tactile finish that has a subtle, but disturbing reference to raw flesh and wounded skin.
  7. He was a moralist in the tradition of Daumier, Georges Rouault and Max Beckmann, working in a realist/expressionist manner to show brutality, oppression, and conflict.
Michael Graves, Portland Building, 1980‐1983

Postmodern architecture
  1. The Portland Building, by architect and product designer Michael Graves, is considered the first major built work of Postmodernist architecture. 
  2. The design, which displays numerous symbolic elements on its monumental facades, stands in purposeful contrast to the functional Modernist architecture that was dominant at the time. 
  3. In 1979 the City of Portland sponsored a competition for the design of the Portland Service Building, located on a 40,000 square-foot block in downtown Portland. The young Graves submitted his ambitious design. Graves’ colorful low-cost design impressed the jury, who discarded his competitors' costly glass and concrete designs, and awarded Graves the commission, knowing the design was bound to put Portland on the map—which it did.
  4. The building attempts to create a continuum between past and present: 
  5. It’s a symmetrical block with four off-white, stucco-covered rectangular facades featuring reinterpreted Classical elements, such as over-scaled keystones, pilasters and belvederes. 
  6. The building is set on a two-story base, reminiscent of a Greek pedestal, which divides it into the Classical three-part partition of base-body-top. Furthermore, Graves added symbolism through color—green for the ground, blue for the sky, etc—in order to visually tie the building to its environment and location. 
  7. Met with MIXED REVIEWS. The building was criticized for “superficially” incorporating a traditional aesthetic without allowing said traditional elements to be functional. For example, although the design incorporates arcades, which conventionally provide a sheltered, interstitial space between the pedestrian and the city, the arcades that line the three facades of the Portland Building have only two entries set above street level, making them difficult to access.
Fun fact: Graves said, “I thought, ‘Why are they so upset?’ Modernism has given them a choice between vertical and horizontal, white, gray or black. Come on.” (My note: Why do I simultaneously hate and kind of like this weird monstrosity of a building?)
Barbara Kruger, Your Gaze Hits the Side of My Face, 1981

Pop Art / Feminist Postmodernism / Conceptual Art (?)
  1. Like Andy Warhol and Sherrie Levine, Kruger engaged in the appropriation of imagery and strategies of design from popular culture and art history as a means of critiquing of modern media culture. 
  2. In the fall of 1976, Kruger abandoned art making and moved to Berkeley, where she taught at the University of California for four years and steeped herself in the writings of Walter Benjamin and Roland Barthes. Beginning in 1977, she produced a series of black-and-white details of architectural exteriors paired with her own textual ruminations on the lives of those living inside. Published as an artist’s book, Picture/Readings (1979) foreshadows the aesthetic vocabulary Kruger developed in her mature work.
  3. By 1979, Kruger stopped taking photographs and began to employ found images in her art (mostly from mid-century American print-media sources) with words superimposed directly over them. In this case, she has pulled a photograph of a sculpture from a 1950s photo annual. 
  4. Kruger worked as a graphic designer at Mademoiselle in the mid-1960s, and here, her work inhabits the look of a glossy magazine layout: freely cropping and captioning pictures in order to make them conform to a story. In Your Gaze, Kruger exposes the ways that our response to images is shaped (framed?) by the editorializing of its presenter. 
  5. Kruger’s work addresses the relationship between desire and consumerism. The inclusion of personal pronouns in works like Your Gaze and Untitled (I Shop Therefore I Am) (1987) implicates viewers and confounding any clear notion of who is speaking. 
  6. Like Jenny Holzer, Kruger’s works have been distributed widely on consumer products, confusing the boundaries between art and commerce, and addressing the role of advertising (and, relatedly, slogans) in the public sphere.

Sandro Chia, The Idleness of Sisyphus, 1981
The Museum of Modern Art, New York

Italian Neo-Expressionism
1. The second European nation (aside from Germany) to foster a substantial Neo-Expressionist movement was Italy. Called the transavanguardia, Italian artists of the 1970s and 80s found in painting and Italian classicism, two traditions disregarded since World War II, the ingredients for a contemporary movement.
2. Neo-Expressionism sought to emphasize bold color and representation in reaction to Conceptual Art and Minimalism.
3. Chia, a Florentine who subsequently relocated to New York, relied on the ersatz Neoclassicism practiced during the Fascist 1920s and 30s by artists such as Giorgio de Chirico. Chia parodied his sources by adopting the older painter’s conventions—their absurdly muscle-bound nudes and self-consciously mythic situations—but inflating the figures to balloon proportions while reducing the overblown narratives to the scale of fairytales.
4. Just as appealing as the comic amplitude of these harmless giants is the Mediterranean warmth of Chia’s color and the nervous energy of his painterly surfaces.
5. In The Idleness of Sisyphus, Chia’s injects contemporary citizens into classical themes, in this case a bureaucrat, dressed in contemporary fashion (complete with fedora), rolling a stone up a hill. It can be read as a representation of the Kafkaesque futility of bureaucracy where the work is ongoing and nothing ever gets done.

Robert Mapplethorpe
Agitto, 1981

1. In the 1980s, Mapplethorpe photographed a series featuring Black men, published under the titled “Black Book” in 1986. Like his early sex pictures, they are the product of erotic fixation.
  2. His treatment of the black body has been criticized as exoticizing and racially fetishizing. This is one of four images of an African American model named Ajitto, whom Mapplethorpe positioned on a pedestal and photographed from all four sides. This treatment can be likened to the treatment of the racialized body in ethnographic photography, or merely the reduction of the black body to an aesthetic object, hardly differentiated in their treatment from his still life images of flowers.
  3. Some have argued, however, that in his photographs he invested homosexuality with grandeur, masculinity and enviable nobility. By rendering societies “underbelly” beautiful, he pulled those considered degenerate out from the shadows and gave them a stage.
  4. Mapplethorpe was interested in breaking the boundaries between high art and the “low art” of pornography, even referring to some of his work as pornographic. In his work he aimed to arouse the viewer while maintaining his photographs’ status as “high art.”
  5. The two profile shots clearly recall Hippolyte Flandrin’s popular 1836 painting, Nude Youth Sitting by the Sea. These ones however were highly controversial due to the visibility of the model’s genitalia.  
  6. His depiction of the human form in formal compositions reflects his love of classical sculpture and his groundbreaking marriage of those aesthetics with often challenging subject matter. Mapplethorpe's style is present regardless of subject matter — from erotic nudes to self-portraits and flowers — as he ceaselessly strove for what he called "perfection of form."

Julian Schnabel, The Sea, 1981
The Saatchi Collection, London

American Neo-Expressionism
1.     The artist most often credited with reviving the 1980s art scene in New York was the Brooklyn born, Texas educated Julian Schnabel. Schnabel’s grand-scale, thematic pictures– reviving the whole panoply of religious and cultural archetypes once the glory of traditional high art– had an electrifying effect.
2.     In a move both innovative and violently expressive, Schnabel incorporated three dimensions into a flat surface in works such as The Sea, by embedding broken crockery in a reinforced wood support. 
3.     The idea for this process came to him during a visit to Barcelona, where he saw Antoni Gaudi’s tiled mosaic benches in Güell Park. However, rather than smooth and inlaid, Schnabel’s shards project from the surface in an irregular, disjunctive arrangement that visually functions, edge to edges, as a field of pointillist dots.
4.     At the same that the china pieces serve to define shapes and even model form, they also break up the image and absorb it into the overall surface flicker like a primitive, encrusted version of the Art Nouveau figure-in-pattern effect of Gustav Klimt, Guadi’s Austrian contemporary.
5.     By painting over, around or even under the protruding ceramic, Schnabel created every kind of pictorial drama from evocations of folkloric wit and charm to suggestions of mythic ritual. The emotive effect of his work arise less from the image, which is not immediately decipherable, than from an audacious stylistic process, that simultaneously structures and shatters the surface.

Richard Serra, Tilted Arc, 1981 
Federal Plaza, New York (dismantled In 1989)

Postminimalism

  1. Serra is a Post-minimalist artist known for his monumental steel sculptures that often provoke dizziness and disorientation as viewers walk through their winding passages. Though he also makes paintings and prints, Serra’s attention to materiality has been the hallmark of his practice. His exploration of the properties of unconventional materials—such as molten lead and vulcanized rubber—gradually increased the scale of his work.
  2. Tilted Arc was commissioned by the U.S. General Services Administration (GSA), as part of its “Art-in-Architecture” program, which commissioned permanent artworks for new government buildings. It was a site specific, public sculpture, 12-foot-tall, 120-foot-long, 15-ton steel slab that cut across Federal Plaza in Lower Manhattan.
  3. Instead of focusing on the optical experience of sculpture, looking at it from afar, Serra wanted passers-by to experience the sculpture in a physical way, to alter their experience of the space as they moved to and from the surrounding government buildings. His works, rather than complementing their settings, often oppose them, with right-angled forms in nature and sinuous ones against angular architecture. Some feel mazelike, they rhyme exquisite engineering with brute materiality.
  4. The long, curving metal sheet looked graceful when viewed from its ends but faced anyone emerging from the building with a grim wall and cancelled any other use for the plaza. Federal workers petitioned against it, leading to the most notorious public sculpture controversy, which led to its removal in 1989, and raised questions of who owns public space (Serra was outraged to have the work removed and filed a lawsuit under 1st amendment). 
  5. The controversy ended a period of lavish funding for art by national and state agencies. "The event now seems an early harbinger of today’s catastrophic ruptures in the national body politic. (For the record, I deemed the installation a mistake and, in print, sided with the unhappy workers.) But it also illustrates, by overbalancing, the dynamic of the sublime—the affront, the seduction—that Serra usually keeps in splendid tension." (Peter Schjeldahl)

Anish Kapoor, Part of the Red, 1981
Kroller‐Muller Museum, Otterlo, NL

New British Sculpture
  1. Born in 1954 in Mumbai, Anish Kapoor moved to London in the early 1970s. Kapoor first came to wider attention in the group exhibition New Sculpture (1978) at the Hayward Gallery, London. The show featured several artists who were a part of the New British Sculpture movement.
  2. The New British Sculpture movement broke from the Minimalism and Post-Minimalism of previous generations and instead infused art with postmodern viewpoints that include merging high and low art forms, using new technologies in unconventional ways, and greater recognition of cultural diversity.
  3. A sculptural innovator, Kapoor is particularly known for his unexpected use of terrene materials such as limestone, granite, dirt, concrete, and colorful pigment, along with his ability to create engaging environments that inspire a meditative, poetic experience.
  4. Kapoor became known in the 1980s for his geometric or biomorphic sculptures using simple materials such as granite, limestone, marble, pigment and plaster. These early sculptures are frequently simple, curved forms, usually monochromatic and brightly coloured, using powder pigment to define and permeate the form.
  5. Kapoor fashions largely monochromatic and deceptively simple works that challenge ideas of rationality and perception through the interplay of curvilinear forms, reflective surfaces, and size. His works are grounded in Eastern metaphysics and often serve as evocative statements of perception, spirituality, the body, the mind, as well as yin-and-yang dualities inherent in nature.
Fun fact: Kapoor made Cloud Gate (the bean) in downtown Chicago and created millions of selfies in the process.
Maya Lin, Vietnam War Memorial, 1981‐1984 Washington, D. C.

Contemporary Monumental Sculpture
  1. Lin submitted her proposal for the Vietnam War Memorial during her senior year of college at Yale, where she studied sculpture and architecture. Her work has frequently tested the boundaries between architecture and art, and she is often commissioned to work on installations addressing history as well as the design of museums and cultural spaces. 
  2. Lin’s acclaimed design consists of a polished black granite V-shaped wall inscribed with the names of the approximately 58,000 men and women who were killed or missing in action. This minimal plan was in sharp contrast to the traditional format for a memorial, which usually included figurative, heroic sculpture. Instead, Lin’s proposal was influenced by Land Art. 
  3. Lin did not research the history of the Vietnam War before creating her design, seeking to remain unswayed by politics. Instead, she sought to address loss in America more broadly: “I was trying to come to some understanding of mourning and grieving,” Lin has said. “We as Americans are more afraid of death and aging than many other cultures—we don’t want to accept it or deal with it.
  4. Detractors including some veterans’ groups, saw Lin’s design as overly abstract. Eventually, a compromise was reached with the commissioning of a traditional statue depicting three servicemen with a flag to stand at the entrance to the memorial, at a distance from Lin’s structure. 
  5. The black polished material allows visitors to see their own faces as they read the names of the casualties inscribed on the wall, phenomenologically disallowing a separation between the history of loss and the present moment. 
  6. Visitors often make rubbings of the names of their loved ones, a practice rooted in the centuries-old practice of creating grave rubbings.
  7. Christopher Knight, art critic for the Los Angeles Times, wrote in 2000 that the Vietnam Veterans Memorial is the “greatest aesthetic achievement in an American public monument in the 20th century.”
Fun (?) fact: the memorial is one of the most-visited monuments in Washington, D.C., drawing about four million people annually.

Jeff Koons,  New Hoover Convertibles,
Green, Blue; New Hoover Convertibles,
Green, Blue; Double‐Decker, 1981–87
Whitney Museum of American Art

American Commodity Art
