1. In the wake of Postmodernism, many artists decided to wrestle with the art market on their own terns, producing and trafficking in clearly marked consumer goods. Koons began his artistic career in the 1980s by emphasizing the conspicuous consumption that defined the era.
2. Koons, an ex-stockbroker, made his mark in the art world with a 1980 exhibition in the window of the New Museum in New York, titled “The New,” in which New Hoover Convertibles was included. With an irony reminiscent of Marcel Duchamp, Koons placed brand-new, store-bought vacuum cleaners in a sterile, fluorescent-lit vitrine that protects them from the dirt and grime they are designed to remove.
3. New Hoover Convertibles is further typical of his early sculptures in its clear gridded composition and its commitment to leaving the new materials affixed to the commercial products for which they were intended. Here is a classical Minimalism of merchandise that brought together the economic and psychological satisfaction of fine art and the commodity.
4. By thoroughly transforming the expected context and use of the vacuum cleaners, and by raising domestic appliances to the realm of fine art, Koons questions society’s obsession with cleanliness, efficiency, and newness. Koons: “I don’t seek to make consumer icons, but to decode why and how consumer objects are glorified.”
5. Yet, the theoretical position of Commodity Artists remains somewhat ambiguous. Not only did their work seem to fetishize its materials, it also played at a Warholesque naivety (see Koon’s later work Michael Jackson and Bubbles 1988).
Ilya Kabakov, The Man Who Flew into Space From His Apartment, 1981‐88

Moscow Conceptualism
  1. Kabakov grew up in the Soviet Union during Stalinist era and earned his living as a children’s book illustrator. He started creating full-scale environmental pieces in the mid 1980s which also contained elements of narrative, often revealing the difficulties and privations of Soviet daily life. His fantastical gatherings of objects have been described as Kabakov’s “material poetry.”
  2. After the collapse of the communist state, these works took on the character of archeological sites, where visitors could explore the culture history of a vanished system.
  3. In this work, the hardships of ordinary people are ironically juxtaposed with the grandiose projects of the state, like the Soviet space program.
  4. Created in 1984, the viewer enters the installation through a single door and is invited to visit the separate rooms, only one of which cannot be entered and must be viewed through cracks in a door that has been shoddily boarded up. The Man Who Flew into Space from His Apartment tells the story of one of the residents who built a catapult-like contraption to shoot himself through the roof into outer space, where he would travel on powerful streams of energy. A text describes the story as narrated by three of the other residents, one of whom happened to know the cosmonaut better than the others yet admits, “I didn’t know him well.” The room still contains the contraption, a gaping hole in the ceiling, and scientific drawings and diagrams tacked to a wall that is covered with wallpaper composed of old Soviet propaganda posters along with debris left behind (broken dishes, simple furniture and clothing). A diorama of the town shows the man’s expected projectile path into outer space. The text explains that shortly after the man went into orbit authorities arrived and boarded up the room.
  5. The work also raises questions of authorship in modernity. All of Kabakov's work is made in the name of other, fictitious artists. This reveals a hidden rule of the modern art system: only an artist who doesn't want to be an artist or who doesn't even know that he is an artist is a real artist—just as only an artwork that does not look like an artwork is a real artwork. The installation is a narrative, the documentation of a fictitious event.

Jenny Holzer, Truisms, 1982,
Times Square, NYC

Appropriation art
1.     Like their Conceptualist forebears, whose strategies provided direct inspiration, Appropriation artists in the 1980s appeared to dismantle the myths of originality, genius and power that had been threatening to collapse since the 1960s. Moreover, the consequences of this lay within the worlds of practice as well as theory. 
2.     Henny Holzer held a close  focus on means of public address, creating “language” works that appropriate the anonymous, often aggressive many in which messages of warning or instruction are transmitted from institutions like police forces, the military, schools or churches.
3.     Holzer came to New York in 1976 to participate in the Whitney ISP. Intrigued by the brevity, rhetoric and relative anonymity of texts that surrounded her– advertisements, propaganda posters, news headlines, she began to write her own “Truisms.” She created nearly 300 of these statements, based on common sayings and clichés. 
4.     At first, Holzer printed her aphorisms on posters and pasted them to the walls of public places, such as phone booths and bus stops, but later ran them on electric signboards in more prominent locations. Her aim was to present messages in ways that reach masses outside of the museum context, hoping they would prompt people to recognize and questions the “usual baloney they are fed” in daily life. 
5.     In 1982, she was selected by the Public Art Fund to create a piece for the Spectacolor Board in New York Times Square and flashed pointed remarks to throngs of pedestrians. Her truisms spoke in huge flashing lights, raising questions about consumerism, politics, and our collective conscience.
David Hammons, Bliz‐aard Ball Sale, 1983

Performance Art / Institutional Critique

  1. Hammons is a conceptual artist working in performance, installation, sculpture and printmaking. Much of his work shares concerns with Dada, Arte Povera, minimalism, and post-minimal art, but with added references to the place of Black people in American society.  He often uses the city as the site of works oriented toward an audience that the gallery and museum system was not capable, or willing, to address.
  2. For this unannounced street action Hammons situated himself alongside street vendors in the East Village - close to Cooper Union, where he taught - to sell snowballs that were neatly set in a grid over a rug, from small to large, and priced according to size. He called it Bliz-aard Ball Sale.
  3. The action, though it existed outside the art world, became legendary despite only being known through a mix of eyewitness rumors and a handful of photographs. It was documented by his friend and collaborator for two decades, Dawoud Bey, a socially conscious street photographer known for work that contests the history of black representation. At the time, both artists showed at Just Above Midtown, Linda Goode Bryant’s gallery known as JAM, a laboratory of ideas devoted to contemporary African American artists at a time when few other institutions gave them a platform.
  4. The snowballs put a satirical premium on "whiteness", ridiculing the superficiality of racial classification. Hammons also draws attention to street vendors and the precarious financial conditions of working-class New Yorkers often discriminated against in terms of race or class.
  5. By assigning value to a nature-made, ephemeral object, and letting oral history play a dominant role, the artist points to the arbitrary way social and economic systems assign value to things, including the art world for things that only the privileged may afford. But he’s not only “knowledgeable” about those systems as a keen observer, he’s an expert at playing with them and inventing his own.
  6. The action is considered the backbone of Hammons' radical oeuvre that places an emphasis on communal spirit, and transforms notions like “art,” “commodity,” “performance,” and “race” into categories that shift and dissolve, much like slowly melting snowballs. 
  7. Questioning the politics of visibility, uninterested in accolades or institutional attention, he has cultivated an enigmatic persona predicated as much on conceptual rigor as resistance to public life. His mystique has been nurtured by other actions meant to be performed and experienced, often leaving viewers with nothing but a memory. These include pissing on a Serra sculpture (Pissed Off, 1981), or inviting people to an empty and unlit gallery (Concerto in Black and Blue, 2002)
Faith Ringgold, Who’s Afraid of Aunt Jemima? 1983

Activist art/story quilt

  1. This is Ringgold's first story quilt and the first quilt project she made by herself, without the help of her mother, who died the previous year. 
  2. Squares along the borders depict African American women of varying ages from all walks of life, and the squares in the center depict a variety of different people, each connected to a block of text that tell some part of Aunt Jemima's story. The center square resembles a book title page and declares the piece a "quilt book."
  3. As Michele Wallace, the artist's daughter and art critic, has noted, the work answers the question "what are we (as black women) supposed to do with our lives and how are we supposed to do it?" Ringgold contradicts a common stereotype of an African American woman by here recasting Aunt Jemima as a successful businesswoman
  4. She notes that the work is also "a feminist statement about the stereotype of black women as fat. Aunt Jemima conveys the same negative connotation as Uncle Tom, simply because of her looks.'' By focusing on a heroic matriarch, Ringgold also connects to Aunt Jemima's story her own success in overcoming the stereotypes she faced as an African American woman and artist.
  5. Ringgold’s various Story Quilts, from the pioneering “Who’s Afraid of Aunt Jemima?” (1983) to notable works such as “Tar Beach” (1988) of the Woman on a Bridge series (which the award-winning illustrated children’s story book was based on), connect high art with folk traditions and social analysis.
  6. Ringgold began quilting as a means of “mixing art and ideas so that neither suffers” in a family tradition that extends to her great-grandmother, who had learned quilting as a slave.
  7. Ringgold often makes her life stories accessible through caricatured figures, while unequivocally presenting the realities of racial inequalities and societal anxieties.
Sherrie Levine, After Piet Mondrian, 1983

Postmodernism / Conceptual Art / Pictures Generation
  1. Levine (b. 1947, USA) is often identified as part of the Pictures generation, a name derived from the seminal exhibition Pictures organized by Douglas Crimp for Artist’s Space in 1977, in which Levine’s series Sons and Lovers was included. The Pictures generation artists were a loose group including Levine, Louise Lawler, Barbara Kruger, and Richard Prince. Their work addressed the sea of images in contemporary consumer culture and the constructedness of identity with a coolness informed by French philosophers including Roland Barthes, Michel Foucault, and Julia Kristeva (whose works had recently been translated into English).  
  2. Levine’s first solo exhibition (1981) was made up of photographs of photographs: her own unmanipulated photographs of well-known images taken by photographers including Walker Evans and Edward Weston. Levine’s images threw the modernist ideals of originality, authenticity, and the unmediated link between image and meaning into question--this destabilizing is a quintessentially postmodernist move. 
  3. Levine continued to use copying as an artistic approach in a series of watercolors and gouaches in which she rendered works that had been accepted as modernist masterpieces by male artists (including Fernand Léger, Mondrian, El Lissitzky, and Stuart Davis). 
  4. Her series reads both as a wry “what, like it’s hard?” and a mode of questioning the myth of (male) artistic genius, whereby women’s work must always come “after” that of men in the art historical canon. 
  5. In the case of After Piet Mondrian (one of a number that Levine painted based on Mondrian’s works, each titled similarly) Levine worked from a textbook reproduction, which was rendered in greyscale. 
  6. After Piet Mondrian is part of a 1970s-80s discourse about consumerism and reproducibility (itself dominated by men) which (beyond the Pictures generation) also included Andy Warhol, Sigmar Polke, and Betye Saar. 
Fun fact: Arneson’s not-statement statement about Levine’s intervention is impressive in its ability to convey no meaning: “as a woman artist, deconstructing masterpieces by male artists by redoing them in watercolor carried its own feminist statement.”

Peter Eisenman, Wexner Center for the Visual
Arts, Ohio State University, Columbus, 1983‐89

Postmodern / Deconstructivist architecture
1. Peter Eisenman, one of the architects closely associated with Deconstructivism, collaborated for a time with Derrida. Whereas the International Style of architecture valued purity and simplicity of form, pursuing designs that would appear inevitable and timeless, Deconstructivist architecture frankly asserts its status as something designed and fabricated over time (importance of movement, change, protracted encounter).
2. This contemporary art museum is Eisenman’s first building to gain wide recognition. It is an intricate complex of construction and landscape, an “archeological earthwork” as Eisenman termed it, that radically breaks with the predictable order of the traditional bucolic American academic campus.
3. Connects the academic community with the Columbus civic community: the historic plan of the campus was set at a 12.25° angle from the grid of the city. By locating a center at this point of intersection between the civic and academic life of the city, Eisenman suggests that the metaphor of meeting place rather than repository best suits the contemporary museum.
4. Symbolic of the act of collision and exchange is what the architect calls a “scaffolding” of square white steel pipes whose formation is a “metaphoric microcosm of the urban grid.”
5. Harks back to the formal geometric integration of garden and building of 17th century European palaces.
Anselm Kiefer, Departure from Egypt, 1984

Neo-Expressionism
  1. In his apocalyptic paintings, Kiefer symbolically evokes German and Jewish history through the motif and appearance of scorched earth. His work deals widely with how to reckon with German history on a personal as well as national level.
  2. His work participates in the Vergangenheitsbewältigung (“coming to terms with the past”) that had been the dominant theme in German intellectual life since the early 1960s. German critics have taken issue with Kiefer’s approach to German’s history, Andreas Huyssen wrote in 1992 that “to them Kiefer’s deliberate strategy of opening a Pandora’s box of fascist and nationalistic imagery amounted to a kind of original sin of the post-Auschwitz era.”
  3. In working through the legacy of the holocaust, Kiefer often conflates scenes of Nuremberg and of the horror of Auschwitz with historical and biblical themes, as in this one where he evokes the Departure from Egypt or the Exodus, the founding myth of the Israelites. In depicting this monumental subject matter, Kiefer also adopts the scale of history painting.
  4. Through his use of sand, straw, overprocessed photographs, laquer and lead, he simulates a war torn battlefield, swept by fire, or mulched in blood and dung. Across the front of the plane Kiefer affixes Aaron’s miraculous rod.
  5. He often subjects his materials to extreme conditions, and chooses materials that undergo transformation in this process – straw that burns and creates ash, lead that melts and bubbles. The fragility and ephemerality of these materials when layered become encrusted and thick surfaces of impasto, physical and visceral evocations of the sediments of time an meaning they convey.
Louise Lawler, Pollock and Soup Tureen, 1984

1.     Louise Lawler began her career in the early 1980s, at the moment when the art market began to partake of the speculative frenzy of Wall Street and artworks provided instant cultural capital for their owners. She was part of a group of artists called the Pictures Generation (including Cindy Sherman, Barbara Kruger etc.) who were critical of art’s traditional claims to transcend mass-cultural conditions.
2.     Two years after her first solo exhibition at Metro Pictures gallery in New York, Lawler was granted full access to the Connecticut house of collectors Burton and Emily Tremaine who had amassed a significant collection of modern and contemporary masters as well as valuable antiques. Stressing the commodification of the work of art, Lawler’s images also focus on the collectors’ incorporation of the work into their domestic space, thereby making it an extension of their subjectivity.
3.     Developing her consideration of the nature of collecting, she took this photograph of their collection, putting Modernist painting and its associated claims for formalist purity into a relationship with decorative objects associated with the upper classes. 
4.     Working with a 35mm camera and natural lighting available on site, Lawler’s photograph is dividing into two– the tureen (an 18th century Chinese porcelain dish designed for serving soup) shown in full and Pollock 1953-55 painting, Frieze, sharply cropped, as Andrea Fraser suggests looking like “little more than apocalyptic wallpaper.” 
5.     In Lawler’s presentation this important work of modern art, which was one of Pollock’s last all-over canvases completed in the year before his death, is pushed into the background. It becomes yet another ornament among the many trinkets of wealth lined up in the opulent surroundings, a symptom of the taste of a collector couple. 
6.     Inviting the viewer to question the relative cultural value of the objects shown, the focus on the tureen rather than the canvas leads to a sense that Pollock’s work has been rendered kitsch by the owners, reduced to the status of decoration in the same way as the ornate serving dish.

Mike Kelley
More Love Hours Than Can Ever Be Repaid and The Wages of Sin, 1987
Whitney Museum of American Art

1. Kelley was a prolific conceptual artist concerned with abjection, youth, class, and the divide between high and low culture. Working across disciplines in installations, sculpture, drawings, paintings, videos, and music, his work was often playful and grotesque, commenting on popular culture, folk art, youthful rebellion, and societal norms.  
  2. More Love Hours Than Can Ever Be Repaid is a chaotic assemblage, measuring eight by ten feet, of handmade dolls and blankets, tokens of childhood devotion, that Kelley found in thrift stores and yard sales.
  3. The title conjures associations of guilt as Kelley does not designate to whom more “love hours” are owed, but simply puts forward the condition of loving something too much, or of receiving too little in return for crafts that took countless hours of stitching to complete — like the cast-off items that through an accumulative effect make up the sculpture.  
  4. Using Pollock’s large drip paintings and Hoffmann's "push-and-pull" paintings as models, Kelley transformed the orphaned handicrafts into a swirling mass of unrequited affection that is beyond human reciprocation.
  5. This work marks the first time he used stuffed-animal toys as a medium. These objects would become a hallmark of his practice, and it marks the emergence of the degraded "junk" aesthetic cultivated by artists in the late 1980s and 1990s, from Jason Rhoades to Thomas Hirschhorn.
  6. The companion sculpture, a collection of melted candles, The Wages of Sin, becomes a shrine to the power of teen angst and implies a child’s rite of passage into the adult worlds of labor, debt, and atonement.
  7. Together with the autobiographical, Catholic overtones of its companion piece, the works connote themes of devotion, longing and debt, tinged with nostalgia for the innocence of childhood, while pointing with bitter humor to the disenchantments of adulthood. 
  8. In the 1960s, artists became interested in repetition and accumulation as almost mechanical techniques that downplayed the role of individual expression; here, Kelley questions that impulse. Given the materials he uses, accumulation doesn't result in just more of the same, but creates layers of association, memory, feeling, and meaning. Together they offer an altar of unabashed sentimentality, a sly assault on the high-minded aesthetics of 20th-century abstract painting and minimalism. The works' deflation of the ideals of high modernism is of a piece with its general aura of emotional and spiritual disillusionment.  
Not so fun fact: This landmark work was recreated in an empty lot near his studio in Los Angeles as a spontaneous memorial after he committed suicide in 2012. Moving article about it here: https://eastofborneo.org/articles/at-the-end-of-tipton-way-on-the-more-love-hours-memorial-to-mike-kelley/

Christian Boltanski, Lessons of Darkness, 1987
Kunstmuseum, Bern, Switzerland

Installation art
  1. Preoccupied with collective memory, mortality, and the passage of time, Christian Boltanski creates paintings, sculptures, films, and mixed-media installations that approach these themes in a range of styles, symbolic to direct. 
  2. Boltanski often makes metaphorical use of found objects, as in No Man’s Land (2010), an enormous pile of discarded jackets set to the soundtrack of thousands of human heartbeats, suggesting the anonymity, randomness, and inevitability of death. In Monuments (1985), electrical bulbs cast a seemingly bittersweet light on pictures of child holocaust victims.
  3. Describing his interest in personal histories, Boltanski has said, “What drives me as an artist is that I think everyone is unique, yet everyone disappears so quickly. […] We hate to see the dead, yet we love them, we appreciate them.”
  4. In 1986, Boltanski began creating mixed media/materials installations with light as essential concept. Tin boxes, altar-like construction of framed and manipulated photographs (e.g. Chases School, 1986–1987), photographs of Jewish schoolchildren taken in Vienna in 1931, used as a forceful reminder of mass murder of Jews by the Nazis.
  5. All elements and materials used in his work are used in order to represent deep contemplation regarding reconstruction of past.
Andres Serrano, Piss Christ, 1987

Culture Wars / Conceptual Art* / Neo-Baroque Photography (?)** 
  1. The large-scale cibachrome photograph was made by Serrano (b. 1950, USA) in 1987 as part of the series Immersions. The series showed religious objects submerged in bodily fluids such as blood and milk - an exploration, Serrano has said, of the intersection of the human and divine natures of Christ. (Serrano was brought up as a strict Roman Catholic.) For Piss Christ, a crucifix was submerged in a tank of the artist’s urine, which was placed against a red backdrop. 
  2. Serrano is influenced by Straight Photography - the image (like many of his other works, which often center supposedly abject subjects) is not manipulated. 
  3. The title inflects the viewer’s interpretation of the work - without it, the photograph perhaps recalls depictions of a golden, glowing Christ in children’s Bibles, or the treatment of light in paintings by Caravaggio. 
  4. "At the time I made Piss Christ, I wasn't trying to get anything across," Serrano recalled. "In hindsight, I'd say Piss Christ is a reflection of my work, not only as an artist, but as a Christian." He continued, "The thing about the crucifix itself is that we treat it almost like a fashion accessory. When you see it, you're not horrified by it at all, but what it represents is the crucifixion of a man. And for Christ to have been crucified and laid on the cross for three days where he not only bled to death, he shat himself and he peed himself to death. So if Piss Christ upsets you, maybe it's a good thing to think about what happened on the cross."
  5. In 1987, the Southeastern Center for Contemporary Art (which was funded by the National Endowment for the Arts) awarded a $15,000 to Serrano; during this period, Serrano produced Piss Christ, leading Rev. Donald Wildmon (director of the American Family Association) to accuse him of “religious bigotry.” This - along with the NEA’s funding of a retrospective of Mapplethorpe’s work the same year - led to a debate in the US about public arts funding often called the Culture Wars (not to be confused with today’s culture wars). At a meeting of the US Senate the following May, Republican senator Jesse Helms said this of Serrano and his work: 'Mr President [George Bush, Sr.], he is not an artist. He is a jerk. And he is taunting the American people.' Ultimately, funding for the NEA was slashed and an anti-obscenity clause was inserted into NEA contracts (unconstitutionally, it was argued).
  6. Piss Christ has also been physically attacked numerous times, most recently when it was assaulted with chisel, hammer, and spray paint in Avignon in 2011.
  7. Serrano is “not a political artist.” Sure, why not. 

Not at all fun fact: Serrano recently photographed 4 men who had been hooded while being tortured by the British authorities in 1971 (they were accused of being members of the IRA). “I wasn’t interested in photographing them as individuals, but as The Hooded Men, so I brought hoods with me.” He asked them to put hoods on for the photographs, reliving their trauma. 

*According to Serrano: https://brooklynrail.org/2017/10/art/ANDRES-SERRANO-with-Eleanor-Heartney
**Not an accepted category but I stand by it. Maybe works for Mapplethorpe too.
Krysztof Wodiczko, Homeless Projection: The Soldiers And Sailors Civil War Memorial, 1987

Site-Specific Installation Art
1. From 1980 onward, the Polish-born Krzysztof Wodiczko projected specific images at night, at first in guerrilla fashion, onto different monuments and buildings redolent of political and financial power: nuclear missiles on war memorials, presidential pledges of allegiance on corporate buildings, homeless people on heroic statues.
2. His goal was to counter the official languages and to expose the suppressed histories of these architectures, with the result that under his projections they often seemed to erupt with repressed contents and connections.
3. Wodiczko creates art that intrudes upon the built environment, insisting that viewers reckon with the social as well as individual impact of architecture on the day-to-day lives of individuals. In these architectural projections, the notion of site specificity is attached to both bodies and places.
4. Homeless Projection consists of photographs of people displaced by the processes of urban development—in this case in Boston—which he projects onto prominent buildings. The socially invisible become all but inescapable.
5. In a related piece called Poliscar (1991), the artist interviewed people living on the streets and created vehicles designed to meet their needs for shelter, storage, protection, and comfort. The vehicles were meant to function within the existing system, making the invisible visible and changing the way homelessness is perceived and discussed by society.
Gerhard Richter, Man Shot Down 1, 1988 from the series October 18, 1977

1. This series depicting the Baader-Meinhof Group’s violent attempts to overthrow capitalism came at the end of a long, complex succession of German artist’s attempt to reposition painting as a critical reflection on German history. The paintings have been widely recognized as an elegiac expression of German doubt and skepticism about the possibilities of utopian political transformation.
  2. In works such as this, Richter questions painting’s access to and capacity for representing historical significance (in contrast to Kiefer to explicitly addresses the legacy of Nazism). Furthermore, Richter employs photography in his work as a way to emphasize the degree to which history is mediated by photographic images, and how not just the construction of historical memory but its very conception are dependent on photographic representation.
  3. By addressing a more contemporary event, Richter explored the longer-term effects of Nazism on German political life and the formation of postwar German identity, rather than relegating the events to the past. Writers on the post-1968 student movement and the events leading to the formation of the Baader-Meinhof Group had made it clear that this rebellion against the neocapitalist German state was triggered largely by an underlying horror at both the complicity of the postwar generation's participation in the history of Nazi Germany and its insistent refusal to acknowledge this complicity
  4. In this work, Richter employs his signature technique of wiping across the still-wet surface of his photo-paintings with a squeegee to soften the edges and blur the image. This signature blur can evoke a range of things—the motion of the viewer or the camera, the passage of time, but also something more metaphoric, of the type suggested in the artist’s 1971 musing: “My relationship to reality has a great deal to do with imprecision, uncertainty, transience, incompleteness.”
  5. The image here depicts Andreas Baader dead on the floor of his cell. Richter drew some of his source images from newspapers and magazines or snapshots of television coverage—markers of the pervasiveness of media coverage of the Baader-Meinhof Group during their violent reign and in its aftermath, and others from police evidentiary photographs.
I. M. Pei, Grand Louvre Pyramid, Paris, 1988

Postmodern architecture 
1.     The Louvre Pyramid is a large glass and metal pyramid designed by Chinese-American architect I.M. Pei, surrounded by three smaller pyramids in the main courtyard of the Louvre Palace in Paris, with the large pyramid serving as the main entrance to the museum. The structure was commissioned in an attempt to modernize the Louvre, as part of the French president Francois Mitterand’s campaign to renovate cultural institutions across France. 
2.     The pyramid and underground lobby beneath it were created because of a series of problems with the Louvre’s original main entrance, which could no longer handle the enormous number of visitors on a daily basis. In addition to the new entrance, Pei’s design featured a new underground system of galleries, storage and preservation labs– allowing the Louvre to expand its collection. 
3.     The construction of the pyramid triggered many years of an aesthetic and political debate. Those criticizing the aesthetics said it was “sacrilegious” to tamper with the Louvre’s majestic old French Renaissance architecture, and called the pyramid an anachronistic intrusion of an Egyptian death symbol in the middle of Paris. 
4.     The Pyramid deliberately turns the tradition and concept of the pyramid inside out. While pyramids are sold, dark and solitary, Pei’s structurer is clear glass, almost immaterial, serving as a vast skylight for the museum visitors. 
5.     Besides its associations of timelessness and its ingenuity in lighting an underground space, the structure is an example of how new buildings in old settings do now always have to accommodate themselves to the style of their found surroundings.
Cindy Sherman, Untitled # 224 (after Caravaggio's Bacchus), 1990

1. Sherman is part of the Pictures Generation, media-savvy artists who came of age in the 1960s and 1970s, shaped by the Vietnam War, social movements, feminism, and television, known for tweaking conventions of high art and popular culture.  She is best known for elaborately staged photographs, often using herself as the subject in all manner of disguises to explore identity.
  2. Sherman was living in Rome when she began “History Portraits” (1988–90), a series of thirty-five intentionally peculiar photographs where she continues to examine the construction of stereotypes, again casting herself in them, but this time plumbing the history of painting with theatrical pastiches of Old Masters in antique-looking frames.
  3. Sherman served as model, set-dresser, and photographer. Drawing from a range of art-historical periods, including the Renaissance, Baroque, Rococo, and Neoclassical, she used costuming and settings to transform herself into the historical-looking male and female figures of each photograph. Full of obvious prostheses, bad wigs, and theatrical makeup, the images are made to appear artificial, as parodies of her source images and the societal attitudes they reflect and perpetuate. She alerts viewers that photographs cannot be trusted by revealing that her pictures are constructs, drawing attention to the staged nature of historical portrait paintings.
  4. Here, Sherman has taken on the role of Caravaggio’s Sick Bacchus (1593-4), thought to be a self-portrait of the artist as the Roman god of wine. The painting earned its nickname, the “Sick Bacchus,” because of the jaundiced look of the figure, scholars suggesting it was painted during or after Caravaggio suffered from a bout of Malaria.  The protruding bare shoulder, sensual look, luscious curls, and tactile, juicy fruits being offered to the viewer, have been read as conveying Caravaggio's homosexuality. A thought furthered by Caravaggio's quotation of Antinoüs, an antique bas relief from Villa Albani, as a model for his painting, given that Antinoüs was the same-sex lover of the Roman Emperor Hadrian.
  5. Sherman's costume and gesture are exactly like Caravaggio's painting, and this is one of the rare images where she takes on the guise of a male character. Sherman's double quotation of gay men in history may have been propelled by the AIDS crisis and Culture Wars in the US, begun by Senator Jesse Helms who took offense at a few images in Robert Mapplethorpe's 1989 exhibition ''The Perfect Moment'' that glamorized homoeroticism and sadomasochism, lambasting the N.E.A. for supporting another provocative artist (after Serrano). Sherman's choice of the Sick Bacchus (rather that the later, better known Bacchus in the Uffizi) may have been a nod to Mapplethorpe’s own sickness and death due to AIDS complications in March 1989. 
  6. Sherman’s photographs are not wry, cynical copies of Old Master paintings, they are homages to the past, images that consider changing artistic processes, social mores, and gender roles in Western society.
Andreas Gursky, Salerno, 1990

Contemporary pictorial photography

  1. From the artist: “I saw immediately that pattern, that pictorial density, that industrial aesthetic. This image became an important piece for me, a turning point. It opened up a new sense of possibility, stylistically and thematically. I tried photographing other ports, but I realised that wasn’t what had made the Salerno image work. It was the balance between great scale and a huge amount of sharp detail.”
  2. Gursky studied with Hilla and Bernd Becher at the Dusseldorf Art Academy, where he was schooled in the distinctive Becher approach: photograph a single subject as uniformly and objectively as possible, usually in black and white; then display the results typologically, usually in grids or series. Gursky departed from that training.
  3. Gursky worked in color (his is the first generation of German photographers to use it extensively), and soon he experimented with digital splicing as well (at first to create sleek urban panoramas). By the nineties most of his prints had become large and pictorial,
  4. Gursky does produce the occasional "Romantic" landscape but his primary interest lies in a different sort of contemporary "sublime"—in the intense spaces of detailed commodity production furious financial exchange, spectacular professional sports, rave youth culture, excessive product display and other such "hyperspaces" characteristic of global capitalism both at work and at play
  5. Salerno marks the beginning of Gursky’s mature style, with people and/or products arranged in total designs or as "mass ornaments"
  6. Salerno is a vast panorama of color-coded vehicles, containers, cranes, and freighters, a "second nature" of commercial distribution that has overwhelmed the ancient landscape of this Mediterranean port

Glenn Ligon, Untitled (I Feel Most Colored…), 1990
Whitney Museum of American Art

Conceptual Art
  1. Originally interested in abstraction, Glenn Ligon (B. 1960, USA) began incorporating language into his paintings during his time at the Whitney Museum’s Independent Study Program in 1985. Finding that a strictly abstract style was not suited to the stories he wanted to tell, Ligon has excerpted texts by Zora Neal Hurston, Walt Whitman, Jean Genet, Gertrude Stein, James Baldwin, Richard Pryor, and Ralph Ellison among others in his works. 
  2. Ligon encourages the streaks left behind by oil sticks and stencils to progressively obscure the text on his canvases, experimenting with the subject of legibility and erasure, particularly as they relate to race, and the limits of signs. He explains, “Oil paint wants to spread out and smudge and smear. And after about six months of trying to make perfect letters, I realized that the smudging and smearing and disappearance of the letters was way more interesting than trying to make a perfect letter form. And so the paintings became about that disappearance of language.” (c.f. material specificity) As Ligon worked his way down the support, the text became progressively smudged and illegible because the greasy oil stick left a residue that adhered to the stencil. “The smearing also creates a visual interaction with the gesso ground, a metaphor for the interaction between blacks and whites in the construction of racial identity,” Ligon has said. 
  3. This oilstick-on-canvas work features an excerpt from Zora Neale Hurston’s 1928 essay “How It Feels to Be Colored Me,” in which the author describes leaving the protective black community of her childhood at age thirteen and suddenly being confronted with the issue of race - being a Black person in a white society. 
  4. Describing what drew him to this text, Ligon has said: “I became really fascinated by those sentences that had the word ‘I’ in them—‘I feel most colored when I'm thrown against a sharp white background.’ The use of the word ‘I’ creates a kind of confusion. Is it the ‘I’ of the text that I'm quoting, or is it ‘I,’ Glenn Ligon, feel most colored? And so, the confusion between those two things was something I was interested in.”
  5. In 1989, Ligon’s first solo show, "How It Feels to Be Colored Me," opened in Brooklyn. The exhibition established his reputation for making works like Untitled, in which the same phrase is repeated, growing increasingly obscured as it moves down the support. 
Fun Fact: Notes on the Margin of the Black Book is Ligon’s response to Mapplethorpe’s Black Book, a series of highly eroticized photographs of mostly-nude Black men: https://www.guggenheim.org/artwork/10382
Felix Gonzalez‐Torres, Untitled (Portrait of Ross in L. A.), 1991

Queer conceptual sculpture
1. In the shifting political landscape as AIDS took its toll on American lives and empowered by ACT-UP (AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power), many gay and lesbian artists began to explore homosexuality as a subject of art and engaged in the queering of existing art genres.
2. Félix González-Torres created a poetic oeuvre in which a pile of candy could interweave physicality, memory, biography, politics, and history. Deeply influenced by Minimalism and Conceptual art, he pushed his audience from sixties aesthetics to nineties politics.
3. Untitled (Portrait of Ross in L.A.) is the result of amassing the weight of González-Torres’s lover Ross in brightly wrapped pieces of candy, which the viewer was invited to take – the dwindling physical mass of the sculpture echoing the wasting away of Ross’s body (Ross died of AIDS in 1991, five years before Gonzalez-Torres himself).
4. The piece flies in the face of taboos in art against touching, let alone eating. It also brings together stylistic cues usually kept apart: a Postminimalist-like scatter piece (Robert Morris and Richard Serra did corner pieces, but also Malevich and Tatlin) with Pop-like materials (the glitziness reminds one of Andy Warhol). It even seems to undo, if only for a moment, the old opposition between the avant-garde and kitsch.
5. At the same time, the excess of the piece also conveys a sense of generosity, a spirit of offering so different from the cool cynicism of other uses of the readymade device by Jeff Koons and others. Gonzalez-Torres solicits our participation in the register not only of consumption but of gift-exchange. His candy spills are listed as "endless supply," which reminds us, in a utopian sense, that mass production once had democratic possibilities latent within it.
6. Torres examines both the public qualities of private experiences of love and death and the private consequences of such public events as viewing art or providing healthcare.
Jimmie Durham, Red Turtle, 1991

1. In Durham’s work and activism, he seeks to challenge the government policies that were devastating the Native American community. His Native American heritage (he had claimed at one point to be a member/descendant of the Cherokee Nation but has since gone back this statement) has been much disputed.
  2. His sculpture questions the expectations and stereotypes of Native American art within the settler “art world.” In 1984 he created a display called “On Loan from the Museum of the American Indian.” Featuring Durham’s self-described tongue-in-cheek “neo-primitive neo-conceptualism.” His Museum lent out fake Indian artifacts that pressured the primitivist clichés of the Native American to the point of critical ridicule
  3. Red Turtle maintains this self-parodying societal and institutional critique. Handmade from a turtle shell, painted stick and paper, it is a pastiche of the expected naturalism of Native American art. A label affixed to the reads:
    1. We have tried to train them; to teach them to speak properly, to fill out forms. We have no way of knowing whether they truly perceive and comprehend or whether they simply imitate our actions.
  4. Evoking the authoritative voice of the colonizer or the anthropologist, Durham offers a biting and humorous chal- lenge to the teaching of history in schools, museums, and the marketplace, which requires Native Americans to remain frozen in a romantic and precolonial existence that obscures their far from Edenic reality in modern America.
  5. The piece evokes the spare geometry of Constructivism as well as the witty play of signs typical of Dada. Anchored by a forceful “X,” the piece invites readings as diverse as “X marks the spot” or a vehement cancellation.
Frank O. Gehry, Guggenheim Museum, Bilbao, Spain, 1991‐97

Postmodern architecture
1.     The Bilbao museum is a monumental abstraction designed by Canadian-American architect Frank Gehry, built alongside the Nervión River which runs through the city of Bilbao. It features permanent and visiting exhibits of works by Spanish and international artists and is one of the largest museums in Spain. 
2.     By the 1990s, Gehry had modified his architectural language from the geometry and decoration of his earlier works to more organic designs that evoked natural forces such as the wind. His design for this building was inspired by Bilbao’s industrial history and the curving of the Nervión River, which once supported thriving mills and shipyards. He intended for it to resemble a metal flower rising up from the riverfront. 
3.     Designed with the aid of CATIA, a computer program created by the French aerospace industry to translate sculptural models into specifications for manufacture, the museum rises to a towering point of reinforced concrete at the north end, which appears to hover impossibly in the sky. Undulating walls and ceilings sheathed in titanium open out from the peak like giant petals blown in the wind or floating on the river.
4.     The organic and expressive design elements of the building are anchored by six Spanish limestone cubes that recall the severe geometry of the International style. These elements house more traditional style white box galleries, a library, auditorium, restaurant and retail spaces. From the west, hints of the metallic flower peel out from behind the stone walls, creating a sense of drama as one circles the building. 
5.     The design of the blossoming flower can be read as a metaphor for the political and economic ambitions of the Basque government to assert itself on an international stage. Intent on doing more than symbolizing the growth and stability of the region, Gehry responded to the needs of the city as well as the art collection, with the building combining the function of a museum with facilities for Bilbao’s citizens such as a restaurant and retail spaces accessible from the street independently of the museum.
Kiki Smith, Blood Pool, 1992

Abject Art
  1. Smith is an American artist best known for her representations of mortality, abjection, and sexuality. Her figurative work of the late 1980s and early 1990s confronted subjects such as AIDS and gender, while recent works have depicted the human condition in relationship to nature. Domesticity, fragility, and the humble materials of craft and folk arts feature strongly in her work.
  2. Smith's work examines the dichotomy between the psychological and physiological power of the body.  She creates uncomfortable, life-size figures that challenge and extend the Western tradition of figural representation by treating the body as the site of biological, genetic, social, and political battles.
  3. Composed of wax, which Smith favors for its malleability, and cast from a live model, Blood Pool features a small, apparently violated figure, huddled into a fetal position on the floor. She evokes the texture and color of flesh. The fetal pose and exposed spine become a primal emblem that engages viewers in issues of individual and collective health and disease, heroization and victimization, and life and death (particularly because of the dual potential of human blood in the era of AIDS).
  4. This work emphasizes the body’s vulnerability and references feminist theories of the “abject,” which conceived of the body as a messy, porous, and boundary-less system as espoused by feminist philosopher Julia Kristeva in her seminal essay "Powers of Horror: An Essay on Abjection" (1982).
  5. The piece is imbued with political significance, undermining the traditional erotic representations of women by male artists.  The mournful, violated quality speaks to a tangled sense of damage that is both private and public. Smith's sister died of AIDS in 1988, and the piece was made during the AIDS crisis, when blood became a subject fraught with fears of infection and death.
  6. She was influenced by her father, sculptor Tony Smith, and his female contemporaries, Louise Bourgeois, Eva Hesse and Lee Bontecou, as well as her emergency medical technician training.

Rirkrit Tiravanija, Untitled (Free), 1992
303 Gallery, New York

Relational art?
  1. Rirkrit Tiravanija was born in Buenos Aires in 1961 and was raised in Thailand, Ethiopia, and Canada. Since the 1990s, Tiravanija has aligned his artistic production with an ethic of social engagement, often inviting viewers to inhabit and activate his work. 
  2. In one of his best-known series, begun with pad thai (1990) at the Paula Allen Gallery in New York, Tiravanija rejected traditional art objects altogether and instead cooked and served food for exhibition visitors. For his second solo exhibition in New York, held at 303 Gallery in 1992, Tiravanija filled the white rooms with stacks of cultural cast-offs, rendering the space into what seemed like a storage facility, demoting the primacy of the revered art object.
  3. In a signal piece of 1992, Tiravanija also used the dislocating of space and the offering of food as a means to confuse the normal positions and conventional roles of art, artist, viewer, and  intermediary (in this case the art dealer). At 303 Gallery in New York, he moved the private unseen rooms of the gallery, which contained the business office, the packing, and shipping areas, and all the other materials of its daily functioning, into its public viewing spaces. The director and assistants at desks were on display in the central gallery, while Tiravanija worked over a stove in the back gallery where he cooked and served Thai curry vegetables over jasmine rice. 
  4. In subsequent works he has often played on such reversals of physical space, substitutions of expected function, and displacements of object.
Mona Hatoum, Light Sentence, 1992

Installation Art
  1. Born in Beirut to Palestinian parents, Hatoum found herself shut out of her birth nation when war broke out in 1975 and took up residence in London. There, she became part of a loose group of artists including Sarah Lucas, Cornelia Parker, Gillian Wearing and Rachel Whiteread, discontented with the sensationalist bravado of the male-dominated art-world that (by the late 1980s) thrived on commercialized scandals. 
  2. Hatoum’s work is generally installation-based, and often addresses displacements and boundaries, destabilizing the oppositional relationship between confinement and freedom, home and exile. 
  3. Working in the wake of Minimalist and Duchampian uses of commercially-made and found materials, Hatoum uses industrially fabricated materials, often alongside residues of the human body like hair, skin, and nails. The tension between the two points to the precarity of the human position amid overarching governmental and commercial/economic power structures. 
  4. Light Sentence is a cage-like enclosure made from galvanized wire mesh lockers. At its center is an electric motor and light bulb which slowly circles in the center of the installation, creating geometric, disorienting shadows on the walls of the room around it.
  5. Hatoum’s work tends to operate according to allusion and phenomenological relationship between viewer and the work, rather than literal reference. At the time it was first exhibited, viewers commented that they saw LIght Sentence as relating primarily to Palestinian refugee camps. Hatoum noted that "they [the viewers] tend to over-interpret the work in relation to my background," relating the work more broadly to the feeling of being trapped.
Fred Wilson, Mining the Museum, 1992 (detail)

Installation art / Institutional Critique
1. The 90s witnessed a concerted attempt to expose the mechanisms by which art is produced, displayed and discussed. Fred Wilson’s installations expose the power structures of museums through the manipulation of its display techniques; using juxtaposition, redirection, irony and humor.
2. In Mining the Museum, sponsored by the Museum of Contemporary Art in Baltimore, Wilson took an ethnographic approach to the Maryland Historical Society to expose how the site’s African American past had been rendered invisible.
3. Several meanings of “mining”: First he explored its collection of historical artifacts, especially ones deemed marginal and placed in storage. Then he reclaimed certain objects in the collection, most evocative of African-American experiences, which were not part of the official history on display; Finally he reframed still other objects that were already part of the official history.
4. In Metalwork 1793-1880, Wilson placed a rough pair of slave manacles found in storage in an existing exhibit of exquisite goblets and pitchers; this wrenched the objects on view into a different context of meaning: showing the invisible history of slavery behind the economic situation that supported the decorative arts in 18th and 19th century America.
5. The result was profoundly unsettling, especially given the eruption of protests, a mere week after the show opened, following the acquittal of 4 white officers accusing of beating Rodney King, bringing discussions of racial inequity to the fore.
6. This is one example of the rise of the figure of the artist-curator in the 90s.

Robert Gober, Site‐specific
Installation, Dia Center for the Arts, New York, 1993

Installation art?
  1. In much of Gober’s work, he is interested in creating environments that take fragments of the American environment to suggest the complex intersection of psychic and social identity. His installation at Dia addresses the internal conflicts and external pressures of Western society.
  2. The installation contains stacks of handcrafted newspapers, tied up like recycling, lie about the room and sinks that drip water to the recorded sounds of a babbling brook. The room is wallpapered with an artificial panorama of New England woods punctured by barred windows. The windows underscore that the landscape is an illusion, and also make the room feel all the more like a cell; yet even the sky beyond the windows is unreal, painted on a backdrop behind the walls.
  3. Reading the newspapers reveals an even more upsetting story. Gober manipulated the layouts of various national newspapers, juxtaposing the headlines “Not Guilty,” “Vatican Condones Discrimination Against Homosexuals, Concern That Gay Rights Threaten Marriage,” and an ad featuring Gober in a wedding dress. The presence of the artist, a gay Catholic, cross-dressed for the forbidden ceremony, reiterates the repressive power of society at definitive moments in a person’s life.
  4. Once in the installation, the viewer can walk behind the papered walls and see that they are temporary constructions, a hopeful metaphor for the artificial social constructions that the piece critiques.
  5. He has called his installations "natural history dioramas about contemporary human beings," and sometimes they do possess the hyperreal, almost hallucinatory dimension of such displays. They place us in an ambiguous space—as in a dream we seem to be both inside and outside the scenes—that is also an ambiguous time—"memories filtered through my current experiences." The scene he creates here is idyllic and also extremely claustrophobic. It was painted to look not entirely convincing, with preparatory pencil marks left visible here and there.
Rachel Whiteread, House, 1993

Site specific sculpture

1.   British artist Rachel Whiteread’s site specific sculptures involved making direct casts of objects using materials as varied as plaster, rubber, resin, plastic and concrete. The resulting sculptures reveal the form of negative space around the objects as small and prosaic as bathtubs and mattresses and as large as a house itself. 
2.   Evoking the geometric abstraction of both funereal sculpture and Minimalist art, Whiteread’s work, she says “has to do with the way our culture treats death; other cultures celebrate it and we try to brush it under the carpet.” 
3.   In 1993, Whiteread was commissioned to create House, the casting of the interior of an entire home in London’s East End. Created from sprayed concrete,House stood in a low income neighbourhood that was being gentrified. Trading Victorian flourishes for concrete geometry produced an aggressive analogy for the demographic changes occurring in London. 
4.   For her project, she chose a house that was slated for demolition. The government had chosen to tear down a group of dilapidated dwellings to create more green space for the community, and the artist was able to access the last building standing– recently vacated by a man who had been evictedafter losing a years-long fight to keep his home. 
5.   An aesthetically intrusive commentary on urban planning, House spurred immediate controversy. The site of the sculpture became a popular visitor attraction, with thousands of visitors a day. In spite of this, the work was met with criticism from locals who struggled to pay for their own flats, while an unlivable structure received significant attention and funding. Though conceived as a temporary monument, it caused great uproar and was demolished earlier than scheduled, barely 11 weeks after its completion. 
 
Fun fact: Whiteread won the Turner Prize for the work, as well as the K Foundation art award for the worst example of British art. She was hesitant to accept the award at first, but the Foundation planned to burn the money if she didn’t. Amidst a crowd of witnesses on the steps of the Tate, a masked K foundation operative doused the cash in light fluid– at the last moment Whiteread emerged from the Tate and accepted the money, donating it to a housing charity and to grants for young artists.

Jeff Wall, A Sudden Gust of Wind (After Hokusai), 1993
Tate Gallery, London

Cibachrome transparency mounted on a lightbox

  1. Wall is a Canadian artist best known for his large-scale back-lit cibachrome photographs and art history writing. Initially trained as a painter at the University of British Columbia, he undertook doctoral research in art history at the Courtauld Institute (1970–73), where he studied with Manet expert T.J. Clark. He is a key figure of the Vancouver School, a community of conceptual / post-conceptual photographers whose interests coincide around the play of artifice and observation in narrative photography.
  2. Wall’s work synthesizes the essentials of photography with elements from other art forms—including painting, cinema, and literature—in a complex mode he calls “cinematography.” His pictures range from classical reportage to elaborate constructions and montages, usually produced at the larger scale traditionally identified with painting.
  3. A Sudden Gust of Wind (after Hokusai) depicts a flat, open landscape in which four figures are frozen as they respond to a gust of wind, and narrow trees bend in the force of the wind, while floating papers and leaves create a sense of dynamic movement. It is based on Katsushika Hokusai's woodcut, Travellers Caught in a Sudden breeze at Ejiri (c.1832).
  4. Wall photographed actors in a landscape outside Vancouver, at times when similar weather conditions prevailed over a period of five months. He then collaged elements digitally to achieve the desired composition. The result is a constructed tableau using contemporary technology, which appears staged in the manner of a classical painting. This was one of his first works to employ digital-imaging technology, which has since transformed the landscape of photography.
  5. The large-scale photographic transparency displayed in a light box became Wall’s signature medium, meant to mimic the propagandistic quality of history painting with the boldness of advertising. Wall's works have been characterized as one-frame cinematic productions due to their complicated productions involving cast, sets, crews, special effects, and digital postproduction. This image exemplifies what the artist calls “blatant artifice”: pictures that foreground the theatricality of their subject and their production.
  6. Taking the Japanese woodblock as his model for contemporary photography, Wall alludes to the 19th C European fascination with Asian visual culture. Using photography to transform the woodblock into an image of Canadian businessmen in a landscape that evokes industrial farming projects a certain irony onto the multicultural aspects of both the 19th and 20th C. 
  7. His new version of pictorial photography had a startling effect when exhibited, playing a part in the acceptance of color photography.
Douglas Gordon, 24 Hour Psycho, 1993

Video Installation

Not long ago film was considered the medium of the future; now it appears as a privileged index of the recent past (perhaps it will enter the art museums as it becomes outmoded elsewhere). Early cinema in particular has emerged as an archive of historical experience, a repository of old sensations, private fantasies, and collective hopes,

Much contemporary art of the projected image recalls the two-part movement of the Sublime, as discussed by German philosopher Immanuel Kant, with a first moment in which the viewer is almost overwhelmed, even shattered, by an awesome sight and / or sound, followed by a second moment in which he or she comprehends the experience and so recoups it intellectually, and feels a rush of power, not of loss, for doing so. 

Douglas Gordon focuses more strictly on the traumatic sublime; indeed, he seems obsessed with splittings of many sorts—imagistic, formal, thematic, and psychological. Often Gordon uses split screens to project his appropriated films (he has favored Hollywood auteurs from Alfred Hitchcock to Martin Scorsese),
His most famous work appropriates the most famous movie about schizophrenia, Psycho, however, Gordon slows the Hitchcock film to a hypnotic, almost catatonic pace that stretches the movie to 24 hours
Marlene Dumas, The Painter, 1994

Neo-Expressionism
  1. Dumas (b. 1953, South Africa) began painting the figure in the 1980s in Amsterdam. She works from photographs from magazines, newspapers, or books, or those she shoots herself, usually removing identifying details.
  2. Like the Expressionists, Dumas’ use of color in her paintings is not naturalistic, but rather seems to hint at her subjects’ inner lives, or perhaps her psychological response to them. 
  3. Per Dumas, “I would like my paintings to be like poems. Poems are like sentences that have taken their clothes off. The meaning of a poem is what its beat and rhythm do. How the words move on the page. Poetry is writing that breathes and makes jumps and leaves spaces open, so we can read between the lines.”
  4. The Painter is a monumental oil painting of an unclothed young child, who has paint on their hands and perhaps also smeared on their torso. (The title is ambiguous - it might refer to the subject of the painting specifically, or to the archetypal figure of the painter.) Many writers identify the red paint on the child’s left hand with blood. The perceived threat of the image is bolstered by the painting’s monumental scale (over 6’ tall) and the child’s shadowed eyes. Perhaps the threat is also inflected by Dumas’ own identity - the privilege of being a “sweet young [white] girl” growing up in South Africa during apartheid.
  5. The artist herself, talking about this work, commented on the ambiguity of childhood with its cruelty and naiveté. A parallel can be drawn with Diane Arbus' famous photograph Child with a toy hand grenade in Central Park, NYC (1962). In it, the little boy also seems angry and threatening as he holds a grenade in his hand, yet he was merely growing impatient with the photographer and only wanted to return to his toys. (this via The Art Story)
  6. "Historically . . . it was always the male artist who was the painter and his model the female," Dumas has said of this work. "Here we have a female child (the source my daughter) taking the main role. She painted herself. The model becomes the artist." (The painting is based on a snapshot of Dumas’s daughter finger painting on a hot summer day.)

Kara Walker, Gone: An Historical Romance of a Civil War as It Occurred b'tween the Dusky Thighs of One Young Negress and Her Heart, 1994
Museum of Modern Art, New York

American contemporary sculpture / silhouette
1. This wall installation, first exhibited in Walker's 1994 New York debut, inaugurated the artist's signature medium: black cut-out silhouettes of caricatures of antebellum figures arranged on a white wall in uncanny, sexual, and violent scenarios.
2. In reviving the 18th century cut-paper silhouette to critique historical narratives of slavery and the ongoing perpetuation of ethnic stereotypes, Walker has transformed the craft into a new type of epic history painting.
3. "Gone" refers to Margaret Mitchell's 1936 novel Gone with the Wind, set during the American Civil War. While Walker’s narrative begins and ends with coupled figures (soldier and maiden embracing), the chain of tragicomic, grotesque imagery refutes the promise of romance and confounds conventional attributions of power and oppression.
4. Similarity between the method of the silhouette and the practice of racial stereotyping: both rely on generalization, obliteration of details, both are highly visible and anonymous
5. Walker restages the myths of racist lore, while undermining and reimagining them at the same time. These fantasies persist outrageously in the American unconscious, Walker suggests.
6. With her slapstick sensibility, Walker’s art is a quintessentially Postmodern engagement with the powers of representation.
Thomas Struth, Museum of Modern Art I, 1994

“Becher School”
  1. Drawing on the practice of his professors Bernd and Hilla Becher, Struth applied their typological method to the institutions of learning and art history that developed them, using the camera to interrogate te forms and consequences of various types of artistic display.
  2. Struth’s series of museum interiors present the collusion between art and museum in shaping the physical, intellectual and emotional experiences of the viewer whom Struth includes in his photographs. The works in the series of Museum Photographs (1989-1992) capture anonymous individuals and crowds looking at iconic works of Western art in the world’s most popular museums e.g. Géricault’s Raft of the Medusa in the Louvre.
  3. Here he presents 7 or 8 blurred and moving figures in front of Pollock’s One: Number 31 (1950) which is captured in detailed, unmoving focus, thus documenting the transferences of energy and behavior form the painting to the viewer. This works to emphasize the absence of human agency as the Bechers’ works similarly did.
  4. As attentive to architectural surroundings as to people and objects, Struth emphasizes museum going as a complex social ritual of seeing and being seen, one in which the museum itself functions as both custodian and broker of cultural capital.
  5. As the realms of portrait painting and contemporary photography began to collide within his practice, ‘there arose the idea to bring these two things, with the medium of reproduction, the currently appropriate medium, to the same level; to make a reproduction of a painted image and at the same time to produce a new image in which real persons of today are shown’
William Kentridge, drawing from Felix in Exile, 1994

Biographic art?
1.    Through his animated films, theatrical productions and graphic work, William Kentridge addresses the personal and social traumas that are the vestiges of South African apartheid. He uses biography as a lens to view the relationship between history and the present. 
2.    To express these ideas, he has essentially created his own medium– animation in which the traditional cells are replaced with charcoal drawings filmed at given moments of being drawn, erased and altered. The results document images that seem to carry themselves across the surface of a single page of paper. His films therefore reveal traces of their making, just as the narratives invoke memories of a historic time.
3.    His ongoing series of short animated films Drawings for Projection (begun in 1989) feature two principal characters, who function as the artist’s alter egos: Soho Eckstein, an avaricious South African mining magnate in a pinstriped suit and tie, and Felix Teitlebaum, shown naked and vulnerable to apartheid’s devastating acts.
4.    In Felix in Exile, the fifth film of the series made between September 1993 and February 1994, Kentridge depicts the barren East Rand landscape as witness to the exploitation of and violence against both natural and human resources. Isolated in a hotel room, Felix peruses the survey charts of Nandi, a young black woman who maps the history of the terrain. Figures and structures are subsumed into the landscape or night sky, allegories for how the land can bear the scars of crimes against humanity.
5.    Kentridge displays the drawings from which each film was made together with the film itself. There are thus always two objects that make up his movies: an image frozen at the point where he decided to pause the history of erasures and films and the unstopping film. The contrast of the two media, between the intimacy of charcoal and the distance of film further accentuates the difficult merging of biography and history.
Mona Hatoum, Corps Étranger, 1994

1. Hatoum is a Palestinian artist whose poetic and political oeuvre embraces unconventional media and engages the viewer in conflicting emotions of desire and revulsion, fear and fascination. She became widely known in the 1980s for performance and video works that focused on the body as the locus of political, feminist, and linguistic concerns.
  2. Hatoum has developed a language in which domestic objects are transformed into foreign, threatening and dangerous things. Even the human body is rendered unfamiliar in Corps étranger (Foreign body) (1994), a video installation projected on the floor of a cylindrical cell, one of the most unusual self-portraits in art history: an endoscopic journey through the interior landscape of her body that turns the inside out, making the invisible visible.
  3. Stepping into the claustrophobic cylinder, the visitor hears a soundtrack of heartbeats from different body parts while watching pictures of mucous membranes, hair, teeth – everything enlarged by a tiny camera that ventures into the body's orifices. Breathing, heartbeats, and the gurgling of internal organs intensify the unease of the sense of being inside of the body.
  4. The viewer becomes a foreign body entering Hatoum's body, creating a situation of discomfort and alienation, resonant with her themes of displacement and homelessness, which comments on the history of the Middle East and the artist's life as a double émigré (Lebanese-born Palestinian artist/British resident).
  5. The title designates the camera as an extension of the scientific eye, an external element penetrating the patient's body, appropriating it and then retrieving deconstructed images of it. The defamiliarization is so extreme that the examined body also becomes “foreign”, as if unrecognizable to the person it belongs to. Lastly, the title refers to the onlooker's position within the installation as a voyeur who enters an unknown body whose proportions are beyond the real scale, thus magnifying the effect of immersion.
  6. Surveillance, something Hatoum noticed when she moved to London in the 1970s, is a recurring theme in her work. She wanted to make the work, a kind of ultimate surveillance, in 1980 while a student at Slade, but all the doctors refused on ethical grounds. It only happened in 1994 because she had the weight of the Centre Pompidou behind her. Corps étranger pushed the idea of surveillance to an absurd extreme, "I was implying that surveillance can even penetrate inside you. There’s no place that remains unturned or unobserved."
  7. She is also referring to the principle of correlation between eye and power, developed by Foucault. The encounter within the architectural space, between the artist's body and the onlooker's gaze standing in for the medical eye, works like a spatialization of the power wielded in medicine, by the scientific eye over a patient's vulnerable body.
  8. Hatoum is part of a loose group of female artists in London, including Rachel Whiteread and Gillian Wearing, who disillusioned with YBA shock tactics, looked to Minimalism and Conceptualism.
Chris Ofili, The Holy Virgin Mary, 1996

Young British Artists
  1. Ofili (1968-) was one of the group of artists known as the Young British Artists, noted for "shock tactics", use of throwaway materials, wild-living, and an attitude "both oppositional and entrepreneurial". They achieved considerable media coverage and dominated British art during the 1990s—internationally reviewed shows in the mid-1990s included Brilliant! and Sensation (Holy Virgin Mary was included in Sensation).
  2. Ofili often uses elephant dung as a material in his painting. The materials of Holy Virgin Mary are: paper collage of pornography, oil paint, glitter, polyester resin, map pins & elephant dung on linen
  3. Tension between iconic and iconoclastic. The gold color and frontal static figure echo the Byzantine and medieval icons of the virgin Mary while the pornographic collage and dung provoke. Yet, the artist claims that the sacred and the profane are not always opposed, even in traditional religious art (all who have seen medieval/renaissance art can confirm)
  4. As Carol Becker has explained, Ofili is “transforming the Holy Virgin into an exuberant, folkloric image. (…) probably most controversial of all, he made his own representation of the Virgin, defiant of tradition.” The “parody-like African mouth” and exaggerated facial features call attention to racial stereotypes, as well as to the assumed whiteness of biblical figures in Western representations. Ofili’s icon asks us to confront the possibility of a black Virgin Mary.
  5. Ofili’s work is as formally-motivated as it is political. The artist did not only return to painting, he returned to decoration and visual pleasure, at a time when art was expected to comply with the more cerebral aesthetics of postmodernism. 
  6. Perhaps his attraction to gaudy bright colors, earthy materials and glittering surfaces, paired with the highly conceptual stakes of his project, reflects another blending of sacred and profane, regarding the conservatism of the art world.
Fun Fact and another reason to hate Rudy Giuliani: In October of 1999, Sensation opened at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, where it was The Holy Virgin Mary that incited the most heated debate. Mayor Rudy Giuliani threatened to close the city-funded institution on the grounds that this artwork was offensive to religious viewers. Two months later, the painting, which rests upon two large balls of elephant dung, was desecrated by an elderly visitor who smeared white paint over its surface, claiming that the image was “blasphemous.”

Thomas Demand, Room (Zimmer), 1996
Museum of Modern Art, New York

Conceptual Photography 
  1. The construction of historical memory has been a critical issue for photography since the medium’s emergence as a method of mass reproduction and dissemination. Thomas Demand’s (b. 1964, Germany) photographic work addresses the question of veracity that remains at the heart of photography’s role in shaping the representation and understanding of history. 
  2. Demand begins with a preexisting image culled from the media, usually of a political event, which he translates into a life-size model made of colored paper and cardboard - Demand trained in sculpture - to a final life-scaled photograph. (cf: found images in Dada collage, Duchamp’s LHOOQ, and Sherrie Levine’s After series, among many others.)  So, they’re thrice removed from the subject/space they purport to depict: Space -> original photograph -> Demand’s sculpture -> Demand’s photograph. 
  3. Once they have been photographed, the models are destroyed.
  4. The titles of his works tend to be generic: Like Room (1994), based on a 1944 photo of Hitler’s wrecked HQ, or Poll (2001), traced to a series of Reuters images of workers examining ballots during the Florida recount of November 2000. 
  5. The scenes are depopulated: Hermann Göring and his claque, prominent in a 1944 photograph of Hitler’s headquarters, have been excised from Demand’s architectural model of the same scene; the election counters scrutinizing hanging chads in the Reuters recount scene have disappeared from the site reconstruction in Poll.
  6. For Room, Demand used paper to build a re-creation of the hotel room where the controversial American writer and Scientology founder L. Ron Hubbard lived and worked in 1972 and 1973. 
  7. Room is full of artifice. The even studio lighting, the sharp creases in the white pillow in the foreground, and the lack of detail on objects in the room—like the numberless face of the alarm clock or the keyless typewriter—signal that this is not reality but a mock-up of it. This tension between reality and artifice raises questions about the trust we place in photographs as accurate, unmitigated records of events, times, and places. “It’s not about the real place,” Demand has said. “It’s much more about what we have seen as the real place.”
Tracy Emin, My Bed, 1998

British contemporary installation art
1. Tracey Emin is an English artist known for her autobiographical and confessional artwork. Once the enfant terrible of the Young British Artists in the 1980s, Emin is now a Royal Academician of the Royal Academy of Arts.
2. My Bed consisted of her bed with bedroom objects in a disheveled state. It was exhibited at the Tate Gallery in 1999 as one of the shortlisted works for the Turner Prize.
3. The idea for My Bed came from a sexual yet depressive phase in the artist's life when she had remained in bed for four days without eating or drinking anything but alcohol. The artwork generated considerable media furore, particularly over the fact that the bedsheets were stained with bodily secretions and the floor had items from the artist's room, such as condoms and underwear with menstrual blood stains.
4. Two performance artists, the Chinese-British duo Mad For Real, jumped on the bed with bare torsos to improve the work, which they thought had not gone far enough. They called their performance Two Naked Men Jump into Tracey's Bed. The men also had a pillow fight on the bed for around fifteen minutes, to applause from the crowd, before being removed by security guards.
5. My Bed was bought by Charles Saatchi and displayed as part of the first exhibition when the Saatchi Gallery opened its new premises at County Hall, London. Saatchi also installed the bed in a dedicated room in his own home (creepy). When auctioned by Christie's in July 2014, the piece was sold for a little over £2.5 million.

Fun fact: this piece is too wild for both Arnason and Art Since 1900
Shirin Neshat, Untitled (Rapture), 1998

Two channel video
  1. Though Neshat has lived and worked in the West since 1974, her work explores the relationship between female identity and culture in the Islamic context, thus occupying a position between the two societies.
  2. Her films are highly choreographed and richly produced, presenting sweeping panoramas of desert and sea, old cities and moving veiled bodies. Borders and partitions such as walls, screens, curtains and the niqab feature prominently in her work.
  3. Untitled (Rapture) explores the separation of men and women in fundamentalist Islamic culture. Presented as a dual channel black and white video on facing screens, Neshat constructed two parallel narratives: men occupy a fortress (built environment) while women (pictured) move across a desert landscape to the sea (natural environment). As the white-shirted men aggressively define the boundaries o their space, the women, veiled, watch. They shout once and the men look.
  4. In Rapture, Neshat self-consciously exploits entrenched clichés about gender and space: namely, the equation of woman with irrational, wild nature and man with rational, ordered culture. The video installation is itself a study of gendered group dynamics, with the viewer literally positioned between two opposing worlds. The players in Neshat’s surreal, segregated narratives are deployed in a syncopated rhythm of action and nonaction, mutual recognition and nonrecognition, advance and retreat.
