  5. Rapture also exists as a poignant reflection on the rootless, unsettled psychology of exile. As an Iranian expatriate living in the United States, Neshat maintains a critical distance that has allowed her to locate both the poetics and the power of the veil.

Doris Salcedo, Untitled, 1998
Tate Gallery, London

1.    Colombian sculptor Doris Salcedo developed the expressive tradition of Minimalism while transforming its concern with universal experience to address local history. Since the mid 1980s, she has addressed the effects of criminal and political violence through sculptural works and installations that bear witness to death, loss and pain. Collecting testimonies from individuals living in rural Colombia, she both honors the memory of lives lost and contemplates the frequently invisible nature of trauma.
2.    In her works, she employs an uncomfortable combination of domestic furniture and building material. Instead of engaging the traditional methods of sculpture such as carving or molding, she makes her works through acts of physical and symbolic violence: filing, scratching, bending etc. 
3.    Untitledis a sculpturecombining two pieces of furniture with poured cement. Salcedo removed the two doors and drawer from an old fashioned free standing wooden wardrobe she had bought from an antique shop. She inserted an old wooden chair into the opening on one side, so that the seat is inside the body of the wardrobe. She seals the three openings of the wardrobe with the cement; cement residue filling all the crevices emphasises the sculpture’s fused appearance and evokes the sealing of a tomb.
4.    Salcedo’s careful application of cement elicits both fullness and emptiness. The material weight of the woof and cement suggest fullness, while there is literal emptiness in what is missing– clothing and personal belongings. 
5.    The forced union of disparate elements is a central feature of Salcedo’s works. For her, the tension arising from the clash of materials expresses the emotional and psychological unease at the heart of her work, motivated by the traumatic effects of civil war in Colombia.
Candida Höfer, BNF Paris VII, 1998

Düsseldorf School of Photography

  1. Höfer is a German photographer associated with the Düsseldorf School of Photography, a group of photographers who studied at the Kunstakademie Dusseldorf in the mid 1970s under Bernd and Hiller Becher, also including Andreas Gursky, Thomas Ruff and Thomas Struth, who retained the Becher's documentary method, but applied new technical possibilities of scale and color. Höfer's generation was the first to use color extensively, as aesthetics were previously deemed incompatible with the seriousness expected of documentary photography.
  2. Höfer captures the interiors of cultural institutions and displays interest for public collections such as archives, libraries, and museums. These ‘portraits of archival spaces’, as she calls them, function in two ways: they document individual rooms, uncovering structural personalities, and they query the way societies order and relate to, their collective cultural heritage. In fact, Höfer’s own photographic project behaves like an archive that explores how archival spaces behave as cultural-memory sites.
  3. Höfer specializes in large-format photographs of empty interiors that capture the "psychology of social architecture." Her famously ascetic photographs of libraries, the splendid and intimate cathedrals of knowledge, are sober and restrained. Here, she depicts the archives of the Bibliothèque Nationale de France, capturing its austere geometry. Höfer's rhythmically patterned images present interiors constructed by human intention, unearthing patterns of order, logic, and disruption, yet largely devoid of human presence, her trademark.
  4. Herself a bibliophile with a large home library, she has also photographed the British Library in London, the Pierpont Library in New York, and the Hamburg University Library, among many others.
  5. It marks a dramatic shift in Höfer's practice, from small format photographs to an oversized format which also reflects a change in her working method from using a small flexible camera, to using a heavy Linhof plate camera with a tripod, that delivers very sharp images.
  6. Höfer forgoes any staging of the locations, uses natural light, and her photographs are often taken from a classic straight-on frontal angle (as seen here) or seek a diagonal in the composition.  Her attention to aesthetic concerns has built her a reputation for bringing the conventions of painting and a sensitive attention to color to her photographs, resulting in images that radiate a comforting serenity that is rarely found in contemporary photography. 
  7. Höfer's photographs capture the auratic and timeless quality of her spaces, asserting their continued significance in present societies. Perhaps in these obsessive efforts to monumentalize and conserve archival spaces Höfer reveals a subtle fear that they might disappear.
Thomas Hirschhorn, Raymond Carver Altar, 1998­‐9

Interactive, archival aesthetics/ public space art?
  1. Thomas Hirschhorn (born 1957) is a Swiss artist. He lives and works in Paris. His work is often made of readymade and everyday materials.
  2. Raymond Carver altar is one example of Hirschorn’s altar series, an artistic take on the “ spontaneous altars, that one sees here or there, made by those who wish to give a precarious homage to someone deceased on the spot, by accident, suicide, murder or heart attack (Gianni Versace, J.F. Kennedy Jr., Olaf Palme).” 
  3. The altars that Hischorn creates are for artists and writers whose work he admires. He has honored Piet Mondrian, Otto Freundlich, Ingeborg Bachmann, and Raymond Carver.
  4. From the artist:  “I choose locations that are not in the center or in strategic point of a city, just any place. In the same way as people can die anywhere. Most people don’t die in the middle of a square or on a beautiful boulevard; their deaths rarely happen in a strategic location, even famous people don’t die in « the center ». There is no hierarchy of location between anonymous and famous people. There are unexpected locations. The location is important not in relationship to the layout of the city, but in relation to the people who died. This gives me the plan for locating the altars. These altars are questioning the status of a monument today by their form, by their location, and by their duration. Thus, the choice of location is determining for my statement on work in public space and my critique of monuments.The forms of these homages are alike, whether made for celebrities or made for the unknown: candles, flowers, often wrapped in transparent paper, teddy bears and stuffed animals, written messages on scraps of paper with hearts and other love symbols. With this wild mixture of forms, the messages of love and attachment to the deceased person are expressed without any aesthetic concern; it is this personal commitment that interests me. It comes from the heart. It is pure energy. One is not preoccupied with the form-quality of the elements, but only with the message that is to be conveyed. The forms of these altars, that are profane and not religious, convey a visual form based on weakness. The forms and locations of the altars show the precarious aspect of the work. It is because of necessity and urgency that they are there. The cruelty and the non-spectacular of these monuments makes them untouchable by people walking by, proprietors, street-cleaners, dog-walkers, policemen. Everyone could be concerned. Everyone is concerned. These altars will disappear sooner or later. The average duration of the altars is of two weeks. The disappearance of the altar is as important as its presence. The memory of what is important doesn’t need a monument.”
  5. Such works, which exist somewhere between a public installation an obscure performance, and a private archive, can also be found in nonart spaces, which might render them even more difficult to decipher in aesthetic terms; nonetheless, they can be taken to indicate a distinctive turn in recent art. 
  6. They draw on a wide range of artistic precedents such as the performative objects of Fluxus, the humble materials of Arte Povera, and the site-specific strategies of institution-critical artists like Marcel Broodthaers, Michael Asher, and Hans Haacke. Yet the current generation has also transformed the familiar devices of the readymade collaboration, and installation.
OMA (Office for Metropolitan Architecture), Seattle Public Library, Seattle, Washington, 1999-­ 2004

Postmodern Architecture
  1. Rem Koolhaas (b. 1944, Netherlands) is an architect, urbanist, and theorist who has made the unexpected a central tenet to his practice, working in the deconstructionist tradition of Postmodernism. 
  2. Koolhaas understands urbanism as “the staging of uncertainty.” 
  3. Koolhaas rejects the tabula rasa planning of Le Corbusier and the New Urbanists. Instead, the solutions suggested by his firm OMA (the Office of Metropolitan Architecture) often revolve around “Megastructures”: centralized collections of multiuse spaces that concentrate all manner of civic activity within a single structure. These frequently respond to local metropolitan issues; the content and needs dictate the form. 
  4. The Seattle Public Library functions as one of these Megastructures: The library's programs are arranged across five platforms (parking, staff, meeting, Book Spiral, HQ). Four flowing "in between" planes (kids, living room, Mixing Chamber, reading room) occupy interstitial zones, for a total of nine “programmatic clusters.” Each of these is architecturally defined and equipped for dedicated performance. Together, these dictate the building's distinctive faceted shape. 
  5. The library’s striking appearance consists of discrete "floating platforms" seemingly wrapped in a large steel net around glass skin, unifying the programmatic clusters on the platforms and in the interstitial spaces. 
  6. From OMA’s website: “OMA's ambition is to redefine the library as an institution no longer exclusively dedicated to the book, but rather as an information store where all potent forms of media – new and old – are presented equally and legibly. In an age in which information can be accessed anywhere, it is the simultaneity of media and (more importantly) the curatorship of its contents that will make the library vital.”
  7. The Mixing Chamber, on the third floor, is an area of librarian-patron interaction – a trading floor for information orchestrated to fulfill an essential (though often neglected) need for expert interdisciplinary help. Librarians guide readers up into the four-story Books Spiral, a continuous ramp of shelving with sections designed to be flexible and to expand as the library’s holdings grow. This designing of spaces to facilitate interraction and anticipate shifting future needs is typical of OMA’s approach to design.

Emily Jacir, Munir, From the series Where We Come From, 2001‐03
Whitney Museum of American Art

Palestinian-American contemporary photography / neo-Conceptual
1. Emily Jacir is a Palestinian-American artist and filmmaker, living between New York and Ramallah.
2. Where We Come From is a series of collaborations with Palestinians who were prohibited either from returning to their homeland or from moving freely throughout their country.
3. Jacir posed the same question to these individuals: “If I could do anything for you, anywhere in Palestine, what would it be?” This resulted in 30 pairings of photographs and texts as well as a video which record Jacir’s efforts to realize the personal requests of Palestinians living around the world. Each photograph and text (which appears in both Arabic and English) documents a single person’s response to the question, as well as Jacir’s efforts to satisfy the request.
4. Using her American passport to move across borders demarcating the Gaza Strip, the West Bank, and Israel, Jacir fulfilled desires ranging from the practical (bringing clothes and gifts to family members) to the whimsical (water a tree in a village).
5. Munir—a man who lived in Bethlehem but was denied access to nearby Jerusalem by Israeli authorities—requested: “Go to my mother’s grave in Jerusalem on her birthday and put flowers and pray.”
6. Neo-Conceptual work: the physical materiality of the work is subordinated to the intellectual spirit and its process of creation; blurs the boundaries between performance and photography
7. Other contemporary artists/choreographers thinking about mobility in the Palestinian context: Farah Saleh, Samar Haddad King
Zaha Hadid, BMW Central Building, Leipzig, Germany, 2001-­5

Deconstructivist architecture
  1. Hadid’s buildings exploit the possibility of Deconstructivist theory, which emphasizes the experience of the spectator in relation to the built environment. She imagined the built environment as a means of nudging or even jolting the viewer into sharper self-awareness through a continual reorientation. To achieve this, Deconstructivist architecture often juxtaposes seemingly incompatible forms or spatial relations, creating an almost theatrical experience of anticipation, tension, and resolution.
  2. A competition was held for the design of a central building for the BMW factory to function as the physical connection of the three production buildings. It also needed to house the administrative and employee needs spaces. Hadid's design took this idea of connectivity and used it to inform every aspect of the new building. It serves as a connection for the assembly process steps and the employees.
  3. Designed as a series of overlapping and interconnecting levels and spaces, it blurs the separation between parts of the complex and between traditional status groups, through an internal organization of common spaces or “nerve centers” that encourages the integration of white and blue collar workers in the factory. There is a social utopianism to the design in this way (Bauhaus influence)
  4. The offices, meeting rooms and public relations facilities are built around elevated conveyors that transfer the cars from one production shed to the other, so that the production process is visible and becomes part of the architecture itself.
  5. All of the load-bearing walls, floors, and office levels are made of cast-in-place concrete, while the roof structure is composed of structural steel beams and space frame construction. The facade is clad in simple materials of like corrugated metal, channel glass, and glass curtain walls.
James Turrell, Milk Run III, 2002

(American) contemporary installation art 
1.    Born in California, Turrell grew up with an enduring love of aviation and the sky, as well as a fascination with the sky. His Quaker background also substantially formed his approach to life and art, with its emphasis on silent access to the “light within.” 
2.    He is considered the founder of “light and space art,” and his installations explore the mysteries of how we perceive light. He manipulates our perception light in order to reveal our understanding of space before us, the way we see things within it, as fundamentally a kind of optical illusion. 
3.    Turrell sets up enormous field of colored lights, which are often produced through a slight opening in a gallery wall backed by an oblique pane that is brilliantly illuminated but whose exact location is almost impossible to determine for that very reason. 
4.    The title of this work, “Milk Run” refers to the short flights that pilots would make to pick up milk from farmers in rural areas. It is part of a series of works called Wedgeworks, in which he creates shimmering colors that play across the surface. 
5.    A Turrell installation seems to exist as a spatial afterimage, appearing as a phantom shape projected by our own retinal activity and nervous system rather than as a fixed object in its own right. Instead of reflexive viewers and delineated spacaes of Minimalism, such art tends to effect a kind of sublime experience in which the spectator is overwhelmed by an apparition that they seem to project into being. 
6.    Describing his light installations he states, “I like to accord light the ‘thingness’ that it should have. Generally, we look at light as a form of revelation of something… Rather than illuminating other things, I’m interested in light’s thingness, its object-making, think-making kind of ability.”

Olafur Eliasson, The Weather Project, 2003-­4
Tate Modern, London

Installation Art

  1. Eliasson is a Danish–Icelandic artist known for sculptures and large-scale installation art employing elemental materials such as light, water, and air temperature, to alter viewers’ sensory perceptions. His art is driven by his interest in perception, movement, embodied experience, and feelings of self. Spanning sculpture, painting, photography, film, and installation, he engages the broader public sphere through architectural projects, interventions in civic space, arts education, policy-making, and issues of sustainability and climate change.
  2. The Weather Project created a sun and generated a fine mist in the Tate Modern's Turbine Hall, harking back to a tradition of immersive spaces in which hyper-awareness of embodied perception is the aim of the work. A glance overhead to see where the mist escaped, revealed that the ceiling was replaced by a reflection of the space below. At the far end of the hall was a giant semi-circular form made up of hundreds of mono-frequency lamps. The arc repeated in the mirror overhead produced a sphere linking the real space with the reflection.
  3. The dichotomy of nature and culture is toyed with, marking this as contemporary Romanticism, with the traditional subject of landscape painting rendered in mechanistic sculpture. It is intended to complicate the sublime loss of self in the romantic experience of nature by making viewers aware of the artifice of the sun, as they could see the machine generating the light and mist.
  4. Eliasson's practice can be placed within the tradition of Minimalism and Post Minimalism, particularly the California Light and Space Movement, as well as the Chromosaturations of Carlos Cruz Diez. He also references the writings of Maurice Merleau-Ponty and cites Dan Graham and Bruce Nauman as precedents for his work.
  5. The work speaks to the increasing spectacularization of museum space and the need to fill ever larger spaces with overwhelming works, leading critics like James Meyer in ArtForum to claim that this kind of art is "marshalled to overwhelm and pacify" rather than "inducing awareness and provoking thought."
  6. In 2008, he crafted four man-made waterfalls in collaboration with the Public Art Fund, and placed them around New York City along the East River, at a cost of over $15 million. He also took 30 icebergs from a Greenland fjord to London (2018) in order to raise awareness about the urgency of climate change. 
  7. In 1995, he founded Studio Olafur Eliasson in Berlin, which comprises a large team of cooks, craftsmen, architects, archivists, researchers, administrators, programmers, art historians, and specialized technicians.
